PETITION.PRESENTERS: Brown, Sen Bob; Lees, Sen Meg
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance; and

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these three planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Brown(from 216 citizens)and Senator Lees(from 200 citizens)

Motion (by Senator McKiernan) proposed:

That the time for the presentation of the report of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee on the need to protect Australian citizens against discrimination and vilification on the grounds of their sexuality or transgender identity, as dealt with by the Sexuality Discrimination Bill 1995 [1996], be extended to the last day of sitting in 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I object strongly to this delay. This matter was referred to the committee in May 1996. The committee concluded evidence gathering in October 1996 and it was due to report by the middle of this year. There has already been one delay. There is now another delay being sought which effectively means that a result will not come out of this committee until at least March next year.

SPEECH.PARA: There are hundreds of thousands of Australians who are concerned about that. The committee is dealing with the business of discrimination on the basis of sexuality. This affects a large number of gay men and lesbians, particularly in Western Australia and Tasmania where there is no protection under the law from discrimination on the basis of people's sexuality. It is an extremely important matter. The committee has received a large number of good submissions. They include related stories of lesbians being evicted from public housing, of gay teachers being sacked and of young homosexual people being harassed to the point of suicide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sacked from schools.

—Do you think that that is a fair matter? We are getting the interjection from the government benches that gay people ought not be enabled to follow the teaching profession. That is an example of why this legislation should be dealt with in this parliament. That is why there is this urgency—because that sort of bigotry and discrimination is occurring in our community. It is time this nation took a stand against it. It is a critical matter. The committee has had a long period since its deliberations. It ought to be bringing a report to this chamber. There is no ostensible reason why it cannot. There are other matters like euthanasia where committee hearings, determinations and reports back to this chamber were done in the express lane. Why not this one? I can only assume that there are political reasons why this report has not come before the Senate, and I oppose that. That is just not good enough. I would like to hear more as to why this chamber is not getting this report and cannot deal with this legislation and, therefore, the concerns that many Australians hold about this particularly insidious form of discrimination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I draw the Senate's attention to pages 78 and 79 of today's Notice Paper. That, I believe, gives the reasons why we are seeking this delay. On page 78, you can see that the brother‐sister committee of the references committee has lodged 17 reports to this chamber. On page 79, you will see that six other reports have been lodged by the references committee. The simple reason why we are seeking a delay is the amount of work the committee has before it. I assure the Senate, Senator Brown and all those who made submissions to the committee and who appeared before the committee that there is no deliberate delay. There is no attempt at a deliberate delay.

SPEECH.PARA: It is simply a matter of the workload that is before the committee and the decisions of this Senate which give priority to legislation that comes before the committees. We are given reporting days on those references to legislation committees and we have to give a priority to them. That is a decision of the Senate. Speaking on behalf of all members of the committee, we will certainly be endeavouring to get the report delivered to the chamber by the end of this year. We do not want any undue delays.

I would like, personally, to get on with the inquiry into the legal aid system in Australia and access to justice, but unfortunately, because of other pressures, we are just not able to do that either. There are many other things we would like to do. I trust that the Senate is satisfied with this very brief explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I put the question that the motion moved by Senator McKiernan be agreed to.

The purpose of the Airport Demand Management Bill is to give effect to the Government's commitment to cap aircraft movements at Kingsford Smith Airport (KSA) at 80 movements per hour through the implementation of a slot system.

In addition to honouring an election commitment, the Bill is the Government's response to Mr Anthony Albanese's Private Member's Bill, which sought to force the Government into a pre-emptive move towards legislating for a cap on movements at KSA. While it is proposed to begin the implementation of the slots system on a cooperative basis with industry, legislation is required to support this process and if necessary to resolve any conflicting positions within the aviation industry.
It is therefore essential that the Sydney Airport Demand Management Bill be passed in the 1997 Spring sittings.
(Circulated with the authority of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development.)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee: Joint

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report entitled ANZUS after 45 years: Seminar Proceedings, 11‐12 August 1997 together with minutes of proceedings. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard and I also seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The report I am tabling today is a record of the proceedings of a Seminar conducted by the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade in August this year. This seminar assembled some of the most pre-eminent and authoritative speakers from both Australia and the United States, to share their views on the current status, relevance and future prospects for the Security Treaty between Australia, New Zealand and the United States, otherwise known by its acronym, the ANZUS Treaty.

The alliance with the United States continues to be the most important of Australia's Defence agreements. Few would dispute this point. The previous Government's Defence White Paper accepted the value of the US alliance as a key element of our Defence policy, and this Government's recently-released Foreign and Trade Policy White Paper reaffirms the importance of this relationship. I expect that the soon-to‐be-released Strategic Review similarly will reflect that strategic reality.
This seminar sought to inform the Parliament, and the wider public through open discussion, of all the provisions and the implications of those provisions of the Treaty.

The US Ambassador, in opening the seminar, commented upon both the flexibility and adaptability of the ANZUS Treaty. Its brief and relatively simple wording has allowed it to evolve with changing strategic circumstances. This is the key to the Treaty's continued relevance: that the true value to Australia from the ANZUS alliance arises from the myriad activities, exercises, exchanges and cooperative ventures enabled under its auspices, rather than from what is prescribed by the Treaty.

This was the main emphasis of the seminar. It was not an occasion to reflect on the military ties between Australia and the United States, strong though they are; from the links forged in the crucible of the wars of this century and annealed in the prolonged and testing uncertainties of the Cold War.

It is true that the Alliance was propelled into existence by the common threat of an expansionist Soviet empire, but at heart it was an alliance between nations which was based on shared democratic and cultural ideals and a shared belief in a system of fair and just international relations. Now, over 45 years later, those fundamental considerations are as relevant as ever and remain the strong foundation on which the alliance is based.

The one great internal change in ANZUS has come about because of the adoption by New Zealand of its prohibition of ship visits by nuclear powered vessels. Discussion took place of current New Zealand defence policies, regrettably, without official representation from the New Zealand government. New Zealand's suspension from trilateral activities is an unresolved issue for the Alliance though this is of greater concern to Australia than to the United States or New Zealand.

The Committee, in reporting its views of the seminar, chose to keep its remarks brief. In so doing, the words of the individual speakers have been allowed to stand by themselves. While individually noteworthy, these presentations collectively provide a comprehensive overview of the alliance, and of the continuing value it provides, not just for Australia, but also for the United States, and for most regional nations.

As a final point, I wish to note that, in the papers presented to the seminar, and in the issues raised by the audience present, there emerged no fundamental questioning of the rationale for Australia's continued membership of ANZUS. Following two days of discussions, the consensus that emerged was that there remains distinct advantages in maintaining the ANZUS relationship, and the Treaty is likely to remain a pillar of Australia's national security policy into the foreseeable future.

In conclusion, I would like to thank the many members of the military, academic, foreign affairs and diplomatic communities, and members of the general public who participated in the seminar, and particularly the score of speakers who generously contributed their time to ensure its success through the quality of their presentations. I believe their efforts have contributed to the creation of a valuable reference source and an important collation of contemporary thought on the ANZUS alliance. I commend these proceedings to you.

BREAK.PARA: The Australian Firearms Buyback which has been a central part of the implementation of the nationwide agreement on firearms regulation comes to a close on 30 September 1997. To date more than 540,000 firearms have been surrendered in the various States and Territories.

The National Firearms Program Implementation Act 1996, which appropriated the funds required to reimburse the States and Territories for the compensation paid for surrendered firearms, followed the letter of that nationwide agreement. It applied, however, only to those firearms which were expressly prohibited by that agreement.

There have in addition, of course, been historically prohibited weapons, including sub‐machine guns, heavy machine guns and other similar weapons in the community. It was certainly the intention of the Australasian Police Ministers' Council that these weapons should also be surrendered for fair and proper compensation.

To ensure that this compensation can be properly reimbursed, it is necessary to provide authority for the Attorney‐General to certify that the surrender of particular firearms or other weapons is consistent with the spirit of the national program and to allow the Attorney‐General to authorise payments for the purpose of providing compensation to firearm owners and dealers.

The bill is of major importance in the implementation of the national firearms program. It is, therefore, extremely important that the bill be passed as quickly as possible. The national firearms program has had bi‐partisan support throughout and I ask that that support continue.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

Since its creation under the NRTC Act 1991 the National Road Transport Commission has been the means of carrying forward a major program of reforms in road transport. The Commission reports to the Australian Transport Council, recommending policies and legislation for reforming road transport and producing a uniform, consistent regulatory environment.

Road transport affects every part of Australian life. Inefficient road transport that is more costly than it needs to be affects everyone; improvements in efficiency and safety benefit every Australian.
This government from the outset has reiterated its commitment to road transport reform. When in opposition we gave bipartisan support to the road transport reform process.

Having different regulations, different inspection requirements, different permit criteria from one jurisdiction to another is frustrating, time consuming and costly. Fragmented regulations in states and Territories impede the competitiveness of industry and restrict the effective integration of the Australian transport market.
This government has committed itself wholeheartedly to bringing the regulatory and operating environment for road transport up to date.
Since the NRTC was created in 1991 heavy vehicle charges have been reformed.
The Road Transport Reform (Vehicles and Traffic) Act has been passed to provide the basis for new, nationally uniform road rules
The Road Transport Reform (Heavy Vehicles Registration) Act allows for uniform and consistent registration requirements across the country
The Road Transport Reform (Dangerous Goods) Act provides for a safer operating regime for the transport by road of dangerous goods.
Driving hours for long distance coaches and for trucks have reached an advanced stage of development

Although a great deal has been accomplished, much remains to be done. Such matters as driving hours, speed management, have consumed vastly more time and involved a great deal more consultation than could have been envisaged at the outset. Pilot projects on alternative compliance for the management of vehicle maintenance, mass limits, and fatigue management have proved to be more complex than was thought necessary when these projects were commenced.
The reform process must continue. The tasks that have commenced need to be brought to completion.
More progress has been made in reforming road transport legislation and in achieving uniformity and consistency of approach in the last six years than had been made in the previous half century.

In accordance with the NRTC Act 1991 the government set up a review last year of the functions and achievements of the Commission. That review found that the Commission should continue through an amendment to its enabling legislation, but that several improvements needed to be made to improve its functioning and effectiveness.
In February the Ministerial Council on Road Transport accepted the main features of the review report and gave in principle approval to proceed.
Since that time Commonwealth, state and territory officials have been working to translate those principles into amendments to the NRTC Act and Heavy and Light Vehicles Agreements.

Accordingly, this bill will extend the NRTC Act by one year to enable the Commission to continue in operation. The bill also provides for Commissioners to be reappointed, if necessary, in the interim period.

This bill is an interim measure. It is intended to allow the reform process to continue while the legislation is finalised to place road transport reform on a more solid foundation to deliver the returns to the industry for the benefit of all Australians.
In this bill no changes will be made to present arrangements for the operation of the Commission.

It is the government's intention to introduce a substantive bill to put the recommendations of the review into effect. The changes that will result from the review will make substantial improvements to the operational efficiency, the direction and the accountability of the Commission. It is intended to introduce the bill to give effect to those changes later in this session.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges:

(1) Whether the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), or any other person, sought, by force or threat, or by other improper means, to influence the Australian Law Reform Commission, and/or its President, Mr Alan Rose, in respect of evidence to be given, namely the making of a submission, and/or the giving of evidence in person, to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, and whether the Attorney‐General, or any other person, induced the commission, or its President, to refrain from giving that evidence.
(2) Whether any contempt was committed in respect of this matter.

The matter we are discussing this morning should be of concern to all of us, particularly to all Australians. We are talking this morning about activity undertaken by the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) or on his behalf—activity which raises issues of breach of privilege, possible illegality, stifling debate and, underlying all of it, the issue of incompetence on behalf of the Attorney. The charges go very much to the heart of our parliamentary system. The Clerk of the Senate wrote in his first advice to Senator Faulkner:

Past judgments of the courts leave no doubt that the actions that have been specified would, if proved, amount to contempt of court and an attempt to pervert the course of justice if undertaken in respect of witnesses or potential witnesses before courts. Equally, those actions could, if proved, be dealt with by a House as a contempt of Parliament and could be successfully prosecuted as offences under the Parliamentary Privileges Act.

We are here talking about behaviour which goes very much to the core of the operation of the parliament and its committees. In short, we are talking about the nobbling of witnesses. Section 12 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act relevantly states:

A person shall not, by . . . intimidation . . . threat . . . or by other improper means . . . influence another person in respect of any evidence given or to be given before . . . a committee, or induce another person to refrain from giving such evidence.

It is a serious offence that is punishable, in the case of a natural person, by $5,000 or imprisonment for six months. An offence of this nature can be prosecuted in the courts. A breach of parliamentary privilege may also be penalised by the Senate under subsection 7(1) of the Parliamentary Privileges Act by imposing a penalty of imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months. The laws of this country have obviously determined that the offences we are talking about, the activity we are talking about, are serious offences.

The real issue here essentially is: was pressure put on the Australian Law Reform Commission by the Attorney or someone on his behalf, an agent of his, in respect of that commission giving evidence, or about to give evidence, before a parliamentary committee? The question before the Senate today relates to whether, on or about 25 September 1997, the Attorney-General caused the acting secretary to his department, Mr Reaburn, to influence the Australian Law Reform Commission and its President, Mr Rose, not to make a submission or give evidence in person to the Joint Standing Committee on Native Title.

When we talk about that committee let us remember that we are talking about an issue that has a high profile; we are talking about an issue with respect to native title which this parliament will have to confront over the next few months—in fact, probably over the next few years.

On 17 September 1997, Mr Rose wrote to the joint standing committee confirming that the commission `would be pleased to present oral evidence to the committee'. Mr Rose also enclosed the first page of the draft of the commission's intended submission to the committee. The secretary of the committee, Mr Grundy, responded later that same day seeking confirmation that that commission would present evidence to that committee at 11 a.m. on Friday, 3 October—this Friday.

On 19 September, Mr Rose formally accepted the committee's invitation and indicated that he was intending to provide the commission's written submission `early next week'—that is, the week commencing 23 September. Then on 24 September, Mr Rose unexpectedly confirmed in writing the commission's intention to withdraw its acceptance to present evidence before the committee and also confirmed that the commission `would not now be making a written submission to the committee in respect to the inquiry'.

Why the change of heart? Why did the commission withdraw? On Monday this week, in the Sydney Morning Herald, it was revealed that on 24 September 1997, the Attorney-General, through the acting secretary to his department, Mr Norman Reaburn, told the commission not to give evidence to the joint standing committee. In response to this allegation, Mr Williams's spokesman advised that Mr Williams had had talks with Mr Reaburn `about the committee operating within its references, and the acting secretary passed those discussions on'.

One thing that can be said right at the outset is that if you look at all of the responses of the Attorney throughout this particular matter, as with some previous ones, he has a great capacity to lead people off the track, to mislead. When it comes to misleading, this Attorney-General is a recidivist.

As I say, that was the response from the spokesman for the Attorney. Mr Rose confirmed that Mr Williams had previously protested to the commission in relation to a submission that the commission provided at the request of Senator Minchin and the Wik task force in relation to the same subject—the Native Title Amendment Bill 1997 . In the words of Mr Rose, Mr Williams protested that `our putting the submission was not within current reference'. Mr Rose indicated that he rejected that view.

When asked about this in the House of Representatives on Monday this week, the Attorney confirmed that he had written to Mr Rose on 28 August complaining that, in his view, the commission was acting outside its current terms of reference. Importantly, the Attorney deliberately chose, despite a specific question about the conversation held between Mr Reaburn and Mr Rose asked by the member for Banks (Mr Melham), not to advise the House about the content of that conversation. He deliberately created the impression that the only discussions that had taken place were academic discussions about whether the commission was acting inside its terms of reference in wanting to make the submission.

Mr Williams later appeared on the ABC's PM program. He repeated that version of events. He told the reporter, Mr Ross Solley, that as a result of Mr Reaburn's conversation with Mr Rose, the choice of whether to make the submission or not was left completely in Mr Rose's hands. Mr Williams said:
If that is his, Mr Rose's decision, that's it. If he's summonsed by the Committee, then no doubt he will appear before the Committee.

However, that basically misleads the public and it misleads the parliament in terms of his earlier answer. Importantly, Mr Williams made this statement immediately after Mr Rose had preceded him on PM . Despite having heard Mr Rose, I would imagine, he went on to make a statement which was intended to mislead. In the PM interview Mr Rose said:

Last Tuesday I had a conversation with the Acting Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, Norman Reaburn, in which he conveyed to me the very great dislike which the Attorney had for the proposal that we were proposing to put to the parliamentary committee . . .
He had great dislike for the proposal that the commission was putting to the parliamentary committee. Mr Rose says there was real concern about the content of the proposal. He continued:
. . . that is he was strongly opposed, he, the Attorney was strongly opposed to that draft submission which we'd provided to the Committee.
Mr Rose goes on to say, quite pointedly:

And it was said to me that if we proceeded with that submission we could expect a second letter from the Attorney-General in very, very strong language in effect directing us to conduct no functions that weren't within those provisions of the Act dealing with references.
Mr Solley put this again to Mr Rose. Mr Solley asked:
Can I just clarify, just finally, what impression you were left with after your discussion with Mr Williams' department. Was it your impression that the Attorney-General would wind back your powers.
Again, Mr Rose responded:
Well, it was put to me very directly that we would get a second letter in very, very strong terms that would be in effect an indication of the Government's determination to do that.

Mr Rose went on to repeat these comments in an article that appeared in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald . This is the reality of the choice that he did have, which was no choice. It was an offer he could not refuse. He said:

I was given a choice—hold back the submission and be able to discuss commission guidelines later, or go ahead with the submission and get a very strong letter from the Attorney-General directing us only to work on formal references from him . . .
Mr Rose says:
So we were really given no choice at all.
Despite this being on the public record and despite the Attorney-General knowing this, the spokesman for Mr Williams stated in response:

Mr Reaburn denies requesting the withdrawal of the submission or threatening to narrow the commission's role if it did not do so, and Mr Williams denies asking him to request the submission's withdrawal.

There is a direct conflict of evidence here. I know who I believe. Later on, on Tuesday night, on the 7.30 Report Mr Williams himself admitted that an attempt to improperly influence Mr Rose had been made to limit the powers of the commission. Mr Williams said:
What we suggested to him—
Mr Rose—

is that he had a choice: either to go the route he wanted to go . . . appeared to want to go, or to not go down that route. If he went that route, he would know that he would be acting contrary to the views that I had expressed, and that's as high as it goes.
Ms Byrne, from the 7.30 Report , then asked:
He—
Mr Rose—

has already told that it you were very unhappy; you had a very great dislike; and he feared that it could result in limiting his commission's powers. I ask you again, if it's not a threat, what is it?

I think Jennifer Byrne got it right. If that was not a threat, what is a threat? Mr Rose was basically told, `You either pull the submission or else if you go ahead, we're going to cut back on your powers, your functions and all your activities.' As I say, that was an offer that Mr Rose could not refuse.

We also have at the end of the day the first admission by the attorney that what Mr Rose has been saying all along was right. The Acting Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Reaburn, did leave the commission with no choice: it either pulled its head in and withdrew the submission or it would have had its powers reduced. Then in parliament yesterday the attorney again admitted what I think we had known all along. At first in his normal way of trying to gloss over conversations Mr Williams tried to gloss over the conversation by claiming:
this is the conversation between Reaburn and Rose—

was left on the basis that it was ultimately the Commission's decision whether or not to comment on the Native Title Bill. But, if they were to do so, they knew that it was my view that they would be doing so without statutory authority.

This is despite the fact that during the term of this Attorney-General, the commissioners appeared before parliamentary committees on 21 occasions, giving evidence. During the term of this Attorney-General on 49 occasions in two years they have provided evidence not just to parliamentary committees but to all arms of government, state and federal. In direct contradiction of this innocent, naive interpretation of events given by the attorney, he quoted from a minute which Mr Reaburn made of the conversation. Mr Reaburn said:
I told him—
Mr Rose—

that the Attorney regarded the justification for making the submission to the Wik Task Force as intellectually untenable. I told him he was "at the cross‐roads"—the Commission could go forward with the submission to the PJC and he would receive an `unhappy letter' from the Attorney. Or they could not go forward, and he would not receive any letter—instead he and I would sit down and try to work out a set of ground rules relating to submissions which would satisfy all the parties.

In other words, Mr Reaburn made it clear that the commission should either behave or it would get a strong direction from the attorney as to what matters it can and cannot carry out and in what manner it can carry out its duties. I think such a statement is clearly an improper statement. It clearly influenced the commission to withdraw its submission to the joint standing committee on 24 September. It also proves two things: it proves the ineptness and incompetence not just of the attorney but of Mr Reaburn. Mr Reaburn is a person who has just assumed the position of acting secretary to the department, and he is trying hard to fill that job, but in this process he does not come out smelling all that well.

What we also have out of this series of events is an attorney deliberately misleading the House, the media and the Australian public. His comments have not been consistent. No matter how much they have tried to deceive, his comments have not deceived.

The attorney's defence to this is threefold. First, I note that he has deliberately sought to evade discussion of that conversation between Reaburn and Rose that took place on 24 September, preferring instead to refer to his own letter of 28 August 1997. That communique is not in dispute.

Second, the attorney seeks to characterise the conversation between Reaburn and Rose as one which merely academically discussed the appropriate powers of the commission. As I have put on the record already, Mr Williams has since admitted that the conversation was more than an academic discussion. Third, he seeks to defend his actions on the basis that, in any event, it was proper for him to tell the commission to act within its powers and pull its head in.

In this regard, I do not think that whether the commission does have the power is genuinely a matter of dispute. Whilst it is true that the commission has no explicit reference on the Native Title Amendment Bill, the commission does have other references that are relevant.

Mr Rose has explained that the commission had a previous reference on Aboriginal customary law. The commission, pursuant to section 24 of the 1996 act, has power to examine matters that unduly trespass on people's personal rights, including property rights such as native title. It has a duty to consider whether Australia is acting in compliance with its international obligations, such as the Convention on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination—a matter which is clearly in contention under the current bill. The commission also has a specific reference before it at the moment in relation to federal civil litigation process. Of course, that includes the operation of the National Native Title Tribunal.

So there is a very powerful case to argue that the commission does have sufficient terms of reference to make the submission. It has always acted on this basis over the last 21 years of its existence. In this regard, it needs to be placed on the record that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Prime Minister, Senator Minchin, saw absolutely no problems in getting advice from this commission specifically on the issue of the Native Title Amendment Bill. The attorney is yet to explain why Senator Minchin and the Prime Minister's department thought obtaining evidence from this commission was appropriate while the attorney does not think so.

Section 26 of the commission act specifically requires the commission to give evidence to a committee when requested to do so. The power of the attorney to direct the commission in relation to various matters does not extend to the power to prevent it from appearing and making submissions.

In the last 24 hours, the attorney in his defence has invoked the evidence of Mr Burmester, who at his last outing just a few months ago tried to protect the government in respect of a privileges claim. I must say that Mr Burmester's advice can be seen to be stillborn. He says that, since the commission had no power, under his interpretation, to give evidence, then the attorney is not in breach of privilege.

That advice runs directly contrary to the advice of the Clerk of the Senate. The response of the attorney to this was twofold. First of all, he made a grossly inappropriate and unfair attack on Mr Evans's competence. Second, he hid behind that advice. There is now a direct conflict with the advice of Mr Burmester, a person who also is in a difficult situation, a person who is subservient to the attorney. Mr Burmester is someone who is under the attorney's direction. He should never have been asked to provide this advice. It is totally inappropriate for someone directly under the Attorney-General's supervision to be asked to give advice as to whether his boss is in the clear or not.
Yesterday we had the advice of Mr Evans and the President's statement to the parliament. On the critical point, the President said:

. . . the point has been made in public controversy about this matter that the Attorney-General has a statutory power to direct the Australian Law Reform Commission as to the work it is to undertake. Improper influence with a witness, however, can be constituted by an act which a person is otherwise lawfully entitled to take. This has been made clear by the courts in relation to contempt of court, and also by the Privileges Committee in relation to interference with Senate witnesses.
I think it is quite important to put on the record that the President also stated:

. . . the point has also been made in public controversy that the Australian Law Reform Commission does not have a statutory function of giving evidence to parliamentary committees. The question of whether a witness has been interfered with, however, does not depend on the nature of any evidence to be given or on the power or ability of a witness to give it. This principle also applies equally to legal proceedings and parliamentary proceedings.

So, in respect of the one point that the Attorney-General is trying to hide behind, the one emanating from the Burmester advice—that is, the commission had no power, therefore the attorney cannot be in breach of privilege for attempting to bring it back to the powers that it does have—the advice of the Clerk and the statement of the President of the Senate to this place yesterday run directly contradictory to it.

Once again, Mr Burmester really needs to go back to his law books and reassess the advice that has been given here. I suggest to him that when he does that he should actually have a look at the history and the record on privileges in this place and in the House of Representatives. That might help him.

In essence, what we have here is an attempted cover‐up of the ALRC's submission to the parliamentary committee. It had critical advice, which I would have thought the government would welcome. The government is out of its depth in trying to tackle the native title issue and respond to Wik. It should take into account any advice available to it, but in this case it has tried to cover it up. Thereafter, it has tried to cover up the cover‐up by getting the native title committee to oppose the commission coming before it. Very few matters that come before us are of graver weight than this one. This matter raises critical issues of privilege and needs to be addressed by a full inquiry accordingly. That is why I have moved the motion this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Indeed, we have a weighty matter before us today, as Senator Bolkus has stated. The Senate's power to adjudicate an allegation of a breach of privilege and contempt of parliament involves the exercise of judicial power. This reinforces the great responsibility which we discharge when we consider a privileges issue. We sit here more as judges than as political partisans. So yesterday, when the President ruled that this matter had precedence, the President in no way was making a predetermination of any guilt or of any finding. She was simply saying that this was a very serious allegation and it should have precedence.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, we now have the task to consider whether the matter at stake constitutes one which involves an improper act tending substantially to obstruct the Senate. That is what we have before us today. The task is akin to a magistrate who determines whether a matter should be committed for trial.

In the notice of motion that Senator Bolkus relies on, he has drawn the words from the Parliamentary Privileges Act, where he refers to whether the Attorney-General or any other person sought, by force or threat or by other improper means, to influence the Australian Law Reform Commission in the giving of evidence. That basically is the nub of the allegation by Senator Bolkus. As he has outlined today, what we are looking at are the actions of the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and the Acting Secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Norman Reaburn.

In relation to how we approach this matter, the Senate adopted a number of procedures to guide it in its consideration. These criteria are set out in Senate resolution 3 of the resolutions agreed to by the Senate on 25 February 1988. Part (a) states:

The principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for Senators against improper acts tending substantially—
and I stress substantially—
to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate;
Part (b) states:
The existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt;
In other words, is there another remedy available to the Senate? Finally, part (c) states:
Whether a person who committed any act which may be held to be a contempt:
(i) knowingly committed that act, or
(ii) had any reasonable excuse for the commission of that act.
Those are the three criteria that we are guided by when we look at this matter.

Let us look at the criteria contained in part (a). The proponents for this motion have to show that the claimed conduct tended to substantially obstruct senators in the performance of their functions or the Senate in its functions. There has been no obstruction whatsoever; no attempt at obstruction, let alone a substantial obstruction. We have to decide whether there has been a substantial obstruction.

Let us look at the facts. The facts are that the Joint Statutory Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund invited the Law Reform Commission to provide it with a submission in relation to its current reference. The Attorney-General wrote to the President of the ALRC and drew his attention to a very legitimate concern about the desirability of the commission working within its charter which was given to it by this parliament. That is where we have to look at the duty imposed upon the Attorney-General.

The ALRC comes under the direction and control of the Attorney-General. That is provided for by the administrative arrangements order. It is also provided for, by implication, in section 20 of the Australian Law Reform Commission Act 1996, which provides that the Attorney-General refers matters to the Australian Law Reform Commission. The Australian Law Reform Commission must act according to law; it must act within its powers. If it did not, it would bring the Law Reform Commission into disrepute. What the Attorney-General was doing was exercising his duty in pointing out to the Australian Law Reform Commission its powers and its limitations on its powers.

At the estimates committee, the Australian Law Reform Commission comes before a Senate committee. It is the representative of the Attorney-General who sits before that committee and answers questions on behalf of the Australian Law Reform Commission. That Law Reform Commission is accountable to the people of Australia and to this parliament, and so it should be. It is a creature of parliament and it is accountable. It is governed by an act of parliament, and it comes under the responsibility of the Attorney-General.

When Senator Bolkus says that a lawful direction can still constitute a contempt, he fails to recognise the relationship between the Attorney-General and the Australian Law Reform Commission. Indeed, I believe this full aspect was not put before the Clerk of the Senate when the supplementary evidence was obtained. The opposition would say that you can sack an employee and that can still constitute a contempt, albeit that it is a lawful act.

What the opposition fails to realise is that the Attorney-General had a duty to make sure that the Law Reform Commission was acting within its powers. If he did not do that, the opposition would be on him like a shot. It would be raised at the estimates committee. The question would be, `Mr Attorney, why weren't you making sure that the Law Reform Commission was acting within its powers?' Under the Audit Act, the Attorney‐General has a responsibility to make sure that the Law Reform Commission does not waste people's money. It cannot go engaging in a frolic of its own expending taxpayers' money without proper power or a proper statutory base.

In the letter that the Attorney-General wrote to the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission on 28 August and which has been tabled in this parliament—so there is no cover-up about the communication; from day one the Attorney-General tabled this letter—he simply pointed this out to him. The Attorney‐General finished by stating:
I should therefore be grateful if you would ensure that you undertake consultation with me should such occasions arise again in the future.

There is no threat in this letter. There is not even a scintilla of a threat in this letter. The Attorney-General's actions were more than reasonable. Mr Reaburn, who is a Commonwealth officer and who has to carry out the laws of the Commonwealth, was doing no more, no less than his duty in talking to the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission.

There is no evidence whatsoever that Mr Reaburn induced, threatened or attempted to do any of those things in relation to the evidence or any submission which was to be given by the Australian Law Reform Commission. In fact, the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission has corroborated the fact that he did not feel threatened by the communications to him, and that was in relation to the communications of either Mr Reaburn or the Attorney-General. So there is not a scintilla of evidence in relation to any threat whatsoever. The Attorney-General was acting lawfully.

The question of what are improper means to influence a witness is an issue which has been considered by the courts on a number of occasions. I bring to the attention of the Senate the case of Meissner v. the Queen 1995, 130 Australian Law Reports, page 547, where it is stated:

Argument or advice that merely seeks to persuade the accused to plead guilty is not improper conduct for this purpose, no matter how strongly the argument or advice is put. Reasoned argument or advice does not involve the use of improper means and does not have the tendency to prevent the accused from making a free and voluntary choice concerning his or her plea to the charge. As long as the argument or advice does not constitute harassment or other improper pressure and leaves the accused free to make the choice, no interference with the administration of justice occurs.
What we have here was the Attorney-General and Mr Reaburn advising the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission of his duty, of his powers, of what the law was—nothing more, nothing less.

Let us turn now to the other criterion that the Senate must consider when it considers whether to refer this to the Privileges Committee, and that is whether any other remedy exists in relation to the act which is alleged to be contemptuous. The native title bill has been referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. That is a Senate committee with much power and it will have the chance to go over all the legal questions in relation to that bill. It will have the opportunity and power to go into the very aspect that was asked of the Australian Law Reform Commission. This chamber is another remedy. For the last two days this matter has been ventilated thoroughly before the people of Australia. So we have two alternative remedies where this matter has been canvassed and ventilated. It does not need further ventilation before the Privileges Committee. That would be a waste of the time of a Senate committee. We have here a political exercise which is trying to disguise itself as something which is judicious.

The next criterion we have to look at is whether a person who committed the act did so knowingly or whether they had any reasonable excuse for the act, so that the person who is alleged to have committed this act did so with some sort of intent. The Committee of Privileges has said the following on a number of occasions—I quote from the 42nd report, May 1993:
Only in the most exceptional circumstances should it—
the committee—

contemplate make being a finding of contempt in the absence of any intention on the part of a person or persons to commit any act which may be held to be in contempt. As a general principle, the committee accepts that the damage to the Senate and its committees resulting from such acts would need to be of the most serious kind in order for the committee to find that a contempt had been committed in the absence of intent.

For a start, the opposition just does not get off the ground in relation to intent or knowingly committing any act which could be held to be in contempt. There is absolutely no evidence, and none made out by the opposition, that there was any intent of any sort. There is no guilty mind whatsoever—in fact, quite the opposite. You have two people exercising their duty under the law of this Commonwealth.

As for any excuse, if you do not have any intent and you do not get past that first arm of this criterion or charge, then you do not even have to get to any reasonable excuse. In any event, the Attorney-general and Mr Reaburn were just doing their duty. That produces the simple finding of no case to answer. When we look at this matter, the Senate has to confine itself to that criterion. As I have indicated, there is absolutely no evidence of any transgression.

So what happens if the Senate comes to the conclusion that there is no case to answer—not a shred of evidence that would support any of these aspects that we have to look at? The Senate then is duty bound not to refer this matter to the Committee of Privileges because the Committee of Privileges is doing work on behalf of the Senate. It is not there to consider matters which do not constitute a prima facie case, which are impossible ever to be found to have constituted some sort of substantial obstruction to the Senate. It is not there for frivolous or vexatious references.

It would be an abuse of the system, and the Senate committee system in particular, if this were referred, because there is no case made out. It would be taking up unnecessarily that Senate committee's time. It would be turning something which is heavy and weighty and of great importance into a simple political stunt. If the opposition is serious about all this, if it is serious about the Committee of Privileges, if it is serious about the Senate committee system, it will not burden that system with something which is simply not worthy of reference.

This has been a very tawdry attempt by the opposition to try to besmirch the Attorney-General, who was simply carrying out his duty. If he had not carried out his duty, the opposition would be the first to jump up and down at the Senate estimates committee. The subject matter of the submission will be dealt with by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. The questions of constitutionality will receive full consideration.

This bill, the native title bill, is already before a joint committee. There is no question of this bill not receiving adequate scrutiny. In fact, I doubt whether any other bill will receive the scrutiny that this amendment bill will receive.

What we have is no interference with any due consideration of any piece of legislation. What we have is an exercise of duty on the part of the Attorney-General in pointing out to the Australian Law Reform Commission its powers. What we have is the Attorney-General carrying out his responsibility under the administrative orders of this country. What we have is the Attorney-General ensuring that, under the Audit Act, unnecessary expenditure of taxpayers' money is not engaged in. Further, what we have here is the situation where an officer from the Attorney-General's Department was doing all those things as well as the Attorney-General.

There has been no cover-up, no cover‐up at all. The Attorney-General has tabled his letter of communication. He has answered in full the questions that have been put to him. In fact, Mr Reaburn has made full disclosure. Their version of events has been corroborated by the President of the Australian Law Reform Commission.

What we have before us is uncontested evidence; and, on that uncontested evidence, there simply is not a case to be made out. There has been no substantial obstruction. There has not even been a scintilla of obstruction; in fact, the reverse. We have had people carrying out their duty. At one end of the scale, you have criticism of an Attorney-General who is trying to do his job; at the other end of the scale, you have due process in relation to the native title bill which is it is being scrutinised by no less than two committees and will have full attention given to it in relation to questions of law and constitutionality.

The Australian Law Reform Commission is governed by its act, no more, no less. It has to deal with references given to it by the Attorney-General, and it should act within that, no more, no less. That is what the people of this country expect of that Law Reform Commission—not to go on frolics of its own.

I might point out that there was another aspect which the Attorney‐General raised with the Law Reform Commission, and that was in relation to copyright. It was not just the native title bill; it was in relation to copyright as well. He believed there that the Law Reform Commission again had exceeded the terms of sections 20 and 21 of its act. He was not just confining it to the native title bill.

There has been no attempt to single out the Australian Law Reform Commission because of some submission that the Attorney-General did not like. In fact, it was asked to make a submission to the Wik task force. Its views were asked for by the Commonwealth government in relation to the drafting of that bill. It has been employed by the government, properly so, and that is how it should be employed. But it should not be improperly employed, and that is where it embarks on aspects which are beyond its powers under the act.

On all points, the people of Australia will be well served. They will not be well served or better served by this reference going to the Privileges Committee. In fact, they will be badly served, because this will be an unworthy reference to a very good committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ellison made reference to `trivial issues unworthy of the Senate'. If the Senate chooses to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee, it is so that that committee can determine whether there are recommendations to be made. The fact that the reference has been made, the fact that it is being debated here, indicates that a number of people do not believe that these matters are trivial; they believe they ought to be considered.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to look at this issue in context. We have had a number of debates in relation to the Attorney-General, as to whether or not, as the chief law officer of the land, he should be seen to be above politics, in politics, out of politics or totally separate from politics—and, quite clearly, it is not the case. We know that in the case of the Environmental Defender's Office there were very distinct messages going to their offices, saying that the government was unhappy, the minister was unhappy—and, of course, in reality, the cabinet were unhappy—with decisions to take cases against the government, or to try to defend the environment. The reality is that most of the cases which ended up having to be defended were, in the end, cases about whether or not the government played the role that they were meant to play under their own legislation.

Let us look at that case. What happened? The Environmental Defender's offices, which had not long been established in some states—longer in New South Wales—did not choose to pull their heads in because of those notes. What happened? They got their funding cut. As to the funding, basically it was said, `If you take any cases at all, any litigation'—because it would have been too obvious to say `any litigation against the Commonwealth or the states'—`then you will get your funding cut.' We have the Environmental Defender's Office unable to take litigation at all. We have a group of lawyers who are hobbled because they were doing their job, because they were trying to defend the environment.

If we did not have that and other examples before us, we probably would be less likely to be in this position of being deeply concerned about whether a commission, which is meant to have some level of independence, was being told what it could or could not say, both to the community and to the parliamentary process. Is the commission required to ask permission of the minister for every statement they put out? Is the commission required to ask permission? Is it written in their orders that they have to ask permission and get everything okayed by the minister? I do not believe that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Open government.

—That is right. Within a relatively short time, this government has become contemptuous of the need to have independent commissions, of the need to separate executive power from the parliament and its bodies. That is a very, very important issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also had the debate about the ongoing influence on parliamentary committees. We need to have further debate about placing departmental officers on parliamentary committees. And that, in my opinion, will mean that the executive, once again, has more and more undue influence on the outcome of parliamentary committees. We have a very dodgy line here in relation to the separation of powers, and it is getting worse.

I do not think this is a trivial issue. If there needs to be clarification, this can be sought during the Privileges Committee inquiry and I am sure there will be a number of legal opinions given in relation to the limitations or otherwise of the powers of the Australian Law Reform Commission. That will probably be a useful thing and I am sure there will be differences of opinion. I am sure the government may roll out its own appropriate or convenient opinion or its own legal assistance in that sense, but it is important to have that brought out in the committee.

If clarification needs to be sought, this is the appropriate way to do that. I do think it is wrong to call these issues trivial or unworthy of the Senate. It should not be the case that we can have a situation where committees of parliament are hindered from taking action. In fact, this committee ended up being hindered because of course the government used its votes in the committee to refuse to require the attendance of the Legal Aid Commission. We had two sides to it. We had the minister acting in the way he did and also the government using its numbers on the committee to vote against requiring the Legal Aid Commission to attend and provide evidence.

BREAK.PARA: I personally would like to avoid the kind of situation which I experienced during the hearing on legal aid in Western Australia. The Western Australian minister attended the hearing and, because he was tired, answered a direct question from me as to why the Western Australian Legal Aid Commission was not able to attend the meeting. He clearly said that it was because he told them that they were not allowed to. The embarrassment and the outrage within the media and the community was such that within a very short time the Legal Aid Commission was permitted to come and give evidence.

I do not want to see that happening in the federal parliament. I do not want to see that kind of influence or bullying by ministers. If there is any indication that there is a concern that this might be happening, or anything like that might be happening, then we must deal with it. We must be clear about what we are dealing with and we must be clear about where the rights of the parliament exist and where the line might be between executive influence and the democratic process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the situation, in the last 12 or 18 months the ALRC has made around 20 submissions to parliamentary committees. It does appear to me from a political standpoint that it is rather odd that the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) should have taken this step when he did. He had not objected to any of other submissions going before the committee, but on this one and the copyright one he apparently did.

SPEECH.PARA: ALRC reports or submissions are not holy writ and in fact some of them have sunk without trace. It seems to me that this would be just another submission which might have been useful to look at, and obviously it will be useful to have a look at it on a matter of some significance. The ALRC is a creature of statute. I am not in a position to decide whether, under the interpretation of those functions, this would have been justified. I am not in a position the make that judgment at this point of time.

At the meeting the other night of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund I was given copies of the ALRC's letters to the secretariat. It did appear on the face of it from those documents—and Senator Ellison may be able to correct me if I am wrong—that the committee must have asked the ALRC whether they would be interested in providing a submission. That is what it seems to me from the correspondence.

I have listened to what honourable senators have said and the minister, Senator Ellison, has done a very valiant job. He did refer to the resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988. Part 3 of that resolution says:

The Senate declares that it will take into account the following criteria when determining whether matters possibly involving contempt should be referred to the Committee of Privileges and whether a contempt has been committed, and requires the Committee of Privileges to take these criteria into account when inquiring into any matter referred to it:. . .

Clearly, we have an obligation here to give consideration to (a), (b) and (c), as has been expressed by Senator Ellison. But the statement by the President indicates that it was not her role at the stage that she made the statement to make any judgment as to the facts of the matter. She went on to say:

Since these provisions were adopted, Presidents have followed the principle that a matter should be given precedence if it is capable of being held by the Senate to satisfy criterion (a) and if there is no other readily available remedy.
We have gone over criterion (a) and it does seem to me that, on the face of it, this matter is capable of being held by the Senate to satisfy criterion (a).

A number of matters have been raised in the debate today about whether or not the ALRC has exceeded its powers. If it were the case that the ALRC has acted improperly, in a narrow sense of that term, then the question arises whether an improper act—again, I use the word very narrowly—and the prevention of an improper act can be regarded as contempt. I suppose that is a matter that will have to be thoroughly considered by the Privileges Committee.

I do not want to canvass all of the other matters that have been raised during this debate—such as whether the person who committed an act which may be held to be in contempt knowingly committed that act or had any reasonable excuse for commission of that act. These are matters which, it seems to me, are more appropriately dealt with by the Privileges Committee. I am quite convinced that this is a matter that is proper to go before the Privileges Committee because it does go to the protection of the processes of this parliament, which are essential for us to carry out our responsibilities on behalf of the electors.

I make absolutely no judgment as to the propriety or otherwise of the Attorney-General. I would only say, as the President has done, that if this is a matter that is capable of being held by the Senate to satisfy criterion (a), then it should be given precedence—as it has been given precedence. In my view, the matters deserve to be considered by the Privileges Committee, and that is how I will vote.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Messages from the House of Representatives were reported agreeing to the amendments made by the Senate to the following bills:

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it has agreed to amendment No. 1 made by the Senate and has disagreed to amendment No. 2.
Schedule of the amendment to which the House of Representatives has disagreed.
(2) Clause 37, page 23 (after line 17), after subclause (2), insert:

(2A) The Attorney‐General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor‐General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: House of Representatives reasons for disagreeing to amendment No. 2—

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senate Amendment Number 2

The amendment proposes clause 37, page 23 after subclause (2) be supplemented to include that the Attorney‐General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Auditor‐General by a House of the Parliament, a committee of a House of the Parliament or a joint committee of both Houses of the Parliament. The House of Representatives does not accept the amendment for two reasons.

First, it is the proper role of the elected Executive to bear responsibility for preventing damage to the public interest—and it is the Executive which will be held accountable by the Parliament and, ultimately, the electorate for its performance in that regard. Secondly, the framework of clause 37, as amended by the Senate, would provide scope for the Auditor‐General to be drawn in as an unwitting party to the, often, political issues that Members and Senators may wish to pursue.

Clause 37 replicates a framework that has been in operation in the Audit Act 1901 for almost 20 years. The scope for intervention by the Attorney‐General to prevent disclosure of particular kinds of information on public interest grounds is not extensive. The reasons listed in Clause 37(2) for the Attorney‐General to issue a certificate relate only to matters of genuine importance and significance. If one were to imagine a worst case scenario that could occur under the Senate amendment, it is possible to see how damage could be caused to Australia's national or international security and how the integrity of the Commonwealth's position could be undermined in ways that caused genuine damage to Australia. Accordingly, the House of Representatives believes that it in not worth the risk to accept the Senate amendment.

The House of Representatives believes that the framework in Clause 37, unamended, has been proven to operate in a realistic and sensible way, having been used only once, for reasons of national security. Moreover, Clause 37, as drafted, provides an added measure of accountability on the Executive in that it compels the Auditor‐General to report any intervention by the Executive and the reasons for it. The House of Representatives believes that the framework provided for in clause 37 is sound and therefore disagrees with the Senate amendment.
