SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table explanatory memorandum relating to the bill and a document relating to international requirements for interception and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

The Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 applies new arrangements to procedures for establishing an interception capability for telecommunications services in Australia, and the funding of this interception capability. The bill also deals with minor technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1997, including aspects of industry development plans, labelling of equipment and ACA industry reports.
I will deal firstly with the interception aspects of the bill.

Under Part 15 of the Telecommunications Act 1997, which largely carries forward the arrangements under the Telecommunications Act 1991, telecommunications carriers and nominated carriage service providers must ensure they can execute an interception warrant. The only exception to this is when the Minister for Communications and the Arts grants an authorisation. Carriers have also been required to consult with agencies on new technologies before introducing a telecommunications service. Agencies have borne all the costs associated with developing those interception capabilities required to be able to execute an interception warrant, and the costs of executing individual warrants.

However, the existing arrangements for interception capabilities are no longer suitable. The introduction of some new telecommunications services have been significantly delayed with obvious adverse consequences for business and consumers. On occasion services have also been introduced without an adequate interception capability, impacting adversely upon the operations of law enforcement and national security agencies. The funding of all interception requirements by the agencies, with no industry assistance on the establishment and maintenance of this essential service, has been a large and continuing drain upon the agencies' resources.

These problems will not go away under the current framework. One of the effects of the opening of the telecommunications market to full competition will be to increase the difficulties, and expense, faced by the agencies in attempting to negotiate interception capability arrangements with each and every new entrant. Add to this the escalating speed of technological change in telecommunications and the obvious outcome is increasing delays to the entrance of new market participants, and to new services, with implications for the growth and development of the Australian telecommunications market.

The best long term hope for retaining a cost effective interception capability into the longer run is through international co‐operation directed at getting telecommunications equipment vendors (especially manufacturers of switches) to include common interception capabilities into their equipment. This will ensure that capabilities are maintained, while keeping costs down by sharing them among all user countries and achieving economies of scale.

The bill therefore provides for a new level of interception capability based upon the relevant international standard or guideline. The Attorney‐General will be given the power to determine, via one or more disallowable instruments, the specifics of the new capability. The Attorney‐General will base this new capability requirement on the International User Requirement (IUR) developed by most OECD law enforcement and national security agencies (including Australia) under the auspices of the International Law Enforcement Telecommunications Seminar (ILETS). I have tabled a copy of the IUR with the bill, for Senators information.

However, to ensure there is no lapse in the requirement for an interception capability, carriers and carriage service providers will be required to be in a position to execute an interception warrant issued under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 until the Attorney‐General has made his determination, that is the `fallback' position will be a continuation of the current capability obligations.

Law enforcement and national security agencies will be able to authorise the operation of a service with a lower (or no) level of interception capability. This is reasonable given that these agencies are the users of the capability, and are in the best position to determine when it is no longer required. The Minister will continue to have a reserve power, exercisable with the agreement of the Attorney‐General, to also grant authorisations. The Australian Communications Authority (ACA) is to be being given a limited power to provide exemptions for trial services after appropriate consultations.

The bill continues the current requirement for carriers and nominated carriage service providers to notify the ACA of relevant changes to technology, with the ACA ensuring relevant agencies are consulted. In order to make sure that the introduction of new telecommunications services is not unduly delayed, the ACA is now required to specify reasonable timeframes with which agencies can consider new technologies for each new technology notification. If agencies do not comment within this reasonable period they lose their ability to specify particular delivery requirements.

The bill also introduces new funding arrangements for interception. Agencies will continue to be liable for the costs of executing individual interception warrants, as well as most other matters of `help' that are in addition to the basic listening and recording of a communication. They will also be liable for the costs of establishing capabilities they have specifically requested. The ACA has been given new audit powers to ensure that the most cost effective solutions are adopted. However carriers will now be required to pay for the costs of providing the interception capability determined by the Attorney‐General, or the costs of the `fallback' capability.

In regard to allocating the transmission costs of an intercepted communication, a new concept of the `delivery point' has been introduced in Part 14. Individual carriers and carriage service providers, and the agencies, will be required to agree to the location of the `delivery point', with the carrier or carriage service provider paying for the costs of transmitting the intercepted information to the delivery point, and the agencies paying for the transmission costs from the delivery point to the final destination.

Another new concept, the interception capability plan, is also introduced with this bill. These plans are intended to provide a strategic communications and planning tool for the industry and agencies. Carriers and carriage service providers nominated by the Attorney‐General will be required to submit these plans on an annual basis, and their content will include the policies of the carrier or provider in relation to interception generally; of their strategies for compliance with their interception obligations; a statement of any relevant business developments; and a description of strategies for minimising long run costs.

The bill therefore introduces a new framework for the accomplishment of a cost effective and relevant interception capability within Australia. However, we recognise that technologies, the communications market, and the needs of agencies are continuing to evolve rapidly. While telecommunications interception remains for the present a cost effective tool for agencies, it is important that we keep our approach to this issue under review. The bill therefore requires the Minister, in consultation with the Attorney‐General, to cause a review to be conducted before 1 July 1999 into the longer‐term cost effectiveness of the arrangements provided for in Parts 14 and 15 of the act that relate to the funding of telecommunications interception. A copy of the report from this review is to be laid before each House of the Parliament.
There are also several other matters in the bill which I will now discuss.

The bill provides for the labelling requirements for customer equipment and customer cabling under Division 7 of Part 21 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 to apply not only to manufacturers or importers of this equipment or cabling but also to authorised agents acting in Australia on behalf of such manufacturers or importers.

This will allow overseas manufacturers and importers to revert back to established agency arrangements whereby their Australian agents take responsibility for ensuring that the requirements for labelling telecommunications customer equipment and customer cabling are met. This will ensure the supply of equipment and cabling to Australia and facilitate the introduction and growth of competition in the supply of goods and services in the Australian telecommunications market.

In addition, the ACA is currently required to monitor and report each financial year to the Minister on all significant matters relating to the performance of carriers and carriage service providers. The bill builds in additional flexibility by giving the Minister the power to direct the ACA in relation to the preparation of periodic reports as well as special reports on particular matters that may arise during the year.

Technical amendments are also proposed to Clause 27 of Schedule 3 to the act dealing with the carriers' powers and immunities. This clause sets out the matters that the ACA must be satisfied about before it may issue a facility installation permit. It also sets out the things that the ACA must take into account in deciding whether the grounds for a permit have been made out.

Clause 27, as currently drafted, requires that before a facility installation permit can be issued for telecommunications installations other than designated overhead lines, the ACA must be satisfied that both the landowner and the relevant local authority have not consented to the installation. This has the peculiar and unintended consequence that a consent by either a landowner or relevant authority will prevent the ACA from issuing a facility installation permit. The bill amends clause 27 to address this anomaly.

The re‐draft makes it clear that the ACA can issue a facility installation permit for non‐designated overhead lines infrastructure where either the landowner or the relevant authority refuse or withhold consent.

The bill contains minor amendments to Part 2 of Schedule 1 which covers industry development plan arrangements. The amendments correct shortcomings in the legislation relating to when industry development plans are required and when the approval of the Industry Minister is necessary, as well as clarifying the notification of Government policies which carriers must have regard to in preparing their industry development plans.

The first amendment will require all carriers to have a current industry development plan at all times, rather than only when applying for a carrier licence, as currently provided in the act. The second amendment will see amended industry development plans requiring approval of the Industry Minister, treating them in a similar manner to original plans. The third amendment will require the Industry Minister to notify carriers and applicants for carrier licences of government policies he wishes them to take into account in preparing their plans.

The bill also makes a number of other minor and technical amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1997, the Telecommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act 1997 and the Trade Practices Act 1974.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first sitting day in 1998, in accordance with standing order 111. (Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 1 October.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 and amendments 3 and 6 moved by Senator Murray for the Australian Democrats. The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —When we were in the midst of debate yesterday, Senator Cook, on behalf of Labor, made some remarks about clauses 3 and 6. I recognise that Senator Cook had to come into the debate a little late and may not have picked up the important point about these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook, I ask you to reconsider the remarks you made yesterday, because I think you may have made them with insufficient information. The actual effect of my amendments is to add to the framework for the development of government fiscal policy and to add to the issues which the Treasurer (Mr Costello) must assess in the development of long‐term sustainable fiscal strategies.

The amendments have nothing to do with the short‐term costing of election commitments and the restrictive time requirements under that part. I think you were properly and rightly concerned that, in the hurly burly—I think those were the words you used—of election momentum it would be impossible to take up those future generational issues. We would concur. It might be exceptionally difficult to do that in the broader framework.

BREAK.PARA: But this Charter of Budget Honesty Bill does not refer just to the election, as you know. It refers to the entire process of government—the presentation of budgets, fiscal strategies and so on. It is to those long‐term considerations—the intergenerational considerations—that these amendments are directed. I raise those points with you in the hope that they will influence you—as new information—to reconsider the position you took yesterday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I never expected to be in this position this morning. Since it is not normal for me to carry this bill, I thought that I would very likely not be carrying it today. However, a few moments ago—
—Why are you here, then?

—I was advised that I am carrying it today, and just a few seconds ago I got the documents in front of me, so I am not in the fully prepared briefed‐up state on this matter that I normally would be. However, going from my recollection of the debate when we closed it down yesterday, my concerns at that point were that, firstly, if this amendment were carried, the Department of the Treasury would be required to provide costings of the social impact of economic policies and provide costings or comments on the ecological sustainability of measures put down by the major parties in an election context.

SPEECH.PARA: My concerns were, firstly, that those issues are complex and detailed and in many respects call up subjective judgments. Secondly, does Treasury have the equipment and firepower to handle it? I think not. Thirdly, there is contention about the subjective nature of some of these issues. Do we start from a clear definitional base so that we all agree what it is we are looking at? It is essential that we agree on what the implications might be in order to cost them and, if we are working from different premises, it complicates debate; it does not enlighten it. As much as I have reservations about this bill, its purpose is to try and enlighten debate and make it easier for electors to assess the policies of major parties at election time.

BREAK.PARA: The fourth concern I had yesterday, as I recall, was that, given the subjective nature of some of these matters, if in an election campaign a major party—and it would most likely be mine—disagreed with what the federal bureaucracy thought were the implications of some of its policies, then in an election context you have got a political party arguing with the bureaucracy over a question of credibility. That exposes us to issues of whom you believe: do you believe the bureaucrats or the politicians? That is a terrible bind. I think most people will believe us, because we are entirely credible, but I would not want to be in a position where they have to make the choice.

They were the concerns that I had about this amendment. What I apprehend you have just put to me is that this is not to be seen as in an election context; this is to be seen as a longer term thing. I would like to hear the government's view on this amendment. That will enable me to look at Senator Murray's most recent remarks and come to a conclusion about those. At the moment, as I said, I have just recapped my arguments from yesterday. I just need a little more time in order to come to a conclusion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —In order to assist Senator Cook, may I suggest that he read his speech from yesterday. It is on page 7133 of the Senate Hansard . Basically, it was a pretty good speech, Senator. I thought you summed up the position particularly well. If we had had three more minutes, I think the vote would have been taken. I think what we are trying to do in this is to focus on the issues of sound fiscal management. I do not say that the other issues which have been brought into this matter are unimportant, but they are not matters which deal directly with the issue which is before the chamber, which is trying to establish sound principles of fiscal management. The other matters which have been raised are important, and clearly they will be matters of concern to people, but they are not matters which I believe should be considered in the context of this particular bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook did make some useful points in relation to the role of the Treasury in producing this particular document, and he focused on the particular skills which Treasury can bring to such a document. I was going to speak on this matter yesterday, if there had been time, and was not going to say all that much because I thought that Senator Cook had expressed the position pretty well. I am surprised that he could not remember what he said yesterday because it was still ringing in my ears. When this came back on for debate, I asked my advisers to pass me the speech that Senator Cook made yesterday because I thought it was a pretty good summing up of the issue.

Just to encapsulate it, the issues which have been raised, the social effects and the ecological sustainability issues, are very important; no‐one doubts that. They are issues which will always be taken into account in public debate as we look towards the long term. But this is a document produced by the Treasury which deals with the issues of fiscal sustainability. That is the focus of the bill and that is what we are trying to achieve. I think that to widen it in this way, as Senator Cook said so well and so eloquently, is suggesting that Treasury will be bringing in particular skills and issues which are far wider than is appropriate for such a document. So we will not be supporting this measure. The issue of whether or not it is in the election context is another issue, but the fact of the matter is that the general principles that Senator Cook laid out yesterday were sensible. We will not be supporting this measure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook, if I may also assist you, in part of your remarks yesterday you said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the reasons why I would oppose this is that it is in the cut and thrust of the last days of an election campaign when these reports are coming down.

You will find around this chamber people who think this is a strange statement, but budgets are, in my belief, about politics and public policy. They are about how you direct your decisions and so economics is a part of the tool that you should be using but budgets should not be simply the realm of economics. All the decisions on revenue, tax and spending are about policy and politics. They are not about decisions about economics; they are about decisions about politics and how you make and direct your choices.

SPEECH.PARA: Only in relatively recent times have we actually tried to separate economics from politics. I am reminded of a story of about three years ago when I had a parliamentary intern who interviewed a staffer of a Liberal politician on an issue. He was a bit perplexed when he saw that she had done political economy as one of the courses in her law degree. He said, `What has politics got to do with economics?' She was perplexed, as I was, and quite amused, because originally economics was called political economy. Adam Smith called it political economy in recognition of the fact that it is about the choices you make as to how you make a living and how you provide the goods and services and physical needs—and sometimes other needs—of people in the community.

The politics and the policy have been artificially separated to the bizarre extent where we find that we are in fact being dictated by speculative markets way out of our purview telling us what we should be doing and how we should be doing it, and being punished by what is happening to our dollar. SPEECH.PARA: These amendments to the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 address the issues of mandatory matters that must be contained within the budget, economic and fiscal outlook reports. What we are seeking in these amendments is to insert into the bill a requirement that some important additional information be provided in the reports. Specifically, the opposition considers that the government must provide national savings forecasts and an estimate of the net effect on savings of the budget as part of the group of obligations created by clause 12 of schedule 1 of this bill.

The major topic of economic policy debate which has dominated this parliament since the election of the Howard government is that of national savings and the priority the government should be placing on national savings. These amendments seek to ensure that the appropriate emphasis is placed on national savings and its impact by stipulating in this bill that the government must provide separate estimates of the net effect of future budgets on the national savings—both public and private savings.

It seems somewhat odd that this government, which has embarked upon a slash and burn approach to public expenditure in the name of improving public sector savings, has actually excluded this very important item from its reporting requirements. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has put the issue of improved national savings at the forefront of public debate since March 1996. However, his practice is not to tell the public what his budgets will actually do for national savings. We suspect that the reason for this is that he knows he is following the wrong policy mix and that the government will be embarrassed by the poor national savings outcome that this policy mix will create.

We in the opposition have maintained for a long time that an appropriate budget strategy would be one that placed more emphasis on growth and employment with resultant benefits flowing through to national savings by having more people working, saving and paying tax. The government has chosen a different path and in the process flattened the economy, including both consumer and business confidence, which has a resultant negative impact on national savings.

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, clause 12, page 11 (after line 25), after paragraph (da), insert:

TAB.TAB: (db) a report prepared by the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury of any material threats to the integrity of the tax system including the fiscal impact of these threats, and their best professional judgment of the specific means necessary to counter these threats;

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important amendment. One can hope that this would have the unanimous support of members of the Senate. The integrity of the tax base is fundamental to the delivery of adequate public services. Taxes are necessary to finance public services, and these are most fairly raised when everyone so able contributes to them. Ensuring the integrity of the tax base is, therefore, crucial to ensuring that all taxpayers are paying their fair share of taxation. Amendment No. 4 proposes to require the Commissioner of Taxation and the Secretary to the Treasury to provide a report on any material threats to the integrity of the tax system, including the fiscal impact of any of these threats as a permanent and integral part of fiscal reporting.

This is a very important proposal because it will allow the government, and especially the Treasurer, to be held accountable for the conduct of tax policy. The opposition believes that there can be few duties of higher importance to the Treasurer than to maintain a fair tax system in Australia. Critical to that is that the current tax base be maintained. We are concerned to ensure that the revenue authorities' concerns are made public to enable scrutiny of the Treasurer's performance in his duty to protect the public revenue. The tax commissioner can advise the Treasurer on matters that should be undertaken to maintain the tax base but he has no power to force the Treasurer to act in the national interest. The discretion is all with the Treasurer to either accept or reject the advice of the tax office and the Treasury.

This amendment does not seek to alter the Treasurer's right to make tax policy on behalf of the government, but we do seek to ensure that the material threats to the taxation system are codified on a systematic public basis as to enable the performance of the Treasurer in dealing with these revenue threats to be openly evaluated. Future Treasurers will still be able to refuse to act on the advice of the revenue authorities, but they will not be able to hide their actions or lack of action from the Australian people.

Clause 12 of schedule 1 as currently worded only includes some references to the sorts of risks that may have a material effect on the fiscal outlook, but there is no explicit reference to particular threats proposed to fiscal outcomes due to the integrity of the tax system coming under substantial attack. What we do know, though, is that the tax system and the threat to its integrity is under constant and sustained attack. In some instances this is as a direct result of government legislation opening up loopholes. In other cases it arises through a lack of action on tax avoidance through allowing such things as salary repackaging by its senior public servants. As we believe that risks to the integrity of the tax system will always exist, the opposition is convinced that one way of ensuring that these risks are brought to the attention of the public is by ensuring that the government itself makes its own estimate, which is to be published accompanied by a statement as to where it perceives these threats are coming from.

As we know, there are many areas of avoidance activity that are currently going on, the biggest areas seemingly being the alienation of personal services income and complex trust arrangements by high wealth individuals which this government plans to do nothing about. The opposition believes that these threats to the tax system are so great in themselves and quite readily distinguishable from other kinds of risks such as contingent liabilities that they ought to be the subject of a specific obligation. This amendment establishes that obligation. The opposition seeks the support of the Senate to insert this very important requirement into the bill. A vote against this amendment is a vote against ordinary taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting the government on this motion. We will do so because, firstly, we think that this is a major and important piece of legislation that has waited a long time. The quicker it goes into action, the better. That is our first point.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that the issue under debate is a collision of two quite important principles. The principle of national interest and the principle of the right of the parliament to know. Where the borderline is drawn between those two principles is always a hard question and it depends on the particular issue of the moment. It is not one that you can conceptually easily draw.

I should note that Senator Sherry, who normally speaks in this spot, has indicated how sympathetic he would be to the formation of an Auditor-General's committee of the parliament. If one were formed, these sorts of issues can be canvassed at some length and some greater clarity found about them. But at the present moment we think there is a need to get this bill into law and we will not be supporting this amendment.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Could I ask that the clerk record the votes of those who said `no' on the voices?

TALK.START.PARA: —Knowing that the opposition has indicated that it would not insist on the amendment as put by Senator Murray, I have circulated a lesser amendment in the desperate hope that we will have some parliamentary scrutiny on the issue of certificates. I move:

(1) Clause 37, page 23 (after line 17), after subclause (2), insert:

I think that is reasonable. It is certainly less than many of us would have liked, but I do hope that the opposition has the ability to support this amendment, which I would like to think would also be supported by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator IAN CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will not be supporting this amendment. At the outset I thank Senator Murray for not dividing on the previous motion. It does help the way in which the Senate chamber can deal with legislation if, where clearly the numbers are against, the provision to record the vote is used. It has the same effect as having a division basically, except it is seven or eight minutes shorter. But I do thank Senator Murray and the other senators who did not insist on having a division there. It is very helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: We see the same potential jeopardy in this amendment as in the one that the House of Representatives chose to reject. The fact that the House of Representatives chose to reject that amendment and we moved that the Senate not insist on that amendment shows that we believe that there is an inherent obligation on the executive of whatever political colour to prevent damage to the public interest from inappropriate public disclosure of specified categories of matters.

We believe that in this the government is responsible to the parliament and to the people, and that, if there was an improper public disclosure, then it would be the government—to put it colloquially—who would wear it. It would not do and it would not help for the Attorney-General or the government to point their fingers at a committee or a parliament and say it was their fault. From the accountability point of view, clearly the government needs to be responsible for these matters.

We think the amendment moved by Senator Margetts will, to all intents and purposes, have the same detrimental effect—cutting in between that accountability—as the amendment that the House of Representatives has rejected and this Senate has now agreed not to insist upon. I apologise for reading this advice, but I think it is important for it be read into the record. The advice puts the government's view on the legalities and constitutionality of this issue as well as the policy matters:

The amendment would be inserted as subclause (2A) and seeks to prohibit the Attorney-General from issuing a certificate that would prevent inappropriate public disclosure of the kinds of information specified in subclause (1), in circumstances where that information was requested of the Auditor-General by a House of the Parliament.

It is not certain that the amendment would constrain a House from requesting information from the Auditor-General through a Committee of that House, with the same prohibitions then still applying to the Attorney-General's powers to prevent inappropriate public disclosure.
It is noted that section 49 of the Constitution provides for the powers, privileges and immunities of the Parliament to be such as are declared by the Parliament.

Accordingly, the amendment would appear to leave it open to the Parliament, at some point, to declare that a request for information from the Auditor-General need not depend on a resolution of that House, but could be made by a Committee of that House.

The Government should oppose this amendment as it appears to have the potential to prevent the Executive from carrying out its responsibility to intervene where damage to the public interest is at risk by the inappropriate disclosure of information that the section seeks to protect.

I conclude by saying that, ultimately, the Attorney-General is responsible to the parliament for that. I think it is fair to say that the events of the last couple of days—even though not directly related to these sorts of provisions—show that, within this great democracy we call Australia, the actions of a minister and particularly the Attorney-General in this case are ultimately accountable. If this power is abused, then the Attorney‐General and the government will be accountable. If this power is not used properly, in the event that it is required to be used, again we are held accountable.

Ultimately, if there is an inappropriate public disclosure of information that would put the public interest at risk, it will be the government who wears the responsibility. We are saying that we will accept that responsibility. Future governments will accept that responsibility, just as previous governments have accepted that responsibility both under this package and also under the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act, the Privacy Act, the Freedom of Information Act, the Ombudsman Act and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will not support this amendment by the Greens (WA), although the last part of the argument put by the government is not necessarily convincing to us. SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, the demarcation between national interest and the parliament's right to know is a thorny area. We are sympathetic to the idea of there being a parliamentary committee for the Auditor-General that can look at and work through some of these things. It is for that reason that I think this issue should be examined in that way. I will not be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally, I will support this amendment. It is the third and the last backstop we have tried to preserve an absolutely fundamental matter of parliamentary power. We in my party do not believe that parliament should be the house of the executive; we believe that parliament should be the house of the people and that parliament does reign supreme.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had the debates. I will not speak at length. I will just tell the Senate that I am sick with disappointment at this turn of events because I think it is a fundamental principle. As the Parliamentary Secretary rightly said, I can assure you that we will come back to this issue at every opportunity we get. It is of fundamental importance to the institution which we hold dear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief because, clearly, the amendment will go down the drain. I commend Senator Margetts for preparing it. It is obvious from what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator Ian Campbell) has said in response that the government could see a potential problem if the requests for information came from a committee of the parliament, having regard to the provision in the constitution that the powers and immuni ties of the parliament are those that will be decided by the parliament and, until such time, the powers and immunities that are applicable to the British Houses of Parliament will be applicable here—but that has long since gone.

SPEECH.PARA: Here you have an opportunity to vote for an amendment which does restrict it to a house of parliament. I can understand that a situation could arise late at night when only a few members of the committee, not the full committee, were present and you had a request for information carried.

Senator Margetts was trying to get a balance. I think that she has got the right balance. I would have thought that perhaps even the government would have accepted that. They certainly would have accepted, I expect, an amendment which read: `The Attorney‐General must not issue a certificate in respect of information requested of the Attorney‐General by a resolution of both houses of parliament.' If they were not going to accept this, I would have thought that that they would have gone for that. It appears that we will have to revisit this matter at some later stage, as Senator Murray and Senator Cook have indicated.

TITLE.XREF: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 October, on motion by Senator Parer:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 as non‐controversial legislation. Clearly, as that title implies, the opposition will be supporting this legislation. This bill provides for amendments to four acts administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. All of the amendments are uncontroversial.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly they are: firstly, an amendment to the International Organisations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963 to allow for simultaneous entry into force of a treaty establishing an international organisation and the regulations relating to that organisation; secondly, an amendment to the Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 to provide diplomatic privileges and immunities to inspectors from the organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons and foreign country inspectors carrying out challenge inspections for such weapons in Australia, which would be an extremely unlikely event; thirdly, an amendment to the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 to give effect to Australia's obligations under the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation Treaty (NPT), those under our Safeguards Agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) and other bilateral arrangements and agreements with various countries; and, fourthly, an amendment to the Passports Act 1938 to add the concept of `recklessness' as a mental element in the offence of making a false statement in a passport application or in support of an application. As an aside, I do not want to trot out examples of recklessness, but I am sure that there are some very lurid and colourful such examples.

As I have said, the opposition does not wish to debate the majority of the instruments covered by these amendments. However, it would be neglectful of me not to pass some comment on some issues raised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) in his second reading speech introducing the bill on 25 June.

In that speech, the foreign minister made much of his government's avowed commitment to the international campaign to ban landmines. We are all aware of the total abhorrence felt by the Australian public in response to the horrific toll that landmines inflict on innocent civilians—men, women and children—all over the world. Landmines, originally designed for use against enemy troops, are increasingly being used—intentionally or otherwise—against civilian populations. Their use for random and large‐scale mining of agricultural land has also produced terrible results. The vast majority of landmines laid throughout the world have no use‐by‐date and will remain for years, until either they are painstakingly cleared or, as is more often the case, they are accidentally detonated. Each year, these awful weapons kill or maim over 30,000 people, the overwhelming majority of whom are civilian casualties, many of them children.
Labor recognised the imperative of ridding the world of these weapons. We did so in government and we do so now. As former foreign minister Gareth Evans said in February last year:
Under Labor, Australia is committed to, and will work towards, a total ban on the manufacture, stockpiling, use and transfer of antipersonnel landmines

Our support for such a ban was clearly expressed internationally at the Inhumane Weapons Convention Review Conference in Vienna in September 1995. Furthermore, we agreed in the interim—pending the achievement of total prohibition—to not produce antipersonnel landmines nor transfer landmines to any other country.

This is an issue to be treated with the utmost seriousness. It is not the place for opportunistic, empty pronouncements. On 15 April last year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) reaffirmed, on behalf of the present government, Australia's commitment to work for the objective of a global ban. Australia's commitment to this objective was made absolutely clear by the former government. There is nothing novel in the ministers' reaffirmation.

The funding for mine clearance activities announced in recent months by the Minister for Foreign Affairs is to be welcomed as a contribution to that goal, but the other elements of the government's strategy have been—at best—a public relations exercise. They do not advance honest dealing with a problem of massive and tragic proportions. Indeed, they are more likely to trivialise it.

Also on 15 April 1996, the government introduced what was described as a unilateral suspension on the operational use of antipersonnel landmines by the Australian Defence Force. This was announced as a departure from the policy of the former government. This is patently untrue, because the announcement carried a crucial qualification—the suspension would be reviewed:

In the case of substantial deterioration in our strategic circumstances in which Australia's security was under threat and the denial of an APL capability to the ADF would result in additional Australian casualties and damage to vital infrastructure.
In other words, the government's ban on the operational use of landmines will continue only until such time as their use becomes operationally necessary.

We will continue to argue that this offensive charade must be dropped in favour of a genuine demonstration of resolve. While other countries continue to use landmines, the Australian Defence Force continues to train with them. The retention of the existing stockpile against the contingency of future operational use is another matter. Public demolition of the current stockpile, with the exception of the minimal stocks required for ADF training, could be carried out in the presence of the international media and would be a tremendous boost to Australia's campaign for a global ban—a campaign which has gathered and continues to gather international support.

I acknowledge at this point the contribution to that international campaign made by Princess Diana in campaigning around the world for the discontinuance of the use of landmines as international weapons in war and for their removal. That contribution is readily recognised in all the recognition given to her up to and after her most tragic death.

The public demolition of our current stockpile before the media would be an international act by Australia which would show our support and which would, I think, attract further international support for this cause. It would be an advance on the position taken by Labor when we were in power. That is only appropriate, given the way the international debate on landmines has moved on from where it was last year. Far from taking this step, the Australian government was one of only five countries—the others being Ecuador, Japan, Poland and Spain—to support US efforts to undermine the recent signing of the Oslo treaty.
I conclude by saying that we will applaud genuine progress wholeheartedly. We will not applaud empty posturing on this issue, and it is time that posturing stopped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Cook for his contribution. We will conclude the debate on that note. I appreciate that the Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is an important bill, and the support of the opposition is valued.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997 also fills the category of the previous legislation passed in this place. It is minor, it is technical, but it does have important implications. As indicated by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in his second reading speech, this bill allows the Commonwealth to pay money to the states and territories for compensation paid by each of those jurisdictions for historically prohibited weapons, including weapons such as submachine guns, heavy machine‐guns and other similar weapons.

SPEECH.PARA: As has been noted, the payment of compo for these weapons was within the original intent of the Australian firearms buyback, and as a result the bill authorises the Attorney to pay moneys to states and territories for purposes consistent with the spirit of the resolutions of the Australian Police Ministers Council. We support the resolutions made by the council and we consequently support the enactment of this bill. Consequent with our support, we have agreed to speedy passage of this bill through the parliament.

BREAK.PARA: There are just two issues I want to raise with the Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison). I put them to him both as minister representing the Attorney and in the knowledge that there is a fair chance that when we come back here later on he may in fact be the Attorney. At the time of the Firearms Appropriation Act 1996, the commitment was made by the government that, if money was left over from the buyback, that money would be paid back to taxpayers through a reduction in the Medicare levy. Though I appreciate that the amount of compensation is yet to be finally determined, I seek a restatement from the government of a commitment to repay any such surplus via the mechanism that was previously announced.

The second inquiry I have is with respect to a report prepared either by the Attorney‐General's Department alone or in conjunction with the Australian Council of Police Ministers. Apparently that document was prepared in May of this year. It was advice to the Attorney‐General as to the degree of compliance of each state and territory within the resolutions agreed to by the Australian Council of Police Ministers. I seek the tabling of a copy of that report; either that report that was prepared in May or an up‐to‐date version thereof. I do not know whether you are in a position to do that today. If not, I would like an indication of a commitment to table that report or a commitment to ensure that the matter is addressed by the Attorney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats have supported the Australian firearms buyback, which ended this week, and we support the National Firearms Program Implementation Bill 1997, which will allow compensation to be paid for firearms which were surrendered under the scheme but which were not expressly banned by the nationwide agreement on firearms regulation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two issues, Minister, which I would be grateful if you could deal with in your response. The first is that I raised a question without notice with you on 4 September in the Senate and I followed up with a letter on 30 September. You responded fully on 2 October. I think your answer is very helpful. I would appreciate it, though, if you could perhaps deal with those issues and outline the government's intentions as you have outlined to me in your letter, which I am sure you would be content to do. Those issues, for the benefit of the Senate, concern our concern with the possibility of how any funds left over from the scheme will be used. Plainly, if there has been a levy on Medicare and there is an amount of money which is not expended on government buyback, there must be concern as to whether that money will be used for a good purpose. Accordingly, I would appreciate the minister's response on that.

The second one might be very difficult for you to answer. There seem to be somewhat extravagant claims being made in the media—I do not know the source of them—that anything up to a million illegal guns might still be out there in Australia. I do not know how anyone arrives at such a figure, nor do I know how they could imagine there would be such a figure, but I think it would be helpful to the Senate, Minister, if you would indicate whether the government has any feeling or any knowledge as to how many illegal weapons are in Australia outside of the approved and registered scheme. If you wish to take that on notice, I would be happy to have your response at some other time. We would certainly like an indication as to whether there is a major law and order issue brewing in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, in relation to the questions posed by Senator Bolkus and Senator Murray, I can answer them both with the reply that the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) stands that any surplus funds from the guns buy‐back scheme will be returned to taxpayers through the Medicare levy system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible that, if the amount of money that remains is relatively small, the community might have an expectation that it would be devoted to an appropriate measure rather than subsumed in administration on the return of a modest amount. The government will consider the options in relation to any money left over from the scheme once it becomes clear that most dealers' claims have been finalised. This will, of course, follow a thorough audit of the scheme. I think that answers the questions put by both senators.

In relation to the question put by Senator Bolkus about the report he mentioned, it will take some weeks to compile that report. I can give an undertaking that it will be tabled when it is to hand, but it will take some weeks to get that information together. With respect to the question from Senator Murray as to the number of guns that are still illegally in the community, I will take that on notice in order to do the question justice. We will have that information to you, Senator Murray, as best we can. There was a Newspoll that was conducted recently, but perhaps that is not the only authority as to how many guns there are in the community. It is a matter of vital interest to the government. This piece of legislation is technical in nature. It is providing for some anomalies that arise in these sorts of schemes. It always happens that there is something which was not accounted for. For instance, there have been cannons, sub‐machine guns and all sorts of weapons that have been returned, which I do not think were originally envisaged. This bill has to be passed in order to effect compensation for that. I thank the opposition and the Democrats for their support on this bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, can you confirm that you received advice from your department detailing concerns about William Angliss 2000 on 30 April and chose to ignore this advice? Can you confirm that you allowed your department to extend the South Pacific Cruise Lines contract on 20 August despite the fact that you had said, on the previous day in Senate estimates, that you had serious concerns about the contract? In fact, can you confirm you hopelessly dithered for a period of almost three months after initial concerns were raised in the Courier‐Mail of 11 June about the nearly $3 million payment to South Pacific Cruise Lines? Given that it took you 76 days to get your department to ask SPCL to open its books, why shouldn't the Australian public view your inaction as a gross dereliction of duty?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for a God‐given question. I just cannot believe that Senator Faulkner is so stupid as to open himself up for yet another knock on the glass jaw.

ANSWER.PARA: The question is: did I ignore some advice about William Angliss? The answer to that is no. Some advice on William Angliss was in some material provided to my office but not in connection with the contract being made with SPCL. Yesterday's hearing absolutely confirmed this just in the initial stages—we did not need to waste 10½ hours of taxpayers' time and money—with the initial statement outlined by the secretary to the department indicating that the delegations to make the contract were exercised by them—that is, officers in the department—without recourse to the minister or her office. We took 10½ hours trawling over every little bit of paper we could, looking for the name William Angliss, saying that that must mean that I knew something about SPCL and, in the end, getting nowhere.

Did I agree that the department could extend the contract with SPCL? Senator Faulkner asked this question last night and clearly he was not happy with the answer, so I should take the opportunity to explain for senators who were not there last night the proposition that Senator Faulkner was actually putting.

The proposition he was actually putting was this: once the money had been paid over and the contract had not been satisfactorily com pleted, the question, from the department's point of view, is, will we allow them more time to complete, even though we are not paying any more money? Senator Faulkner seems to think that what the department should have said is, `No, don't let them complete. We are not paying any more money anyway, but don't let them complete.'

It is a bit like the analogy I used last night at the estimates committee. If you have a contract for an extension to your house and the builder does not complete it on time, but you have paid all the money, are you serious ly going to say to the builder if he offers to complete without requiring any more money, `No, I don't want you to complete. Even though I am not giving you any more money, I still don't want you to complete'? What a ludicrous proposition that you put forward, Senator Faulkner.

You were an embarrassment to the Senate last night and your question now is an embarrassment to the people behind you; no more `Ho, ho's' today from those behind you. You got that clear as a bell last night—everyone understands about having a contract completed without paying more money—but you are such a sucker that you have to come in here and ask the question again.

Senator Faulkner went on to purport that somehow—and this is what he is desperate to show—my office or myself in some way inadequately managed this issue once we found out about it. If you were at the estimates committee last night, Madam President, what you would have found is that both I and my office first became aware of a contract between the department and SPCL, South Pacific Cruise Lines, after the contract had been made and after the money had been paid over; and that within days—and I am not using days to cover weeks and months—my office had requested a brief on that matter, had got some information from the Brisbane area office, had been assured that financial checks had been made and that no irregularities had occurred, and had asked for a subsequent and further brief from the national office.

So I do not know whether Senator Faulkner is in dreamland, incompetent, unable to understand what he was told last night or simply, yet again, wanting to misuse the time and money of this chamber to try to allege that I have not done my job in respect of this matter when he knows the SPCL contract—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, didn't you say at the estimates committee last night that `money was spent, and the mistakes were made'? Those are your words, Minister. Isn't it a fact that you were just crossing your fingers and just hoping and praying that the inevitable disaster would not happen? Minister, given your gross dereliction of duty in relation to this particular matter, would you agree with the majority of the Australian people and the majority of commentators in Australia that the Prime Minister has no choice but to dump you during the reshuffle this weekend?

—I thank you very much, Senator, for the question. I did say to you, as I have said to you on a number of occasions, the money was paid, the mistakes had been made. But I have constantly indicated in this place, in estimates and yet again last night, that I was not happy with the processes and I am pursuing them. After all, Senator, it was not you who asked for the matter to go to the Auditor‐General; it was not you who was quick enough to do that—it was me, when I became dissatisfied with the answers coming from my department. Senator, as to anything the Prime Minister has in mind, those matters are completely up to him. I just remind you that the last time the Australian people were consulted about who ought to be in government, your party did not get the tick.
—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of our recently retired distinguished colleague from South Australia Mr Dominic Foreman.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I understand that tenders have now closed for the employment services market. Will the minister indicate the breadth of interest in our reforms from the range of potential providers for this exciting new market? How does the government's competitive tendering process for the delivery of employment services compare with the processes under the former government under the so-called Working Nation program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tierney for his question and for his patience last night in putting up with 10½ hours of badgering from the union bullyboys coming along trying to get the story they wanted when it was not there. Yes, the tenders have closed. We have received just over 1,000 packages containing about 5,000 tenders, which cover the 29 employment regions throughout Australia. That means there is no region with fewer than 20 tenders. When you consider that the requirement I am looking for is a minimum of five suppliers in each region and that there is no region with fewer than 20 tenders, we can say that this is a very positive vote of confidence in the government's new employment services market.

ANSWER.PARA: This employment services market, which I referred to in the earlier question, shifts away from Working Nation to tendering for contracts, to competition, to transparency and to financial checks and conformance—almost none of which happened regularly under Working Nation contracts. So there was a very big vote of confidence in our new system, which will be operating fully in May next year.

We have been moving towards that system since the budget of 1996 when we announced our changes. We are still in a transition zone. We still have some remnants of the old style Working Nation contracts—less than there were but still a few. That was a system in contrast, a system which allowed the marginal Labor seats of Page and Richmond—remember the members, Harry Woods and Neville Newell—to have $24 million tipped into them; $3 million of that for an advertising campaign. They did not want to call it the `Let's save Harry Woods and Neville Newell campaign' so they called it the Northern Rivers new work opportunity project. But, nonetheless, $24 million of hard earned taxpayers' money was poured down the drain because that contract was an absolute failure.

There was another one called the `Let's save Bob Horne campaign' which went under the guise of the jobs north new work opportunity—in code for people who do not know what to look for. That had $14 million tipped into it. That is what you got under the old system when you did not have to go to tendering, when you did not have to have financial checks, when you looked after your mates, as those opposite did so well—$14 million tipped into the `Save Bob Horne campaign' in Paterson.

If you are not only worried about looking after your members, you can pop over to the Australian Education Union and see if you can tip $17 million into it—but with no outcome requirement, no real check on outcomes, just tip the money in. I must remind myself to take a quick look after question time to see if there are any political donations from that union.

The SPCL contract was the subject of scrutiny at Senate estimates yesterday. It is one of the last Working Nation style contracts. Labor certainly did not want to compare the performance of the SPCL contract against Working Nation contracts. I have the opportunity to tell you what happened yesterday when we tried to do that.

We know already that the SPCL contract, as dissatisfied as I am with it, already has a higher outcome achievement than most of the Working Nation contracts. We have outcomes in jobs, and it has only been a couple of weeks since the program finished. Working Nation projects were given 13 weeks. We are not up to 13 weeks and we will have much better outcomes by the time we get to that point. I want to confirm, as indicated before, what we learnt last night—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, can you confirm that you received briefs from the area Queensland central office shortly after the Courier‐Mail article on 11 June on this SPCL fiasco? Can you also confirm that the brief advised you that the contract with SPCL referred to `the legitimate use of funds, refund, or recovery of monies, and suspension and termination' of the contract? Minister, as you were the person ultimately responsible for Commonwealth funds, why didn't you seek urgent legal advice as to the measures available to the Commonwealth to protect its investment—in this case $2.2 million?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a re‐run of last night for senators who want to indulge themselves. They took up 10½ hours of the Senate's time in the estimates committee yesterday and very largely got answers to these questions. Senator, I do not have that briefing in front of me, but I believe roughly—
—Why not?

—I am not going to carry around three files in case you are silly enough to ask a question you asked the night before. Heavens above! What am I meant to think? Senator O'Brien is so dumb he will ask the same question today that he asked yesterday, I better bring the files along! I mean, really, Senator, get a grip on it! You asked this last night, and I am just repeating it for the benefit of others who could not be bothered sitting there listening to you prattle on.

ANSWER.PARA: What was explained to you last night was the care and attention given to this by the department, after becoming aware of the problems, to see that training was delivered. What was highlighted last night, in a sense, was the difference between the approach of this government and the department and the approach that you wanted to take. You people over there and your counterparts in Queensland knew full well that SPCL was not looking at having union based labour on its ship.
Senator Carr interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You knew that, didn't you? You have been worried about it from the day you heard about it. You set about predetermining to ensure that if there was going to be a job it was going to be a union job and if it was not a union job it was not going to be there. So, Senator, you would have approached that brief and thought, `Wow, now I've got a chance to rip into this. Now I can put a stop to this program going ahead.' On the other hand, on this side of the chamber we have a very different view about jobs. I do not care if they are union jobs or non-union jobs. If a job is created, I am happy that my department puts the effort in to try to assist with the training.

BREAK.PARA: The approach that we took all along—this was detailed for you last night—included consulting with William Angliss 2000, making sure that the training was happening and making sure that they were being paid. All of those things were happening because our focus was on the trainees, not some cheap bit of Labor ideology. That is the difference between your approach and mine. It is a very different approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. I really did not get an answer to the question that I asked, which was: why didn't you, Minister, accept your responsibility to seek urgent legal advice to protect the Commonwealth's $2.2 million? Minister, in your 3 September `Don't blame me, I only work here' letter to the secretary of your department, you claim not to have received a written brief on the matter at any time from central office. Why did you not mention in this letter that you had received the area Queensland central office briefs in June and failed to act for 11 weeks?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Brien, I had great hopes for your future. I thought that you would be popping down to the front before too long. But this performance is occasioning me to think again.

ANSWER.PARA: It was clearly understood that my office had sought a brief and some information from the Queensland office. That was the place to go. That was where this contract was being put together. As I indicated earlier, I sought a written brief from national office. Ministers, generally speaking, get their advice from the national office. That is why I sought a brief from them. They knew that I had sought the brief, and the brief was not forthcoming. There were revised possible parliamentary questions, but not the brief. The details as to how that came about and why were outlined very clearly for you last night. Unlike Senator Carr and Senator Faulkner, you were there most of the time, and I did not notice you nodding off.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, who has special responsibility for the Remuneration Tribunal. Is the minister aware of recent calls for the Remuneration Tribunal to review the existing travel allowance guidelines for parliamentarians and office holders? What has precipitated these calls and what are their merits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —These calls are of very recent origin. As recently as yesterday lunchtime and, indeed, after question time, we had Senator Sherry and the other puppeteers, Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner, mounting a furious defence of the status quo, telling us that all was above board, everything was according to Hoyle and everything had been done according to the rules. All that changed at 5.35 last night when Senator Sherry went on ABC radio in Sydney and said the following in an interview with Mike Jeffreys:

ANSWER.PARA: You say that you believe the guidelines should be changed so you can no longer claim the $300 a night, when you stay, in your case, with your mother at Opossum Bay.
SHERRY
Yes I do. I think it's time they changed and I think there should be a proper independent review to change them.
Was this a sudden conversion on the road to Opossum Bay? No way. Let me read on:
JEFFREYS
And in the meantime, will you continue to claim or will you stop claiming altogether now when you stay at your mother's?
SHERRY
Oh well as I said on occasions I haven't claimed when I've been at Mum's.
JEFFREYS
But what about in the future now?
SHERRY
Um well er I think every Member of Parliament is being extraordinarily careful about what they claim.
JEFFREYS
But what about you? Will you claim?
SHERRY
Oh look er um I think that's highly unlikely.
JEFFREYS
It's unlikely that you'll claim?
SHERRY
Yeah, well look—
JEFFREYS
But you're not sure?
SHERRY
No, no. I'll give an assurance.
JEFFREYS
You'll give an assurance here and now?
SHERRY
Here and now, um—
JEFFREYS
Next time you stay at your Mum's at Opossum Bay, and from here on in, you will not claim the $300 a night?
SHERRY
That, that's correct. And I hope that those—I won't claim—and I hope those guidelines are changed as soon as possible.

There it is. That says it all. Having worked the system for years, he recognises that he is a hopeless and helpless TA addict, so he throws himself on the mercy of the Remuneration Tribunal and asks them to change the rules as soon as possible to save him from himself.

What possessed Senator Sherry to go on the ABC? I suppose he thought that he would be able to get away with a glib line about changing the rules, but instead he found himself cornered like one of mum's possums. He was comprehensively cross-examined into the ground and had to make concessions that he was totally unwilling to make at the start of the interview. In other words, he recognised that his position was politically unsustainable and very damaging to his colleagues.

If the rules are to be changed, let me say this to Senator Sherry: they will be done in due course and after proper consideration. But in the meantime, there is nothing to stop Senator Sherry refraining from working the system. All he has to do is simply go straight, cold turkey, or cold possum. If you are as efficient as you say you are—if you are a very busy fellow—why on earth would you be chalking up hundreds of hours of Comcar just to get down to one of the sleepiest hollows in the country to spend a bit of time at mum's hideaway when all that one could probably expect to find down there are a few marsupials? I bet you that the ones that are there do not have pouches anywhere as large as your TA pouch.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. It follows on from Senator Alston's damp squib dorothy dix. Given that you, Minister, have vociferously criticised Senator Sherry for claiming 35.7 nights per year in Hobart, will you confirm that in the first 11 months of your government, Senator Alston himself claimed TA for 38 nights in Sydney at a cost of $12,200, Mr Fahey claimed TA for 41 nights in Sydney at a cost of $13,120, Mr Fischer claimed TA for 46 nights in Sydney at a cost of $14,720, and Senator Brownhill claimed TA for 48 nights in Sydney at a cost of $15,420? Will you also confirm that, in the period March 1993 to March 1997, when Senator Sherry claimed a total of 143 nights TA, as we have heard ad nauseam, in Hobart, Mr Tim Fischer claimed 161 nights in Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner has raised a number of questions and stated a range of figures in relation to a number of ministers. One thing he did not say was that none of those ministers claimed $320 a night for staying at Opossum Bay. Senator Faulkner, that is the real issue. That is what you have totally ducked. Senator Faulkner along with Senator Ray, the great hounder of Senator Colston, are now the great protectors of Senator Sherry. The public will draw their conclusions.

ANSWER.PARA: Thank you for that question, Senator Faulkner. I appreciated the chance to get up and point out the real issue. The real issue, one which you have comprehensively ducked, is that the man just behind you claimed 143 nights in `Hobart', worth over $40,000, when he was staying at Opossum Bay, 50 kilometres from Hobart. Thank you for the question, Senator Faulkner. If you have a supplementary question, I have a few more figures for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I would not mind, Minister, if you had a crack at actually answering the question that I ask. Perhaps you will investigate whether one of your colleagues, who owns three properties in Sydney, claims TA when he stays in Sydney at a property he owns but rents to a member of his immediate family. Will you have that checked out while you are at it, Minister?

—Senator Faulkner, I will tell you what we are checking out and what you should be checking out. You should be checking out those 143 nights in `Hobart', a lot of them over the weekend, and what your senior colleague was doing. That is the issue. I know the tactic is to come in and throw some mud. The Australian taxpayers are focusing very clearly on all that money, the $43,000, that Senator Sherry was paid to go and visit mum. All you can say is some mothers do have `em.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Minister, it is common knowledge that the government is going to allow countries with infectious diseases to import chicken meat into Australia and expose our poultry and bird life to the threat of Newcastle disease and other bird viruses. Minister, it has been reported that AQIS testing has found there is minimal risk of importing Newcastle disease through cooked chicken meat imports. Are you concerned that, if the tests are wrong, Australian taxpayers could be liable for a multimillion dollar compensation bill if farmers launch a class action? Has the Attorney-General's Department checked the AQIS reports to protect taxpayers from liability for government decisions that prove to be wrong?
—I thank Senator Woodley for that detailed question. I am not aware of any check by the Attorney-General's Department of that matter. I will take it on notice and get back to you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I appreciate that. I wonder, however, whether you would concede that the Attorney-General has a responsibility to protect taxpayers from liability for government decisions that are wrong. I ask you to ask the Attorney-General to check the science of the chicken meat imports to ensure that taxpayers do not have to pay for the government's mistakes.
—Again, Senator Woodley, I will take that on notice. The Attorney-General does advise the government on matters from time to time, and this is something which he clearly can provide advice on.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it is in light of the answer given by Senator Kemp to a question he was not asked. Minister, can you confirm that, from the period of 1 July 1994 to March 1997, you claimed 73 nights travel allowance in Sydney, at the capital city rate, at a cost $22,320? Will you confirm that your entry in the register of senators' interests indicates that you own a property in Sydney and have done so for some years? Will you confirm whether you have ever stayed at that property at any stage in that time and claimed travel allowance?

—I can obviously check the records as to the number of nights that I might have stayed in Sydney in pursuit of my obligations. With the help of a bank, I own one property in Sydney. That is correct. As to whether I have ever stayed at it, I do not recall ever having stayed at it, but I would want to check that as well. If I have stayed at it, it certainly would have been on very few occasions. I do not recall ever having stayed at it. I will check.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. You would understand, Minister, the direct analogy between those circumstances and those of Senator Sherry.
—Sydney is a capital city; Opossum Bay is not.

—Senator Hill knows the reference I am making. I am not being too abrasive here, as he would acknowledge. I in fact know who is in the unit in Sydney. That is not a scandalous accusation; it just happens to be an arrangement to do with his family. I did not want to raise that.
—You have just raised it.

—Senator Hill understands what I am saying. You understand what I am saying, don't you? If you had stayed there and claimed travel allowance, you would agree that it is exactly analogous—other than the GPO argument—to the situation of Senator Sherry.
—If I did what Senator Sherry did, then it would be analogous. But the point is that I did not.
—You can't remember; you're checking it out.

—I have to check the period. Since I have owned the property, it has been let out. It was purchased as an investment property, but for some of that period it has been let to tenants, one of whom is my daughter. But that is not the point. The point is that for night after night Senator Sherry stayed at his mother's property at Opossum Bay and claimed a full allowance. Senator Ray can make a judgment on whether he believes that is an appropriate call on the taxpayers' money or not. When Senator Ray referred to the same sort of thing in relation to Senator Colston, he said that it was a disgrace. But has he said it of Senator Sherry? No. It is a classic case of double standards, Senator Ray, I would suggest.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he recall that on 5 December last year I tabled a document in the Senate—figurings from my office—which indicated that the one-third sale of Telstra could realise $15 billion? Does he agree that that is probably nearer the mark than the government's then estimate of $8 billion? Where is the government going to spend the extra money? Will it at least preserve the integrity of the Natural Heritage Trust Fund and ensure that moneys from that fund do not go for any other purpose?
—Before I call Senator Hill, I would ask senators on my right to turn down some of those microphones.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is appropriate for me to speculate on what might be the return to the government on the sale of one-third of Telstra. What I said at the time still stands: that is, the intention of the government, over and above the specific capital commitments that it made, was that the balance be used to repay debt. That still remains our view.

ANSWER.PARA: We have an opportunity here to continue to repay debt and, therefore, improve the fiscal circumstances of this country from which all Australians will benefit. We believe that is good policy. We said it at the election; it is still our objective. Natural Heritage Trust Fund money will only be used for purposes as provided through the Natural Heritage Trust Fund legislation, set out in some detail in that legislation and debated in further detail in this place during the passage of that legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to you, Madam President. Can you confirm that you have altered procedural rules affecting travel allowance claims for those staying overnight at a capital city having travelled from Perth? Was it ever brought to your attention that a senator caught the red eye special from Perth to Melbourne, snoozed at the airport for a couple of hours and claimed—or tried to claim—travel allowance at the capital city rate?
