If not, would you have the records checked to see whether any Senate official drew this to your attention or to the attention of your predecessor?

—I will have that latter matter checked. There have been arrangements and a determination sent to all senators about the changed arrangements for travelling and stopping on the way to Canberra. I shall incorporate that in Hansard . It was sent out to all senators. The other matter will have to be checked.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Last week the Ombudsman's annual report came out, and it blamed the 43 per cent increase in complaints about Austudy on the decision by the government to cut operational funding for DEETYA as well as the complexity of the Austudy actual means test. Does the minister agree with the Ombudsman's report that the AMT is too complicated, or does the minister believe that students should continue to answer between 280 and 320 questions about personal income and expenditure in order to comply? Does the minister accept the Ombudsman's claims that the funding cuts to DEETYA and the complexity of the AMT are responsible for the problems and the failings of Austudy this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Stott Despoja for her question. Senator, I do not think it is possible to say, `I agree completely with everything in the report' or `I disagree completely with everything in the report' because there might be some things that I agree with and some things that I do not agree with. It is important to understand this: the report is a snapshot of history that no longer reflects the current situation with respect to Austudy. The Austudy actual means test is designed to prevent individuals with very complex arrangements who minimise their tax liabilities from claiming benefits. Any measure designed to catch people who, through the use of well paid accountants and lawyers operating through trusts, partnerships and companies, seek to minimise their taxable income and assets will necessarily be at a level of complexity. It is not possible to produce a yes-no completely simple form.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, as you know, when it became clear in February this year that there were problems with the administration of the AMT, we announced a streamlining of administration to fix the problem. Within a week or so, students at that point who had lost benefits began to receive payments. It is a pity—and I do not want to put it any higher than that—that the Ombudsman's report does not adequately acknowledge three key initiatives that we have taken to address the problems that it draws attention to. I do not dispute that there were problems there and that it is appropriate for the Ombudsman to report them, but it might be equally handy if some of the things that the government was doing to address problems had been referred to.

There was an announcement of a review of the AMT on 24 June this year to identify anomalies in the test and make improvements. I announced this morning, Senator, as you may well be aware, the result of that inquiry, which will be very positive for AMT applicants and significantly streamlined from last year. It might equally be helpful if the Ombudsman had bothered to mention to people who have an interest in these matters the government's key initiative to combine Austudy and other benefits, to streamline them into a youth allowance. That streamlining in itself will be of some benefit, with about 70,000 students living away from home then being eligible to receive rent assistance under the youth allowance. It would also be helpful to mention that Centrelink—the combining of the shop‐front services of the Commonwealth Employment Service and Department of Social Security—would provide an improved and streamlined service delivery to students.

It mighty equally be fair to point out that the Ombudsman's report is largely based on a proportion of complaints. It is necessary that people understand that. It is not a general survey across the board of Austudy applicants but is a comment, as I understand it, on responses that were complaints. It is like taking one portion of the Austudy population that complained and putting a spotlight on it. So necessarily the report gives a much darker picture than what the reality is.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her response. But I was not asking her whether she agreed with all the recommendations; I was asking whether she agreed with two—the findings that suggest, firstly, that the cuts to operational funding to DEETYA and, secondly, the complexity of the AMT were responsible for the failings of Austudy this year. I acknowledge your points about complexity, but the Ombudsman states:

QUESTION.PARA: It is becoming so complex and confusing that it is questionable whether it is delivering an effective form of income support to many students.

So minister, to ensure that history does not repeat, are you prepared to consider streamlining this process and tabling in this place legislation, an Austudy bill, that gets rid of the regulations so that the legislation is more transparent, is easier to administer and is more understandable, not only to people in this place but also to DEETYA, which has to interpret it, and to the public, who need the benefits?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some different views from the Ombudsman as to the causes of the problems last year. There was some downsizing in the department but not so as to result in the problems Austudy students suffered; I do not think that is an adequate explanation for that in any way. As I indicated to you in my answer, by virtue of the fact that because the people who want to minimise their taxable incomes in order to get benefits—the greedy, rather than the needy—have the specialist advice of highly paid lawyers and accountants, it is not possible to design a simple tick form. It is always possible to try to make it simpler, and we are working on that.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of the Kuwaiti-Australian Parliamentary Friendship Group, led by the Chairman, Mr Sami Al- Monayes, MP. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate. I trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable.

INTERJECT.PARA: I also draw the attention of senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of former distinguished South Australian senator Tony Messner. Welcome to you too, Mr Messner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I direct my question to Senator Kemp, the minister for non-answers and minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services.
—I take a point of order, Madam President—
—Ha, ha!

—There is great hilarity here. The opposition has not even heard the point of order. They are not really interested in whether it might be a useful contribution. Just laugh your way through while you are paid money for doing a job.
—Order! Senator Vanstone, what is your point of order?
—They are a disgrace, Madam President. You should kick them all out.
—What is your point of order?

—My point of order is that I ask you to consider—not necessarily today—whether it is in order for people to get up and address a question to a minister that contains in the preamble to the minister's title some sort of derogatory reference as Senator Ray's question does—`the minister for not answering questions' or `the minister for whatever'. I do not think it is appropriate in terms of addressing the question. They might have the opportunity in the substance of the question but not in addressing the question to the relevant minister.

—I didn't mean to hurt Senator Kemp. I humbly withdraw that terrible assertion. Is the minister aware of the practice of certain Western Australian members and senators using their charter entitlement to charter planes to fly members of the Liberal Party preselection panels around the state? Will you ascertain whether this is consistent with the DAS charter guidelines? Were the members and senators concerned on the charter planes when the travel was undertaken? If not, is this travel consistent with the DAS charter guidelines?

—Senator Ray was correct. His unkind comments caused me no hurt, so he should feel mightily relieved on that front. I am happy to respond to the backbencher who defends the indefensible, Saint Nick, who spent the first part of his career as a backbencher trying to attack Colston.
—Senator, you should refer to Senator Colston as `Senator Colston'.

—`Senator Colston'; I am sorry about that. I will certainly accept your guidelines, Madam President. So Senator Ray, there will be an interesting contrast between your relentless attack on Senator Colston and your relentless defence of Saint Nick. When you think on the scale of things, which is the bigger rort? I would say $43,000 is a hell of a rort by anybody's standard. I know in politics that when you are on the back foot you roll out Robert Ray and try to get on the front foot. We understand that, and we understand that it has been a very bad week for Labor and we understand that you want to get up and throw some more mud. But I will check the guidelines. Senator Ray, this comment one of your colleagues made to me may interest you—I will not name the person: `I don't know what Kim Beazley is doing going on about charters. This is a common practice in all parties'.

—I do not know that I should have withdrawn my earlier comment, but I will proceed. Minister, your side has put on the public record via the department via inspired leaks—even though you hate leaks from departments—questions to do with the Leader of the Opposition's charter. I have asked you whether you will investigate joint charters by Western Australian senators. If you need a greater hint, they are both arguing over what the order on the ticket should be—and it is not you, Senator Knowles, if you want a real hint. Will you see whether they ever chartered planes and put on those planes preselection delegates and flew them to preselections? Will you at least commit yourself to do that and not go into any other irrelevancy on entitlements? Will you answer that question?

—Isn't it wonderful. Senator Ray, who has made a specialty of coming into this chamber and slandering as many people as he can, gets a little bit worried if he gets just a little bit back. Very sensitive, Senator Ray. Senator Ray, you have raised a question, and I will see whether there is any particular information I am able to provide to you.

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware of Senator Sherry's claim that the DAS guidelines justified Senator Sherry in claiming travelling allowance at capital city rates for his many stays at his mother's house at Opossum Bay? Is this the case, or is the advice from the Acting Minister for Administrative Services different from what Senator Sherry has asserted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for that important question. I am able to inform the Senate that, as a result of the debate yesterday, the claims and counterclaims and an examination of what Senator Sherry said, there is no doubt that Senator Sherry has misled this Senate. This is what Senator Sherry said:

ANSWER.PARA: I assert to the Senate that each one of my Hobart TA claims meets the requirements as specified in the Department of Administrative Services guidelines.
The DAS guidelines set rates for capital city claims. The guidelines state:
`Capital city is as defined (in relation to its boundaries) by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.'

What Senator Sherry failed to tell the Senate—and, I think, failed to tell Senator Ray—was that he was quoting the guidelines used for car transport purposes only, not the defini tion for office holders for travel allowance purposes.

I have checked with the Acting Minister for Administrative Services, who has reconfirmed with the department, that the advice I gave yesterday was correct. The provisions governing TA for office holders are set out in the Remuneration Tribunal determination No. 21 of 1995, which simply indicates that the likes of Senator Sherry are entitled to claim $320 a night for capital cities. There is no definition of `capital cities'.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're suggesting there's a different one; what's the other one?

—It is not Opossum Bay, mate! There is no definition of `capital cities'. It is up to Senator Sherry to justify why Opossum Bay should be classified as a capital city. The advice Senator Sherry gave to the Senate was wrong—and he knew it was wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: Just to assist Senator Sherry and other Labor senators, the car transport guidelines are different from those for travel allowances, for good reason. The reason is that, if Senator Sherry wishes to stay with mum, he is entitled to get a car to and fro. We do not expect his mum to drive him to the airport or put him on the school bus, and the car transport guidelines reflect this. However, the guidelines for travel allowance and for the treatment of capital cities is a totally different issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?

—The capital city rate is higher than the country rate to reflect the higher cost of accommodation. No-one in their wildest dreams would ever suggest that the cost of accommodation at Opossum Bay is anywhere near as high as that in Hobart.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have seen is that Senator Sherry was wilfully abusing the system—and Senator Sherry got caught. After he got caught, he decided that he had better attempt to justify his actions. So what he did was try to find guidelines, any guidelines, that he thought could cover his actions. Let me restate the point: the guidelines used by Senator Sherry did not relate to travel allowance for office holders; they relate to car transport. That is the advice I have received from the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I would ask you to withdraw the use of the word `wilfully' in your answer.
—Madam President, if that word is offensive, I will withdraw it.
—No, Senator. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw it.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the explanation that the minister has just given, in contrast to the comments made by Senator Sherry yesterday, does the minister believe that, given what the guidelines are, Senator Sherry has in fact misled the Senate?

—There is no question but that Senator Sherry has misled the Senate. There is no question but that Senator Sherry has claimed tens of thousands of dollars for staying with his mum at Opossum Bay. There is no question but that Senator Sherry should pay the money back. There is no question but that Senator Sherry, as a matter of decency, as a matter of proprietary, as a matter of convention, should now resign.

—My question is directed to the minister who resides at 303 Oak Drive and represents the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Could you confirm, Senator Kemp, that one of your colleagues, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade—that is, Senator the honourable David Brownhill—owns three properties in Sydney but claims TA in Sydney at a property he owns but rents to a member of his immediate family?

—Again we see the Labor Party trying to defend Senator Sherry by raising a variety of other issues. Everyone will see through this attempt by Senator Faulkner, but the senator has raised a question and I will refer the question to the minister and see whether there is any response I am able to give to you.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I suppose it is an improvement for Senator Kemp at least to admit that he cannot answer a question and will take it—as he ought—on notice. Perhaps while he is checking things out, the minister might also establish whether the only definition of `capital city' that is in fact defined within Commonwealth legislation is that contained within section 282 of the Telecommunications Act 1997. I would appreciate it if the minister could confirm that that is the case and report back to the Senate as soon as possible.
—I think the supplementary question should have been asked of the Minister for Communications. It related to a bill that he administers, so I am surprised you have asked me the question.
—Where is your definition?

—You made a goose of yourself; you asked the wrong minister the question. Just sit there and take it. If you have a question about that particular act, I suspect that that question should asked of Senator Alston.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Now that we know that Senator Sherry has misled the Senate by using his transport entitlement to justify his travel allowance claims, is it a fact that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, has also resorted to the same misleading behaviour to protect Senator Sherry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Regrettably, it appears so. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, issued a statement in which he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I note that the Acting Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Ruddock, told the House of Representatives that it was a matter for Senator Sherry to decide whether he should be claiming capital city rates for travel allowance. In accordance with this I—
that is, Mr Beazley—

BREAK.PARA: have attached a print‐out of the DAS on-line advice to members and senators which includes the formal definition of `capital city' for the purposes of travel allowance claims.

He did attach a document and in fact all that document included were definitions and the detail of those definitions. It is true that it included a definition of a capital city. Someone had written in hand at the top `Senators and members' entitlements online'.

Madam President, if you go back to those entitlements online, what do you find of the document? You find that the definitions in fact refer to car transport. They do not refer to travel allowance claims at all. It is in fact headed up `Car transport', sets out entitlements in relation to capital cities and then it gives the definitions including the definition of `capital city' for those purposes.

Either Mr Beazley or someone presumably under his authority—or perhaps it was even Senator Sherry—removed that part that detailed car transport and instead simply put at the top `Senators and members' entitlements online' and doctored the document with the purpose of misleading the Australian people. If it was not bad enough for Senator Sherry to come into the parliament yesterday and mislead the Senate by putting the same point and arguing that in fact in relation to travelling allowances there was a definition and reading out that definition when it was not the case, Mr Beazley has gone that one step further and corroborated what Senator Sherry had said—in other words, corroborated the misleading element of the Senator Sherry's statement to this parliament.

There can be no doubt about it when you look at these documents. It would have been possible for Senator Sherry to come in at lunchtime and have said—if he wished to be honest—that there is no definition in fact in relation to travelling allowances. He could have said there is a definition in relation to transport, what the definition was and then argued that it was reasonable for him to apply the car transport definition, but he did not do so. He rather chose to mislead the Senate to advance his interests and that was corroborated then by Mr Beazley's statement.

This is a disgrace. This action by Mr Beazley is an absolute disgrace. He should be setting a standard. That is what we would expect and what the public would expect from someone who holds his high office and he failed to do that yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask Senator Hill if he is aware of comments made by Mr Evans yesterday morning regarding the standards of politicians and travel allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of it. I remember what Mr Evans said at a doorstop yesterday morning. I remember it, but I have also got a note of it, which makes it a bit easier. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . as Kim Beazley made absolutely clear from the outset, to the extent that any of our people, whether politicians or staffers were involved in doing anything wrong, they would have to bear the consequences.

I can tell former Senator Evans that what he is has done is drop Mr Beazley right in it. Because perhaps the greatest wrongdoing of all in this whole exercise is what Mr Beazley did yesterday and that was to deliberately mislead the Australian people for the purpose of protecting Senator Sherry, and that, Madam President, is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not think the senator should cast that aspersion on the Leader of the Opposition.
—I withdraw the word `deliberately'.

—I direct my question to Senator Kemp, the Minister representing the Acting Minister for Administrative Services. Did the department on the change of government draw to the attention of all new members of parliament the requirements and responsibilities in using Cabcharge cards? Is the minister aware that many new members in Sydney used Cabcharge cards when they were not entitled to, noting that the entitlement is only alternate to Commonwealth car use? How many members of parliament have repaid improperly claimed Cabcharge charges and, if you do not have that information, can you bring it back in two weeks time on the next day of sitting?
—Senator Robert Ray has raised a number of detailed questions. I will take that question on notice.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to a contract betwen the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and South Pacific Cruise Lines Limited.

The `ship of fools' issue is the most recent in a very long line of ministerial foul-ups from Senator Vanstone. It has been a sorry saga of ministerial incompetence from Senator Vanstone from day one. Yesterday, we had the absurd spectacle of government senators trying to protect Senator Vanstone. It was a desperate attempt to cover up the South Pacific Cruise Lines issue by derailing a Senate estimates committee hearing. They did this by bringing in extraneous issues, irrelevant issues, and by trying to waste the time of that committee.

But, eventually, the truth had to come out. The truth is this: Senator Vanstone has fouled up again in the administration of her portfolio. That is the story. That is the reason that I predict Senator Vanstone will be losing her job tomorrow. We have seen the last in the Australian Senate of Senator Vanstone as Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

Senator Vanstone said she was aware of the South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco on 11 and 12 June. But many other issues relating to this particular matter came across Senator Vanstone's desk. On 30 April, she got a drop copy of a brief that went to Dr Kemp on the William Angliss 2000 project. Now, of course, that was not signed off by Senator Vanstone—she does not do that; that was signed off by a departmental liaison officer in her office.

Senator Vanstone received several letters from Liberal members of parliament: from her colleague Mr Jull on 7 May and from her colleague Mr Slipper on 22 May. She did nothing about those letters. She got a ministerial brief on the issues that Mr Jull raised on 16 May. That was not signed. In fact, Senator Vanstone has said it was not even seen by her—a ministerial brief to her. She did nothing about it.

After the matter became public on 11 June—when she claims she was made aware of media reports—she got two briefs from the DEETYA Queensland central area office. She did nothing about them. There were consistent media reports and publicity about the South Pacific Cruise Lines issue; she did nothing about them. The matter was debated ad nauseam in the Queensland parliament. Senator Vanstone did nothing about it. She received a number of possible parliamentary questions and question time briefs from her department over those weeks; she did nothing about them.

She was asked questions in the Senate estimates committee hearing on 19 August. Many serious issues were raised, particularly by my colleagues Senator Chris Evans and Senator O'Brien. She did nothing about those issues that were raised at the Senate estimates committee hearing. In fact, the next day, as responsible minister, she oversaw her department extending the contract with these same shonky SPCL operators. Questions were also asked by Senator O'Brien in the chamber right here on 27 and 28 August this year. She did nothing about the matter.

So with bad press after bad press and media reports about the shonky operators of this cruise line company and their mafia links, what did Senator Vanstone do when she read these reports? She did nothing. In fact, it was only on 26 August that she first raised the issue with the secretary of her department. It is extraordinary that it took the minister 76 days or 11 weeks, if you like, after she became aware of the matter—according to her, although we know she was aware of it a lot longer; it took her that long to raise the issue with her departmental secretary. Then she wrote to her departmental secretary, Mr Sedgwick, on 3 September; she had the hide to write to him and complain that nothing was being done by her department.

This minister did nothing. Her office did nothing. She did not, of course, exercise her ministerial responsibilities. She claims that she asked the Auditor-General to act, but only on 12 September. It is a pathetic performance from a minister who, for the last time, has presented in this chamber as Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. She will go; she deserves to go. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —The only useful thing that Senator Faulkner has said in this debate today is that the hearing yesterday was a sorry spectacle. Boy, was it a sorry spectacle! There we had Senator Faulkner and his colleagues trailing through an enormous amount of information from 9 a.m. to 1.30 a.m. The minister says 10 hours but she is being incredibly generous. It was actually 13½ hours of wasted time of the Senate estimates committee and of wasted time of senior public servants. They were given all the information by the minister. The minister was totally up front about this matter. She has provided any information that they wanted and any documents they wanted.

SPEECH.PARA: There were an enormous amount of documents. For hour after hour after hour we heard those opposite referring to a bit of correspondence and asking: When did you get that? When did you know about that? The media were there for a while. I saw a few of them nodding off to sleep and then they totally disappeared. I think this matter got about one column inch today. It was an enormous waste of the Senate's time.

Following that, having wasted so much time, what did those opposite want to do? They decided, `We'll send it off to a Senate references committee and we'll go around and collect evidence on this and waste even more time and money.' That was put up this morning. I note that it was deferred, probably because there was no support for such a silly proposition. That was apparent to anyone who sat and listened last night—if you did not fall asleep watching the TV—through this enormously boring and wasteful time as we went through this particular matter.

The procedures that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) has followed on this matter are completely straightforward. She was concerned about the matter and has sent it off to the Auditor‐General for a full report so that she will have the correct information base on this matter to provide the answers for the Senate. But those opposite could not wait for that; they had to do a bit of grandstanding in the meantime.

DEETYA is obviously an enormously complex department. There are thousands and thousands of contracts, and to expect that the minister would know every little detail about every contract at the time that you indicate is just nonsense. When the minister did become aware of this matter, she expressed great concern and set procedures in train to fix it up.

What a contrast with the way this Labor government operated under Working Nation. Yesterday, the government senators built a picture of stark contrast with the way in which, under the so‐called Working Nation program, with very few checks on how the money was spent—

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom drawer treatment, isn't it? Put it in the bottom drawer and hope it goes away; if you close your eyes it might disappear.

—Senator Carr's mates in the union movement got almost $½ million to employ so‐called `training officers'. When I asked what checks were made on whether those people were doing the job that was intended, the answer was, `Well, we checked at the end of the time that they were in the job.' What job were they in, Senator Carr? They were probably out organising strikes. That is what they were probably doing—`other' union work. We had this cosy little picture where the government gave money to the unions and the unions made donations back to the ALP.
—Who was the minister?
—We had a range of ministers. We had Mr Crean.
—Mr Beazley.

—Yes, Mr Beazley was the minister before that. That was a cosy little arrangement. This government has put in place a range of measures to stop that sort of rorting. There was another type—this was the classic. The northern rivers project was to prop up Harry Woods and Neville Newell in the seats of Page and Richmond.
—Senator Tierney, would you please refer to Mr Woods by his correct name as he is a member of another parliament.

—I will call him Mr Woods, the former member for Page. Those two former members of parliament got $24 million in subsidies for these projects just before the election. Remember Ros Kelly? She handed out $30 million. This was $24 million—not across Australia but for two marginal seats in northern New South Wales and another one further down the coast, Paterson; three marginal seats. What was the great news? Despite spending all that money, Labor still lost the seats. That is the way they operated under Working Nation. What a contrast. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Tierney does not share our concern at the waste of $2.2 million of taxpayers money or how the hopes of 340 long‐term unemployed people have been cruelly crushed by the government's failure to be able to deliver jobs to them at the end of the training scheme that they undertook. We think it is a serious matter and that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) and those opposite ought to take a bit more interest and show a bit more concern about this issue. It is one of the great financial disasters that this government has presided over. It is a big human disaster too, in the sense of its impact on those 340 people who worked hard to qualify for what they thought was a job on a cruise liner. The whole thing came to nothing. Despite what the minister asserted today in question time, in fact not one of those people got a job with the cruise line because the cruise line that was supposed to eventuate was operated by a bunch of crooks who never had a ship or any financial understanding of the industry. In fact, they were discharged bankrupts. These are the persons that the department entered into a contract with.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very serious matter. It is a major financial fiasco and the department has to take a lot of the blame. But the process is far from over. At estimates last night we investigated what we could but, because the Auditor‐General has been required to report on the process, because there are legal proceedings before the courts in terms of suing the people the department entered into contracts with, and because there was a range of questions at estimates taken on notice, this process is far from over. It will continue to hound the minister until she is relieved of her duties. I suspect that that will be a matter of days.

There are serious issues that the department has to answer. It was the largest ever TEP project undertaken with a single employer and the outcome was clearly a complete disaster. A range of problems that need to be examined inside the department has already been identified. One of those that I would like to get to grips with is this push by the minister and senior officers to get departmental officers to spend project funds by the end of the financial year. It is quite clear from all the documentation that the junior officers were under enormous pressure to spend the project funds by the end of the financial year. The government had no policy on employment; it had no employment program strategy. At the end of the year when it suddenly realised that it had done nothing to help create jobs to solve unemployment the officers were told, `Spend the money, quick.' So they spent almost 10 per cent of their budget for TEP in one effort. They gave it to some shonky employer and said, `Quick, give us 340 jobs—or at least make it look like we have 340 jobs.' But there was not one job.

The real question that hangs over all this is: why didn't the minister do anything? She has become known as the Marie Celeste of the government because this is an utter disaster. She first knew on 11 June. She had seen the press. It was then raised in estimates and she was advised by the department. But, from 11 June, do you know how long it took her to do anything? Not till 3 September did she finally take decisive action.

Do you know what she did? She wrote to her department's secretary and said, `Don't blame me. I only work here. When this hits the fan, I wasn't there.' That was the action she took. She did not seek legal advice. She did not seek advice about how to get us out of the mess. She did not seek advice about how to protect $2.2 million of the taxpayers' money and she did not seek advice about how to get 340 people jobs. She just made sure that, when it hit the fan, she was not anywhere to be seen. That has been her position ever since.

So she dropped the department in it, saying, `It's nothing to do with me. I'm the captain of the Marie Celeste.' When they found the ship floating, the crew was still on board but there was no captain. The captain had abandoned ship. The minister is not to be found. She just says to her department, `It's not my fault. You're going to have to wear this one.'

Had she even spoken to the departmental secretary? It was revealed last night in estimates that she had not even had a conversation with him. That is how concerned she was about these 340 people. That is how concerned she was about $2.2 million being handed over to spivs, with no financial checks at all. She did not bother to ask.

Senator O'Brien and I raised it with her on 19 August in estimates, after it had been all through the papers in Queensland for weeks. She was not able to help us with any information. She did not take any action then or afterwards. She has done nothing to protect the financial position of the Commonwealth, she has done nothing to protect the interests of those 340 people who were without jobs. She stands condemned for that. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I had the unfortunate experience of witnessing the opposition trying to cross‐examine Senator Vanstone at the reconvened estimates hearings. The charge was led by Senator Faulkner, whose performance was nothing short of pathetic, although his was the best performance. On occasion he did rise and ask something, but that was only after Senator Robert Ray had walked in to whisper in his ear. It was one of the most boring, unproductive estimates I have ever witnessed in my 3½ years in this place.
—And you have seen a few boring ones.

—Senator Carr is now promising us a few more boring ones, if I heard that interjection correctly. If you are on a committee, Senator Carr, everybody can be guaranteed it will be boring and unproductive.

SPEECH.PARA: What did you end up with, after all those hours of hearing yesterday trying to get the minister? We gave you hours of time, and what did the Australian headline say today? It said, `Vanstone cleared'. That is how the journalists have assessed this. They have heard the questions of Senator O'Brien, Senator Chris Evans, Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr, and what conclusion have they all come to? That Vanstone is cleared.

Instead of raising the white flag, as any decent individual would, having had such an unproductive chase, you come into this chamber trying to pursue the fruitless, unproductive line that Senator Vanstone is somehow in the gun. Even journalists are against you on this one. Even they realise that there is no substance to the allegations being made. What we are witnessing is a trawling exercise of the worst kind. It would be interesting to find out how much it cost the Australian people to have that reconvened estimates hearing last night, going in excess of 12 hours of hearing—

TALK.START.PARA: —Get it right.
—However many hours of hearing it was, to get a headline that the minister is cleared. That is something every decent person in this place knew right from the very beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: With a huge department like hers, Senator O'Brien and his mates on the other side suggest that Senator Vanstone ought to have control over each paperslide and stapler that circulates around in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. She does delegate things.

What is more, the guidelines under which this scheme operated were tightened guidelines from the Working Nation program which used to be administered by Messrs Beazley and Crean. Under Working Nation—Senator Tierney has already pointed this out to us—under your guidelines, the most outrageous things happened. The trade union movement was given literally millions of dollars for these Working Nation schemes and, when accountability came into the question, there was no accountability on those: `We're dealing with trade unions; they are our mates. How dare you think there might be an accountability process when we deliver millions of dollars to our mates in the trade union movement. Of course we would not have accountability processes.'

The fact is we do have accountability processes now. The error that occurred has been recognised by the department and acknowledged by the department. The department has taken responsibility for it. Unlike the former government, when occasions like this arise, we say, `This is unacceptable, and we will ensure that it does not happen again.' Because of that sort of financial control—when mistakes like this occur, we fix them up immediately—we are going to have a budget surplus at the end of our term, unlike Senator O'Brien's government's record of a $10.3 billion deficit. You were handing money out without any accountability processes whatsoever. So the score is 1 to Vanstone, 0 to the opposition, and Vanstone is the clear winner of the match.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz, in future, would you please refer to the minister by her full title.
—I withdraw the term `Vanstone' and replace it with `The honourable the Minister, Senator Vanstone'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard government has had a shocking first 18 months in office. It has lost five ministers, perhaps several others will not see out the weekend, and the minister who has set the pace on incompetence and arrogance is, of course, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the minister who oversaw the Austudy fiasco that disadvantaged thousands of people; who managed to alienate everyone in the higher education sector; who led the charge in the ERC to slash her own budget at a time of rising unemployment, and then invented the Wright family in an attempt to justify her actions. This minister promoted the concept of job insecurity as a means of fixing unemployment and announced that her new policy of job creation was to look to the heavens. And now we have the South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco. The Senate should be aware that I have only listed the highlights and in five minutes I cannot possibly do justice to the absolute shambles that this minister's portfolio is.

We looked at this issue over about 10½ hours. About four of those were taken up with inane questions which had no relevance to the terms of reference that the Senate inquiry was given. That time was taken up on behalf of the government to try to obscure the real issue. When we finally got down to finding out what took place and going through the myriad of documents—we had three large three‐inch thick folders of papers setting out the obscure documentation on this matter—what did we find? Briefs that went to the minister's office, not signed off. `I've never seen them,' said the minister. The briefs that the minister had. `Oh yes, I've seen those. I think I saw them on the 12th, or maybe it was the 13th. I don't really know.' And then, `What did you do, Minister?' `I think someone asked for a brief.' `Did you follow it up?' `I think it was followed up a lot.'

BREAK.PARA: When you asked the department, the response was, `Yes. We think we remember that we were asked for a brief.' How lacking in diligence is either the minister or her office if she seriously wanted a brief from her department—she is telling us she wanted a brief from her department—and she could not get it for 11 weeks. What did she do? Did she commit one thing to paper? Did she say, `Look, I've got to have a brief. Let's get a memo out. At least get it on paper.' Not a word. What did the minister do? Eleven weeks later, when it became clear to everyone and became clear to the minister—it was clear to us beforehand—that this was a project which had `Unacceptable risk' written all over it, the minister wrote the letter to her departmental secretary and said, `Look, this is all your fault. This is not my fault. I don't want to have a part of this.'

When we go back to the first written advice that the minister owns up to having read, what do we see? This is a minister—a legally qualified person, a minister of the Crown, a cabinet minister—who has got a contract which is the subject of press speculation, that has been let to people who have a very poor financial record in terms of their corporate behaviour and their personal behaviour. This is an area where $2.2 million has been given to these people. This is an area where there is a contract, and the minister is told, effectively, `There are provisions in the contract to check where the money is, and perhaps there are provisions in the contract which allow us to monitor performance and terminate the contract.' Does the minister—this legally qualified minister of the Crown, a cabinet minister—seek legal advice? Does the minister say, `Get me an advice. Let me see what our position is.'? No; the minister did nothing.

I have to say that that inaction in itself was a gross dereliction of duty. If the minister cannot see that, what hope have we got for this minister administering a portfolio of billions of dollars? It might only be $2.2 million in her terms, but it is an important example of the incompetence of this minister, a minister lacking diligence. This minister must go and, if the Prime Minister does not seize the opportunity in a reshuffle to get rid of her, he is more foolish than I thought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —I must have been one of the few senators who were not caught up in this fiasco of a 10‐hour hearing in a fruitless chase after Senator Vanstone that took place all of yesterday and all last night into the wee small hours of the morning. But I want to speak on this motion to take note of the minister's answer because I think that the voters out there—the real people out there; the real constituents out there in the real world—must be asking themselves what we are actually doing in this place when we are taking senators away from other duties to inquire, for something like 13 hours by the time that everybody prepared for it, into what happened with this contract, when the real issue is this: what is happening with jobs; what is happening to young people in this country; what is happening to real opportunities to actually try to give them some training and to give them some opportunity to get into the work force?

SPEECH.PARA: That seems to me to be the real issue. Of course, the opposition is not at all interested in that. They are only interested to see if they can actually force the minister's resignation. Fat hope of that. It is not going to happen. She is not going to be removed. What is important and what voters are interested in, what constituents are interested in, is what is happening to real jobs.

It is interesting that nobody says that this contract, the SPCL contract, actually provided 10 weeks of training to participants. Until the end of August, 160 participants were accredited with training from the project, 150 got certificates of attainment and—I hope you on the other side like this—60 jobs have come out of this particular program. That is a significant achievement. Sure, there have been some problems with it—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha; $2.3 million worth of them.
—They have to be addressed. They are being addressed. But how can you overlook the fact that some people have actually benefited from this program and that some real jobs have emerged from it?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Conroy, you might be interested—because you were not in the Senate at this time and neither was I—to look back a little bit at Labor's record on employment. Labor destroyed 420,000 full‐time jobs during the recession we had to have. Full‐time employment fell from 6.2 million in July 1990 to 5.8 million in November 1992—313,000 men lost full‐time work and one can only wonder how many families lost their only breadwinner as a result of Labor's recession.

This is the nub: the number of young people with full‐time jobs was halved during Labor's administration. Full‐time youth employment fell by approximately 240,000 from 465,000 in June 1989 to 227,000 in March 1994. Long‐term unemployment trebled during the worst recession this country has had since the 1930s Depression. Long‐term unemployment increased from 140,000 in November 1989 to 349,000 in July 1993.

Unemployment averaged 8.7 per cent during Labor's 13 years in government. This government has only had 18 months. It has done a lot, of course, to fix the fundamentals. The effect of interest rate cuts and industrial relations changes can only assist to get the country back to work and to actually improve employment. In addition to fixing the fundamentals, the government has introduced specific employment initiatives so that there are apprenticeships and traineeships, such as in the green corps program and the work for the dole program.

The work for the dole program is important in stopping the isolation of young people. It will allow them to get some skills and relevant training to get back into the work force. Under Working Nation, which was a Labor initiative, job placement rates were less than 30 per cent. After 18 months in office, this government has actually put in place some policy initiatives and fixed the economic fundamentals so that surely we will soon see some real assistance for jobs. The attack on this particular initiative of Senator Vanstone's is entirely unjustified. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs and Minister Assisting the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the documents that are to be provided in response to a Senate return to order of 1 October 1997. This relates to Senator Kernot's motion. I seek to table them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.EMPHASIS: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion of censure of Senator Sherry in relation to his travelling allowance claims.

SPEECH.PARA: Censure motions are usually taken—it is not necessary to argue for the suspension—because all of us in this place recognise that censure is such a very important motion to be moved here. It is not moved often. In fact, I am pleased to say, it is moved rarely—only when circumstances demand it. I think this is the first occasion in 18 months in government that we have moved a censure motion. But it is important for the institution and for public confidence in the institution that honourable senators do not mislead the Senate.

What I will be putting is on the basis of what Senator Sherry said in this place yesterday. There can be no other interpretation but that he deliberately misled the Senate, and for that he should be censured. What is particularly disappointing is that he has not come clean since and given some explanation as to why he did it. It might have been that he did not read correctly the guidelines or that he was relying on information that had been provided by another party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill, you should actually be debating the reason for the suspension of standing orders, not the actual contingency matter.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Three years ago, when these debates were unlimited there were constant points of order as to relevance. We then shifted to five minutes a side basically on the agreement that we would not go to exact relevance. There is a far more liberal interpretation of relevance in the five minute speech.

INTERJECT.PARA: I just put it to you, Madam Deputy President, that we should think of that and allow Senator Hill to develop whatever line he wants to without interruption only on that basis. I know it is not in the Standing Orders but it is a sort of a tradition of this place, since we switched to that section, that you can have a five‐minute dash rather than the old half hour. I just put that to you because I helped negotiate that agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Corporate knowledge is very helpful. Thank you, Senator Ray.

—I was seeking to argue why standing orders should be suspended. The reason why they should be suspended is that the government wishes to move a motion of censure. What I was seeking to demonstrate is that there was sufficient material to justify that motion of censure, and that is why standing orders should be suspended. The justification, the material, is on the record and was put down here by Senator Sherry at lunchtime yesterday when he said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I assert to the Senate that each of my Hobart TA claims meets the requirements as specified in the Department of Administrative Services guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: That is fine. He is certainly entitled to assert that, and he is entitled to prove that if he wishes. But he then went on to say:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The DAS guidelines set rates for capital city claims.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, linking the two together, his claims for Hobart TA met the guidelines as stated by the DAS guidelines set rates for capital city claims, and the boundaries of the capital city are as determined by the ABS. What I wish to assert, if we get to a substantive debate on this matter, is that the DAS guidelines do not state any such things.

BREAK.PARA: The DAS guidelines certainly do give a definition of `capital city' in relation to car transport but, in the way that the DAS guidelines are constructed, it has nothing to do with travel allowance claims whatsoever. On that basis, therefore, I put to the Senate that standing orders should be suspended and that the Senate should debate the substantive motion that Senator Sherry, in these circumstances, be censured.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What an extraordinary situation. Senator Hill, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, could speak for only 3½ minutes to justify the case for the suspension of standing orders. I suspect that is a record for this chamber. The Leader of the Government in the Senate could not even go the full five minutes to try to justify this flimsiest of cases.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me make it very clear what the circumstances are in relation to this proposition that is before the chamber. The government wants to suspend standing orders because Senator Sherry allegedly deliberately misled the Senate in relation to a definition of `capital city'. I want to explain very briefly the circumstances here and, take it or leave it, it might just be interesting to some senators—there does not appear to be much interest in the debate.

Senator Sherry, quite properly, thought—in fact, it was a staff member—that he had better establish what the definition was. There is a question about this. You ought to try this yourselves. Go back to your office, turn on your computer and type in the words `capital city'. What you will find, like I did, is that there are 22 hits. Then you scroll through until you get to `definition'. Hit the print button. What comes out? A document which says `definitions'. I will table that document, Madam Deputy President. What happens when you do that? It does not print out the whole of the document contextually.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you say it is wrong—that's all you have to say.

—This is the truth of the matter. It does not actually print out: `car transport and entitlements'. I have to say that that is the only definition that exists in the Department of Administrative Services for capital city. It is the only definition that DAS has. There is no definition in the remuneration tribunal, and there are no guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: It was laughed at in question time by the government, but the truth of the matter is, as far as I know, that the only definition that defines capital city that is enshrined in Commonwealth legislation is in section 282 of the Telecommunications Act 1997.
Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston laughs but, of course, he is responsible for administering that act of parliament. So I suggest you go to your offices, you do precisely that and then you might understand why this occurred. But this is the same government that did not come in here when they had Mr Sharp resign for rorting. Where was the suspension of standing orders and censure there? Where was the condemnation there? When Mr McGauran had to resign for deliberately rorting his travel entitlements there was no action from Senator Hill or the government in this chamber—nothing at all. When Mr Jull deliberately misled the parliament and deliberately covered up the rorting of government ministers while trying to, at the same time, very quickly say that a few members of the Labor Party had to pay back travel allowances that had been legally claimed, was there any move by this mob against him? Not at all.

SPEECH.PARA: When Mr Morris and Ms McKenna had to resign because the Prime Minister had to take a hit in the cover‐up in his own office, was there any word from any of this mob here? Not at all. When Ms Bisshop had to resign or when Mr Semmens was stood aside, pushed into another job, did you say anything about that? No, there was nothing from any of you.

We have a censure motion proposed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate on Senator Sherry. There was not a word about these other circumstances where government members have been found to have deliberately rorted their entitlements and where other government ministers have deliberately covered it up. What a double standard! What hypocrisy from the government. This suspension of standing orders should be opposed. This suspension should be defeated. Let us get on with the business of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an extraordinary performance. Yesterday Senator Sherry said:

PARA.EMPHASIS: I assert to the Senate that each one of my Hobart TA claims meets the requirements as specified in the Department of Administrative Services guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say that the guidelines set rates for capital city claims. What we have just been told by Senator Faulkner is that he now realises that what has been on the public record is totally and utterly misleading. They somehow claim that if you press the wrong button, you do not find out what the DAS guidelines are or whether there are any DAS guidelines.

In other words, you have Senator Ray getting up here and saying, `You are absolutely wrong; you don't understand. How could you possibly believe what you are saying when the DAS guidelines say the following? How could Ruddock and Kemp be so ignorant of the fact when quoting the ABS definition?' In other words, all of that is not operative any more because now we are told that, in fact, they got it wrong.

If they got it wrong and Senator Sherry got it wrong because he did not even bother to find out whether there were any DAS guidelines in relation to TA, Senator Sherry's statement of yesterday is manifestly incorrect. Senator Faulkner has just pleaded guilty on his behalf, which immediately raises the question of when Senator Sherry first knew about this and why he did not immediately come into this chamber and explain himself. Once again, he is totally contemptuous of the processes of the parliament.

A press release was put out by Mr Ruddock. Your attention has been well and truly drawn to this. Presumably, you are the one who gave the information to Mr Beazley. You are the one who gave the information to Senator Ray. You are the one who got it fundamentally wrong. No-one would ever have known that it was wrong until we actually went back to the source and did the very thing Senator Ray said. He said, `Why don't you go back and check the DAS guidelines?' We have and there aren't any. Yet Senator Ray gets up and says that anyone who disagreed with him is completely wrong. You now come in here and admit that there are no such rules that any capital city definition applies to car allowances. Why on earth you would not go back and check defies belief.

The much more important and much more serious question is: when did you find out that you were wrong? Why did you not get up and make a statement? You have had all morning. You had an opportunity in taking note of answers to get up and explain yourself. You simply think, as you tried to do on the Mike Jeffreys show, that you can talk all this away and pretend it is another trivial little political exercise.

The fact is that this is a very serious issue because you had the opportunity to state your position. You put it on the record yesterday and hoped no-one would notice. Well, of course, they have noticed. You have been absolutely exposed. Your explanation is fundamentally wrong and Senator Faulkner has now conceded that.

I will be very interested to hear Senator Sherry's explanation on this matter. Presumably, he is now going to say that he did not bother to make any inquiries. We have not yet heard whether the so-called confirmation from DAS three and a half years ago resulted in any written documentation—in other words, whether any staff member or you took a file note, whether there is anything in DAS recording any such matter, whether you have any letter to that effect or whether you are simply verballing DAS.

In other words, you have not given any evidence at all that you made any attempt to find out what the DAS rules are in relation to TA. You simply come in here and blithely assert that there are guidelines that get you off the hook because they give this tortuous definition that includes Opossum Bay when you and I know full well that Opossum Bay has to be one of the sleepiest hollows in Australia. It has nothing at all to do with a capital city.

It is the most extraordinary contorted exercise to try to claim that you are entitled to the sort of money you have claimed. You chalk up about $20,000 in Comcar just to get there and back when you could easily have stayed in Hobart. But you were not prepared to pay for that. No, you had to travel all that distance for hours and hours simply to find rent free accommodation. To cover all that up, you blithely get up and assert that there are DAS guidelines when there are not. I want to know what your explanation is because you have not given one as yet. Unless you do, you deserve not only to be censured by this parliament but you ought to do the decent thing and fall on your sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it interesting that the previous speaker, Senator Alston, claimed 38 nights in Sydney over 11 months at $12,200, which is a much higher average than Senator Sherry's claim?
—He lives in Melbourne.

—Senator McGauran reminds me that Senator Alston lives in Melbourne. We know someone else who lives in Melbourne as well, Senator McGauran. The reasons for this censure motion are patently clear. John Sharp had to pay back 47 days out of 144, but no-one has gone to his claims prior to the election, where he is going to have to pay back a lot more. Mr McGauran ran up the white flag after only three questions in the House of Representatives. He knew what was in his own background. Mr Jull got sacked for conspiring to cover up the secret repayments. That is what this motion is really about. Mr Morris, the eminence grise of the Liberal Party, got sacked for covering it up, so did one of the more junior officers. I feel sorry for her.

SPEECH.PARA: When they talk about greed on this side, you will not hear any of them comment on Mr Scott, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. In the first 285 days of government, he claimed 80 per cent of nights on travel allowance, spent another nine days overseas and has had to repay two so far. They will not tell you about that. They will not tell you about the Liberal senator who used to jump on the red‐eye special, land at Melbourne airport, sleep on the benches there and claim $320 a night. They will not tell you about the two Liberal senators taking expensive charter flights for their pre-selection cronies, running them all around Western Australia. They will not tell us who has repaid the various Cabcharge accounts over the last few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I submit that Senator Ray's original proposition that there ought to be a degree of freedom allowed in canvassing this matter is appropriate. But what is happening now is that Senator Ray is absolutely refusing to address the central issue which affects him—that is, that he misled the Senate yesterday in support of Senator Sherry. He is not in the slightest addressing that issue. That is what ought to be faced up to here, not a whole tirade of abuse about irrelevancies. Senator Ray, on the strength of what Senator Faulkner has said, has the same explanation facing him. Unless Senator Ray addresses that, he ought to be completely out of order.

—Madam Deputy President, I want to speak to the same point of order. There has been a longstanding tradition for a number of years now—it certainly has been in place throughout the life of the last parliament and throughout this one—that, in relation to a suspension of standing orders motion, any senator addressing the chair has a capacity not just to argue urgency but to argue matters that go to more the substance of the motion and matters that otherwise would be canvassed in debate if the suspension were successful. Madam Deputy President, when you ruled that Senator Hill, when he was on his feet, perhaps should contain himself, you sought a very quick and appropriate response—
—What is your submission?
—Shut up.
—Senator Faulkner, that is unnecessary.

—Well, Madam Deputy President, have I got the floor? You sought a quick and appropriate response to ensure that the conventions of this place that have been in operation now for a number of years were adhered to. Madam Deputy President, you cannot have one rule for government speakers and one rule for opposition speakers. Senator Alston takes a point of order not because he believes there is a procedural issue here but because he does not like what Senator Ray has said. I ask you to rule consistently, as you did in relation to the procedural point taken during Senator Hill's speech. What is good for the goose is good for the gander. And you are the goose, Senator Alston.

—Madam Deputy President, I wish to speak to the point of order. Senator Faulkner is absolutely right: the convention in this place has been that you are able to roll into a five‐minute speech relating to urgency the substance of the motion before the chair. The motion before the chair relates to Senator Sherry's misleading of the Senate yesterday. Senator Ray has not said one word about that. He has talked about Mr McGauran, Mr Scott—everything under the sun—when the substantive issue here directly affects Senator Ray himself because he was a party to Senator Sherry's performance of yesterday. Senator Ray has misled the Senate on the basis of Senator Faulkner's admission of today. Therefore, he ought to be required to address either the substance of it or the urgency of it, but not to totally ignore each of those two matters and talk about other things.

—Madam Deputy President, I want to speak to the point of order. The point of order that has been raised by Senator Alston is due to Senator Alston's sensitivity because he does not like what he is hearing in this debate.
—You can't reflect on my motives.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: COOK

TALK.START.PARA: —I just have. He wishes to close down the debate because the argument does not suit the case of the government. It is unfortunate that the argument does not suit the case of the government, but the argument happens to be true and the government is just going to have to suit itself to that fact.

INTERJECT.PARA: What we have here is a case of duplicitous standards as far as the government is concerned. Every day during question time we have addressed to the chair questions of relevance, and we have the chair rule that ministers are able to canvass a wide range of things, whether or not they have anything at all to do with the questions specifically asked of them.

Today in question time Senator Kemp declined to answer a question and talked about irrelevant trivialities. The point is that that is acceptable as far as the chair is concerned. If you apply the government standards to this debate, then not only are we tightly to the point and specific and relevant, but also there is a fair bit of scope to canvass even more widely, if we wish to, than we are in fact canvassing. I suggest to you, Madam Deputy President, that the appropriate ruling in this case is to sit down the government, overrule their point of order and enable Senator Ray to continue his speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate has ranged very widely. There is no point of order. However, we are debating the suspension of standing orders, and I am sure Senator Ray is going to be quite relevant and germane to the issue.

—Madam Deputy President, I am not ready to take this urgency motion, because I have been so distracted by other issues. Let me let you know my distractions as to why I cannot vote for this urgency motion. The thing that has distracted me the most is what I call the Sydney mob. We heard from one before. Senator Richard Alston, a friend of Kerry Packer, visited Sydney 38 times for $12,200—more times than Senator Sherry's average in Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: Next up is the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey. Remember he lives only up the road. He has been to Sydney 41 times in 11 months at a higher figure. The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, Mr Fischer, has been to Sydney 46 times in 11 months, despite being overseas 15 times for 87 days in that period. Senator Brownhill has been to Sydney on 48 occasions for over $15,000.

When Mr Costello says that he is in awe of Senator Sherry, he must be stunned by his Sydney mob colleagues. I can understand though that, because they have visited Sydney so often, they cannot remember when they were there. Senator Hill is smiling. Don't you remember being there on New Year's Day 1996 for five days for $1,500? What were you doing, Senator Hill, when you put $1,500 in your kick from New Year's Day on? You cannot even remember where you stayed. You can remember to move an urgency motion, but you do not know where you have stayed in the last three to four years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. What has this conceivably got to do with either the urgency or the substance of the motion?

—On that point of order: this is a motion to suspend standing orders in order to debate a matter of urgency. I am trying to indicate to the Senate why I have been so distracted that I cannot vote for this as an urgent matter at the moment. I have been so distracted, upset and distraught by the resignations of three ministers, two prime ministerial staffers and an unfortunate person in PM&C—who should never have resigned—that I have had to open up my heart to the Senate to tell them what is worrying me and why I cannot vote for this urgency motion. That is my attitude on the point of order.
—There is no point of order. Please continue.

—The final point I wanted to make is that this group over here says, `Well, you shouldn't claim travel allowance where there is no expenditure involved. Yet we suspect that at least two of our colleagues whip down to Sydney and stay at properties that they own and pocket the $320 per night. We do not say it happens for sure, but we are waiting on them to respond. They can check the Comcar records themselves through their minister to find out whether the car ever dropped either of them off at night at that particular place and picked them up the next morning. We will let them go away and do that.'

SPEECH.PARA: And they talk about quantum! Their own Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), in exactly the same period as that covering Senator Nick Sherry, claimed 161 days in Sydney—Senator Sherry claimed 143 days in Hobart. Why don't they move an urgency motion to have a full examination of Mr Tim Fischer's claims and see what that shows over the same period of time? This is just another opportunistic, worthless ambush that Senator Hill has trotted in here today. Basically, it is their Ardennes offensive after D‐day. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —This makes me sick. As a younger member of the Senate said to me a while ago, `Isn't this awful?' It is turning into a self‐indulgent exercise in mutually assured destruction.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are going to spend the rest of the afternoon in a debate on who has been the worst in the excesses of abuse of travelling allowances and other allowances, knowing that that is not going to achieve any return to the Australian public, we are simply going to waste the Australian public's time. A whole range of issues on the Notice Paper want attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order. Madam Deputy President, could I inquire as to why you have not followed the procedure of calling one from that side of the chamber and one from this side? Senator Kemp clearly stood and was on his feet and you called Senator Brown after Senator Ray.
—I am sorry, Senator Macdonald, but when—
—May I address Senator Macdonald's point of order: I think it is spurious—
—Order! Senator Alston!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston is right for once. You have got to get it right every now and again, Senator Alston, because it is an important issue. We know that poor old Senator Ian Macdonald is a long way behind the game. Senator Brown has been on his feet now for over one minute, and poor old Senator Macdonald was late to the barricades as usual. He was late getting in, late becoming a parliamentary secretary—but pretty early in getting dumped from the shadow cabinet.

INTERJECT.PARA: Madam Deputy President, I am speaking to the point of order because I am very interested in the point that Senator Macdonald raises, and I would like to ask you to give this consideration: if Senator Macdonald had really been serious about taking a procedural point, surely he would have taken the point when you gave the call to Senator Brown. Even Senator Brown would have to acknowledge that. One minute later some dope on that side gets up and takes a point of order! Oh, what a bright spark you are, Senator Macdonald! Oh, what a procedural genius you really are!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Madam Deputy President, the point I am making to you is that I do not think Senator Macdonald is really serious, and I am sure you would agree with me. I do not believe that Senator Macdonald can seriously take a point of order about your giving a call to a senator who stands on his feet in accordance with the standing orders of the Senate—and one minute later some absolute drongo from the government takes a point of order! I ask you to rule the point of order out of order.
—Order! I would like to do some ruling here. Senator Faulkner, I would like you to speak with more respect about the senators opposite you.
—Absolutely not!
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Madam Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I direct your attention to standing order 203. Senator Faulkner has flouted your ruling in the grossest possible way. You ought to name him. You ought to invite him to explain how he can possibly treat you in the way he just did. You told him that you expected him to give more respect to the chair and he said, `No chance,' and walked away from you. You ought to require him to apologise immediately or throw him out.

—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President: we have yet another example of Senator Alston misleading the Senate. I would never treat the chair with contempt, but I deliberately treat the government with contempt. What I will not do is take someone like Senator Alston seriously. He knows I did not say that. I can assure you, Madam Deputy President, that I do not treat you or any other presiding officer with contempt, nor would I, but I reserve my right to treat the government as they deserve to be treated.
—Senator Faulkner, I request that you use parliamentary language when you are referring to the members of the government. I was seeking for you to actually correct and withdraw your language.
—Madam Deputy President, if I have used unparliamentary language, I withdraw it.
—Thank you. Order! I am going to rule on the previous point of order and say that, when the member speaking from my left had finished speaking, I looked to my right and saw nobody standing. I then—
—Oh, that's—
—Senator Ferris, please stand and withdraw that reflection.
—I withdraw.

—I looked to my right and I saw nobody. However, I then looked to my left and saw Senator Brown. I called Senator Brown. It is my intention now, after Senator Brown has completed his comments, to look to the right again to see if somebody is standing. Before people jump to conclusions about how I am going to make the next call, I ask them to let me give the call first. I now call on Senator Brown to resume his comments.
—Thank you, Madam Deputy President—

—On the point of order, Madam Deputy President, I noticed that you moved with great speed on Senator Ferris. I was intrigued that during the diatribe from Senator Faulkner you constantly tried to correct him and he walked all over you; he completely ignored you.
—Senator Kemp—

—That is what he did—he completely ignored you. I can assure you that the tape of the proceedings will show that. And then he stormed off. I put it to you that you had a difficult time there. I did not stand up and make a fuss about your call. You actually turned to me and said, `I am sorry.' I rose to my feet. I do not know whether you were distracted. You chose Senator Brown. You then came back to me and you said, `I am sorry.' The Hansard will show that. I did not choose to make a fuss about it because I thought you were put in an awkward position. On the other hand, your party leader then proceeded to treat you with utter contempt, in my view. The Hansard will show that you desperately tried to bring him to order and that he walked all over you. I put it to you: we will give you support, but you have got to make sure it is even-handed on both sides of the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: RAY

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Senator Kemp described Senator Faulkner as storming out of the chamber. We have an afternoon tea going on; he came out for a cup of tea. For heaven's sake! If you cannot farewell one of your former senators even during a censure debate it is very poor.

INTERJECT.PARA: The equally valid point that coalition senators have raised—that it was their turn to get the call—also leaves us in a very substantially reduced position because that means that Senator Kemp will get the last drop. That is, they get to move it first and then they get to wind it up. These things are always balanced. Whoever goes first has to have the thread of the final speaker summing up. We are massively disadvantaged on this side of the chamber by only having two speakers in a debate that seeks to suspend—

TALK.START.PARA: —You only have 20 senators; we have 30 senators.

—We are back to the proportionality argument, are we? You might explain why you have rigged the delegation to the constitutional convention, which is not at all proportional. Leaving that aside, this is also a matter not to be ruled on today but taken in the long term. If these things go in order, there is a certain checks and balances in the system. That is, those who moved the suspension of standing orders have the advantage of going first and those who defend the thing have the advantage of summing up and going last in the 30 minutes, six speakers, five per side.
—Order! I call Senator Brown.

—There are on the Notice Paper matters to do with education, the economy, employment, the environment, health, international relations and human rights, which we should be dealing with.
