Instead of that, this chamber is becoming bogged down in a bear pit procedure where members are trying to score off each other at the expense of the Australian people, who I suggest have had enough of the behaviour that is occurring over this issue. I know I am going to cop it, particularly from some of the longest serving and self-serving members of this place.
—Senator Brown, will you please withdraw that reflection upon senators?

—I am quite happy to—from some of the longest serving members of this place, who are on very brittle ground as far as the travel allowance scandal is concerned. What we should have here this afternoon is either a move from the government for an inquiry into the whole affair or, better still, a remedy so that it does not become self-replicating. One of the problems is that this sort of affair, which lowers faith in democracy and in the heart of the democratic system which is our parliament, tends to become self- replicating. After all, what decent, honest, aspiring, faithful person would want to get into politics—
—You did!

—I thank you for that—with this behaviour daily taking up the media when there are much more important things that we as a parliament should be dealing with. If this was a move by the government to establish an independent arbiter to ensure that the sorts of events we have heard about in recent weeks are not replicated, to ensure that the public could have faith not only that allowances were being used properly in the future but also that those allowances were being vetted, and to ensure that members themselves could get past the anxiety of all the grey areas because somebody with commonsense could arbitrate on the matter of travel allowances, then that would be a positive move. Instead, we have a motion to dock a senator who has come in with a definition of what a capital city is. It is not even a debate about how we can remedy the excesses of the travel allowance episode in the interests of the Australian public. It is bogged down in a petty, political point scoring exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: If we support this motion, tempted as we might be to do so, hours of this last day of sitting are going to be taken up on a debate which is going to be divided on party lines at the end of the day and the business of the parliament, the business of the nation, is going to be lost because of that political point scoring. I for one will not stand for it. It is time that we got an approach from both sides that will put this nasty, politically degrading episode behind us and get us on to more constructive ways for the future—not only constructive for the nation but a more constructive way for us to behave and, therefore, to represent the aspirations of the nation that this place should be a house of energy, a parliament of energy, acting in the people's interests and not being seen as self-serving, as sadly it has been seen in recent weeks. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We are all gathered here, obviously, for Senator Quirke's first speech, which was due some minutes ago now. When are we bringing that on?

—So we are arguing about the suspension of standing orders for a 10 minute debate, are we? A whole range of people are waiting to hear Senator Quirke speak, and he was due on some minutes ago. So we have just pushed that aside, have we?
—The order of the Senate is `not later than 4.30 p.m'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose Senator Brown has to work out whether he is prepared to support a motion to censure an individual who has rorted the system, who has misled the parliament. Senator Brown, that is the issue that you are faced with. Senator Brown has to go back to his home state, and the issue for him will be: did he believe that Senator Sherry was quite entitled to claim all those nights in Hobart when he was staying at Opossum Bay? SPEECH.SPEAKER: Quirke, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Madam Deputy President. It is a bit of a hard act to follow, but I will see what I can do. It is a great honour that I rise in this place here today to address all of you; it is a great honour that I represent the state of South Australia; and it is a great honour that I represent the Australian Labor Party in this very important chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Just by way of background, some 37 or so years ago, my family came to this country. I want to make that one of the first points here because much has been said in the course of this year about migration to Australia. Much has been made of political points about migration. There are a number of senators in here who I am sure were born overseas like me.

My father and mother came here for a better life in 1959, and they paid the statutory fee of 10 quid. They were known—amongst other things—as 10‐quid tourists. Some years ago when I was doorknocking in my former state Labor electorate and somebody offered me the 10 quid to go home when I made that point, I pointed out that, unfortunately for them, they got me for nothing. In fact, my father and mother had to pay the 10 quid. I came absolutely free and I have no intentions of leaving.

My family came to Australia and saw this as their home. They never referred to the old country as home; they never saw it that way. They transported themselves and their lives, and were working members of this community for the whole of their lives. Unfortunately, they are not here with us today. It is a great pity that that is the case. They were literally working-class people, of largely Irish stock, who had a life in England for some years before they came here to Australia. I think it would have been nice if they could have been here today to see that, here in Australia, we have a society where people can get into forums such as this. It is on that point that I want to turn now to the Australian Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: The ALP has been my life for many years. I added it up the other day and I think I have been to about 29 conferences. I cannot remember how many campaigns I have been to and I cannot remember all of the other activities that I have been involved in—but it is a large part of my life and that of my family. I am grateful in particular to the South Australian Labor Party who gave me preselection for a state seat in South Australia, which I represented for two parliaments and have only recently left, and who then gave me preselection for the Australian Senate.

I want to single out our national secretary, Gary Gray, who is a long‐term friend of mine, for all of the support, loyalty and friendship that he has given me over those years. Similarly, I wish to point out that Don Farrell from the SDA in South Australia has, I am pleased to say, been a great friend of mine over many years. Don, I owe you a great deal and I will constantly be in your debt. There are other people I wish to mention here this afternoon. Terry Cameron is the former state secretary and now a member of the Legislative Council of South Australia. Terry and I have had many years together in political life. Indeed, it is rather a shame that we are now separated because we sit in different parliaments but I am sure that over many years we will still be very close friends.

Robert Ray is one of those people whom you remember, for all sorts of reasons, and he has been a great friend of mine. I want to thank him for his mateship and his support over many years. Dominic Foreman has, as we have heard today, come back to this chamber. He is only here for a short time. I am glad that he is in the audience now so that I can make some of the comments that I made the other night in the valedictory for Dominic. I owe Dominic a great deal. When he had his farewell down in his electorate office some weeks ago there were a large number of people there who had got their political start with encouragement from Dominic.

Dominic is an intensely private man. I think everybody in here knows that. The one great thing about Dominic is that he encouraged others—not one or two, but lots of them. I was particularly pleased to see at his farewell down at the electorate office in Glenelg a large number of young Labor members whom Dominic had supported over many years. Naturally, I hope he and his wife, Shirley, have a long and very happy retirement.

Dominic stayed on here longer than I think he would have liked to have done. That is largely my fault because once I, as a serving state MP, gained preselection for this particular position, Dominic wanted to ensure that the taxpayers of South Australia did not have to pay the fee for an unnecessary by-election. Where that is concerned I think it is for us to say thank you to him on behalf of those taxpayers.

On the subject of smooth transitions, I also want to thank the South Australian government. Before my colleagues get worried, I will not be doing it again. But at least in this instance they recognised the necessity to ensure that we had a full Senate representation, and they did not make that an issue during the election campaign. The South Australian Attorney‐General, Trevor Griffin, did his utmost—and certainly succeeded—to ensure that the vacancy created here was filled within something like 72 hours.

I am proud to say that my wife, Davina, and my four children, Alexander, Liam, Daniel and Kristian, have given me full support. We had many discussions about whether it was a wise idea for me as a father of four children, particularly young children, to be coming over here, with all of the necessary travel demands in this job. But they are all very happy for me to come and sit in this place. They understand the honour of it. By the way, that was the gang that was here last week. The baby found it very hard to restrain himself up there in the gallery. It is a standing joke that he always does that, so I apologise to the Senate. I know that next time I bring him he will probably do exactly the same.

Australia as a nation has made a number of great strides since World War II. One of those strides is, as we were saying before, migration and the number of migrants who have come to this country and enriched the social fabric. I want to make it absolutely crystal clear here where I stand on this issue. It is essential that we understand that those migrants who have come here, all of whom in my view have made an enormous success of their contribution to this country, have brought some parts of their own culture and they have accepted our ways of life here. They have made contemporary Australia what it is today and it is something that we can be proud of.

We have seen the various waves of migration. Some 37 years ago it was predominantly Anglo‐Saxon, Italian and Greek. Today we have a large number of Asian migrants who have come to this country. I was recently driving around the suburbs of one of the major cities in this country and it occurred to me how much this country has changed in the last 30 or so years. I think it has changed very much for the better.

I represent the state of South Australia, which is a small regional economy. Some points need to be made about that. One of the great things about South Australia is its lifestyle. One of the problems that we have experienced, particularly over the last 20 to 30 years, is that our share of the national cake is declining. We are seeing head offices move to other states. We have seen our share of the population shrink from 10 per cent to a current figure of 8.2 per cent, and there are projections that it will go down possibly as low as six per cent in the not too far distant future. Areas such as South Australia, and Adelaide in particular, where some four‐fifths of the population live, need special policies.

This is not a speech of special pleading for my home state, because I do not believe that what South Australia needs is welfare. I do not believe it needs the welfare mentality. What it needs, and what our party is committed to, is a series of policies which will underpin some of the great advantages that this state has. It is one of the cheapest, cost‐effective states in Australia within which to set up business. It has a great education system. It has a good, cheap, friendly lifestyle that has been commented on by many people around Australia.

What we need to do for regional economies such as South Australia and the many others around this great nation is to understand that their special needs are something that we have to legislate for in this place and the other place. We need to encourage investment and diversity not only in South Australia but also in other regions.

I want to make a couple of other comments about the South Australia that I know. During debate in here the other day one senator—and now is not the time to go into who it was—made the comment, when speaking of the submarine project, that it was a good example of the pork barrel. I will not take that debate up here now with the good senator, but I will make a couple of points about it.

South Australia has done an excellent job with the submarine project. That project has my full support because I recognise that the Australian Navy will only have a blue water capacity if we have an effective arm in the submarine service. We cannot afford the items of military hardware which other countries can deploy: large aircraft carriers and a number of surface ships which can defend themselves at sea and constitute an effective striking force. For all of my life—and that, I suspect, of my children—the submarine force will be the principal striking force for the Royal Australian Navy.

At the end of the day the submarine project has been done well in South Australia. I am sure that there are many people who will argue that we will need more submarines. That is an argument I am not going to get into here now, but I think South Australia does a great job with all its defence contracts and all its work. It is essential that we—here and in the other place—understand that, for defence preparedness in this country, we must identify and develop our defence related industries, because this is a changing world. It has changed dramatically in the last nine years or so, and I think it has become a much less safe world. I will have more to say about that when the appropriate debates come up.

I think it would be inappropriate for me not to mention here that I am a member of a trade union. I have been a member of a trade union for many years and I will continue to be a member of a trade union. My father instilled a number of things in me. One was never to gamble and the other was to become a member of the union. My mother was quite happy for me to be in a union but she had the opposite view on gambling—she used to like putting a few bob on the gee‐gees. At the end of the day my father won out in both those instances. One of the things he was most proud of was his union ticket, which he had until the day he retired.

I make no apology that we on this side of the chamber are supporting the trade unions. We understand that they have played a historic role not only in Australia but in other Western democracies. Indeed, it is interesting to see the role that they are now playing in the emerging economies of the world. They are fighting not only for industrial rights but for political rights as well, as they did—traditionally and historically—both here in Australia and in Britain.

There are a number of other issues which, if I had the time, I would discuss. One of those is the very important question—one of the most significant before us today—of global warming. When there is such a world of opportunity out there for us to understand that targeted greenhouse reductions are absolutely essential, I cannot understand how the government has got itself into the corner it is in. Indeed, even if we do not go down the targeted greenhouse reduction road, I suspect the rest of the world will.

Before everybody here accuses me of being a total greenie, I should also make it crystal clear that, although I am one on all these sorts of issues, I believe that nuclear energy also has a place in the reduction of carbon emissions.
Government senators interjecting—Ooh!

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that would get some sort of response and I make no apology for the fact that I believe that the question of alternative technologies—including the better burning of coal, the solar power question and also that of nuclear energy for those societies which have made the decision to go down that road—is one that we are going to have to address in the next 20 years or so. I believe we are on the wrong track as a nation in what we are doing so far in terms of arguing against carbon emissions.

BREAK.PARA: Not so long ago the country of Australia that I grew up in rarely saw Labor govern ments. I remember very well the great victory in 1972. I remember the one in 1983 even better. Sadly, today my party is out of government everywhere except in one state. We will be working on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes, with concern:

PARA.TAB: (i) the Government's inability to reduce the unemployment figure of 8.7 per cent, and
(ii) the decrease of Australian workers' confidence in the labour market, evident in the participation rate of 62.9 per cent, the lowest in 3 years;

SPEECH.PARA: (b) rejects the comments by the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) that Australia needed a freer labour market and lessened job security to reduce unemployment; and
(c) calls on the Government to reverse its low skilled, low wage, low job security approach and implement a policy direction that provides genuine jobs and job security for Australians.

As I am the first person to speak so soon after Senator Quirke's first speech, I would like to congratulate him very much on what I thought was an excellent first speech. I think you can certainly tell that he was an apt and able state politician and parliamentarian. Welcome to the Senate, Senator Quirke, and congratulations on your first speech.

This general business motion seeks to highlight the parlous situation with regard to unemployment in Australia. It highlights that we still have an unemployment rate of 8.7 per cent. It highlights that in fact the Australian workers' confidence in the labour market, which is evidenced in the participation rate of 62.9 per cent, is the lowest in three years. We reject utterly the comments by Senator Vanstone that Australia needs a freer labour market and lessened job security to reduce unemployment. We also call on the government to reverse what is clearly a low skill, low wage, low job security approach and actually provide some direction that provides security for Australians.

BREAK.PARA: Let us have a look at what the current situation is with regard to unemployment in this country. As the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, herself put it, it is flat. I think that Senator Vanstone, uncharacteristically, was understating the difficulty when she said it was flat, but it is flat, stagnant and going down at 8.7 per cent. What was unemployment when the Prime Minister, John Howard, first came to office? It was 8.4 per cent. So we have actually had an increase of 0.3 per cent in the term of this government. The participation rate, as I indicated before, is currently at 62.9 per cent, which is the lowest in three years. It is a drop of a full percentage point. So people are dropping out of the labour market. That means that over the last year close to 150,000 people have dropped out of the labour market; they have just given up and dropped out.

Long‐term unemployment has reached a 28‐month high and is now at 247,700—the highest since April 1995. Since the first Howard budget in August 1996, we have seen 60,000 full‐time jobs gone—lost, disappeared. That is 60,000 full‐time jobs gone. We have lost 38,200 jobs in one month alone, which was August 1997, this year. Of this figure, 37,500 were full‐time jobs. And, for the first time ever in Australia's history, in the last month we had negative growth in employment without there being a recession. This is a time when the government says that the economic fundamentals are right. Why is it then that, for the first time in our history outside a recession, in the last month we had negative employment growth? You have got growth above the line and you have got the unemployment rate below the line, negative. That is the situation we are currently faced with. This is appalling. This is a crisis, and this is something that I think Senator Vanstone has failed utterly to address.

Let us turn to some of Senator Vanstone's more quotable quotes, including her most recent and, might I suggest, ill‐fated excursions into industry relations. As people in this chamber would be aware, industry relations is something we know quite a lot about; in fact, members opposite have often pointed this out. Industry relations is one of our areas, amongst many others. Unfortunately, it is not one of Senator Vanstone's areas. When she, I thought quite stupidly, commenced her excursion into industry relations the other day in the Senate, she actually talked about the unfair dismissal provisions. I was unable, for various reasons, to respond on that occasion, so I would like now to make the point I would have made then. Senator Vanstone repeatedly in question time yesterday said, `We have to reform your unfair dismissal laws; we have got to get rid of your unfair dismissal laws; we have got to substantially reduce the impact of your unfair dismissal laws.'

What I say to Senator Vanstone is: get with it. This government actually completely overhauled the industrial relations system recently. That came into effect on 1 January this year. What this government is talking about with regard to unfair dismissal is not our unfair dismissal laws; it is her unfair dismissal laws. That is what she is talking about with regard to amendment. For goodness sake, having commenced an ill‐fated excursion into industrial relations, can't the employment minister get her facts right? It is not our unfair dismissal laws; it is the government's unfair dismissal laws. Incidentally, at the time the government did not talk about an exemption with regard to small business, the impact of which will be that one‐third of the Australian work force will have no protection whatsoever. And Senator Vanstone talks about lessened job security. I can tell you that that is precisely what one‐third of Australian workers are going to get if the government's unfair dismissal laws are amended.

Let us look at this. The Workplace Relations Act has only been in since 1 January and already the government is saying it is not working with regard to unfair dismissal and it is seeking an exemption for small business. The government is not even prepared to give its own provisions time to work. The government is not even prepared to say to Senator Vanstone, `Hang on there. Before you start making stupid comments on industrial relations, let's give the new act time to work.' No, we have got Senator Vanstone, fresh from a labour ministers conference, coming back full of energy and going into an area that she knows nothing about.

Let us come to her own areas. I do not think Senator Vanstone knows very much about her own areas either. Let us look again at some of her more quotable quotes, and there are many. I have to say I had to go through and pick some personal favourites because there are many. Some of them, incidentally, I will give, to use one of her phrases, a big tick to, because on some of them she actually told the truth. Let us go through them. On the 7.30 Report last year she said:
If we can't get unemployment below 8 per cent—
this is the government—
we don't deserve to get re‐elected.
Correct. A big tick for telling the truth there. What is unemployment at the moment: 8.7 per cent.

With the effluxion of time, Senator Vanstone obviously realised that perhaps this comment was not in the best interests of her government and all of a sudden we changed to `We will try very hard and we are sure that the electorate, come election time, will give us a big tick for effort'. I doubt whether it will give the government a big tick for effort. Even if it did give the government a big tick, I doubt whether that would be translated into a vote. If the government does not get unemployment below eight per cent, in line with the comments made by Senator Vanstone on the 7.30 Report last year, it will not be re‐elected. That is the reality.
Senator O'Brien interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. Thank you, Senator O'Brien. Let me go to some of the most recent quotable quotes. Consider this one:

BREAK.PARA: You have to have, it might be described as, lessened job security. It's not a message everyone wants to hear.

It is not a message that Senator Vanstone wanted anybody to hear, because she—out of her own mouth the other day—said that she and a member of her staff had taped the proceedings of a CEDA dinner. She said to me—somewhat facetiously, I presume—across the chamber, `Would you like a tape?' I said quite genuinely that I would like a copy of the tape. She said, `You can't have it. Senator, I did say that but you have to understand that it is in relation to the context. I was misquoted. The people were ill‐informed. Okay, I did say this, but in the broader context. If you were to see it, you would understand that I was misquoted.' Thank you, Senator Vanstone, but given your record I doubt whether we can take your word for it. So the invitation is open from the opposition. We are very happy to have the tape and it would expedite matters even more, given our limited resources, if a transcript were to be provided. So I say to Senator Vanstone: please provide the tape.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hold your breath.
—I won't hold my breath, Senator O'Brien, you are right. Senator Vanstone says:

BREAK.PARA: I feel like a farmer that's watching the clouds and saying `this drought is going to break'. . . we are confident it will break—

She is talking about unemployment. When is the drought going to break? We have had this government for 18 months and we have actually had an increase in unemployment, and the situation is getting rapidly worse.

We move to the next quotable quote from Senator Vanstone. She said that the government's spending cuts were partly to blame for unemployment. Correct—a big tick for telling the truth. She is absolutely right. The slash and burn mentality of this government has contributed massively to the unemployment rate and, if you ask any economist of standing, they will confirm that. You cannot slash jobs in the way that they have been slashed in the public sector without having a consequential effect on unemployment. So she is correct but, unfortunately for those people opposite, on this occasion she actually told the truth. But what happened the next day? John Howard came out and said that Senator Vanstone did say that but she was wrong—a big embarrassment for the government, but I concede that she was correct.
In question time the other day, she said:
I can confirm, as any Australian would be able to confirm for you, that the labour market remains flat.

As I said before, that is probably an understatement in Senator Vanstone's case. But on the very same day at the very same time we had, down in the House of Representatives, Peter Costello commenting. Was he saying that unemployment is flat? No, he was saying:
Employment is now on the up.
You have got Senator Vanstone in the Senate saying it is flat and Mr Costello down in the House of Representatives saying it is on the up. It is just an absolute joke. I present her next quote:
I don't enter into the business of setting targets. We've got the Budget forecasts. They're what I keep my eye on.

She wants to keep a pretty good eye on the budget forecasts because the budget forecast for unemployment for this financial year is 8.25 per cent. We are currently running at 8.7 per cent. Clearly, that forecast is going to have to be revised. So, instead of just keeping an eye on it, I suggest that she starts telling the truth and that she revises that to precisely what this government thinks it can achieve in regard to unemployment.

While I am at it, perhaps she would have the intestinal fortitude to start setting a jobs target—something by which the Australian people can measure her performance and this government's performance when they go into the ballot booth and think, `Will we give this government the big tick or not?' That is what she needs to do but she will not do it because she is not into setting targets—no wonder, because the only way you can actually have accountability is by setting targets.

We have Senator Vanstone's brief excursion into macro‐economic policy. That was pretty interesting as well, and I remind the Senate of John Howard's headland speech in which he said that in order to have any impact on unemployment, you had to have a four per cent growth rate. As everybody in this Senate knows, the growth rate in the last financial year came in at under three per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two and a half.

—I think it was 2.6 per cent, Senator Conroy, wasn't it? So John Howard is saying we need four per cent before we can make any real dent in unemployment. What did Senator Vanstone say recently? She conceded that faster economic growth would not lead to rapid jobs growth. I say to this chamber: who is running the jobs strategy in this country? Who is providing the leadership? Who has got the plan? Who has the guts to set a target? Not this government—nobody in this government. There is no plan; there is no strategy—that is the shame of it. Forget the trade union movement in relation to this. We know what they think—they are appalled. Go and talk to your own constituency—industry—about what this government is doing on unemployment and they will tell you what you ought to be doing on industry policy.

BREAK.PARA: By the by, we have John Howard at the recent ACCI conference finally saying the two magic words—it must have just about killed him—that his government has to look at `strategic intervention'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He couldn't eat his dinner; he choked on it.
—That is right—I agree; he just about choked on his dinner. What precisely that means we still do not know. We still do not know what strategic intervention means.
—Neither do they.

—I suspect that the government does not. That is the situation with regard to some of Senator Vanstone's more embarrassing comments. Let me amplify her comment that what Australia needed was a freer labour market and lessened job security. I say again to her: do not go on an excursion into industrial relations when you do not even know that the unfair dismissal laws that you are talking about are your own. Forget it—stick to employment. The senator does not know much about that, but she knows absolutely zero about industrial relations.

BREAK.PARA: I have spoken already about the impact of the changes on unfair dismissals and what they mean to Australians who are concerned about their job security. Unemployment figures are intensifying the feeling of unease in the community with regard to that. Slashes to the public service and the revisions that are being proposed by this government to the Australian Public Service Act, whereby the mendicant status will be enshrined in legislation forevermore with regard to public servants and their political bosses, are adding to these feelings of unease.

There is also the reform of employment services. How can the unemployed feel secure that the government's employment service is actually going to provide jobs? I will tell you that, in terms of votes of confidence, you have four key employment agencies that have said that they are not going to bother tendering under Senator Vanstone's new regime because it is not profitable enough; it is not worth it, and it is full of red tape.

We then had a somewhat extraordinary statement from the government's own appointed chairperson of the interim public employment placement enterprise who, on 10 September, said that if he were a private provider he would not sign it. What was he talking about? He was talking about the tender document. He would not sign the tender document.

With regard to Senator Vanstone's comments on job insecurity—that is to say, what we need is less job security or increased job insecurity—not only has she let the cat out of the bag with regard to what this government is up to but on AM this morning Nick Greiner actually said:
What this government needs to have is lower wages by further industrial relations reform.

He said that the government should institute—he did not use the term `second wave'—further industrial relations reform to facilitate lower wages. So we have Senator Vanstone herself letting the cat out of the bag with regard to what this government's agenda is and she was backed up by Nick Greiner who, incidentally, as everybody knows, is a noted member of the Liberal Party, was premier for a long time and is the director of seven companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Including Phillip Morris.

—Including Phillip Morris. By any criteria that the government wishes to set, he is one of yours—and you cannot tell me that there are not regular discussions, because we know that there are regular discussions with Nick Greiner.
—With Nick Greiner?

—He may not talk to you, Senator McGauran, but I am sure he does talk to other people. Nick Greiner let the cat out of the bag, and he is correct about what this government's agenda is. This government wants to lower wages. I spent a month travelling around Australia, with a number of other senators, talking about the new industrial relations bill. Everywhere we went we asked the question: do you believe John Howard's commitment to the Australian people that no worker will be worse off will be met by this legislation? Every single worker organisation, and even a few employer organisations, said no. In fact, I think I recall the MTIA giving us some interesting submissions with regard to that. So the cat is out of the bag. What this government wants is increased casualisation of the work force and lower wages so that you can put more casuals on and pay them less.
—Greater insecurity.

—Yes, greater insecurity. They have set the parameters with regard to the industrial relations system to make sure that that happens. That is what it is all about. This government had the temerity to run around saying that no worker will be worse off. Let us put it this way: workers are going to be worse off under this government; they are already worse off under this government. There are already more unemployed people; there are already huge cuts to regional economies; and there is already an enormous amount of job insecurity. Why? Because this government has no strategy and it has no plan. It also has an incompetent employment minister. You only had to peruse the newspapers over the last couple of weeks to see who is No. 1 in the dumping stakes, and that is Senator Vanstone. If I were in John Howard's place, I would dump her as well. She is an absolute liability.

BREAK.PARA: This government's record on unemployment is disgraceful—it is not even meeting its own budget forecast. We have unemployment running at a completely outrageous level of 8.7 per cent. This minister should go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Payne, Sen Marise

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to congratulate Senator Quirke, although he is not in the chamber, on his first speech that he made this afternoon. I would like to take up a number of the points that Senator Mackay made in addressing her motion today. The government agrees that unemployment has been a longstanding problem in Australia over more than the last decade. But that will not come as a great surprise to those opposite because, after all, they were the people in charge. For example, the unemployment rate averaged more than 7½ per cent over the second half of the 1980s. From 1990‐1995, the average rate was worse at 9.4 per cent and peaked at 11.2 per cent in December of 1992. The party that was in government was the Australian Labor Party. It was a period marked by the highest unemployment rate since the Depression.

SPEECH.PARA: The quick fixes the opposition propose may have a superficial appeal, but only the right policies will actually address the problem on a lasting basis. So let us look a little harder at Labor's record. Let us look a little harder at the record that Senator Mackay chose to ignore. For 32 consecutive months under the Hawke and Keating governments, unemployment was higher than it was under any government since the end of World War II.

To come here today and criticise the government on the grounds that Senator Mackay chooses shows extraordinary gall. Clearly, the policies pursued by the previous government failed to reduce unemployment. But, in contrast, this government is implementing a range of policies that will act to create the right conditions for employment growth. It is about getting the settings right—working on all fronts together, not one at a time.

Since coming into office, the government has been fixing the fundamentals and creating an economic environment that is conducive to doing business. Let me enumerate some of those reforms. This government has a clear reform agenda. Our commitment is to making Australia one of the world's most internationally competitive nations by 2010 to meet APEC's free trade targets. That means, in the words of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), that there must be significant reforms over the whole spectrum of government activity. We do not accept some polemical view that total reform must occur today or that you can do it in piecemeal fashion, irrespective of the costs to the community. Our approach is strategic. It is one in which significant reform is ongoing and which avoids unnecessary strains on community cohesion.

The government's reform priorities are clear. It is about developing a fairer internationally competitive tax system. The government is moving down that road right now. It is about responding to useful, productive, constructive reports like the Mortimer, Goldsworthy and IPAC reports with a package that encourages business to employ more people, to be internationally competitive. It is about developing world‐class IT and education systems. It is about improving customs and clearance in the waterfront, something the opposition would know nothing about. It is about continuing competition policy development.

Over the last 18 months significant reforms have been put in place but, of course, they are completely unacknowledged by those on the other side. These include the Wallis proposals to strengthen our financial system and the reduction in automotive and TCF tariffs between 1995 and 2005, which will be legislated. Inflation is at a 30‐year low with official interest rates reduced five times since the government came to office. Major changes have occurred in the industrial relations system. One-third of Telstra is being privatised, with that money going to useful works in Australia. Incentives encouraging private health insurance and reforms have been introduced to support small business, including capital gains tax rollover relief, reducing the provisional tax uplift factor and revising FBT compliance. If you take all of those together, it is quite clear that the govern ment's comprehensive commitment is to reform.

The OECD itself recently assessed the government's current reforms against the recommendations outlined in its jobs strategy. Rather than suggesting that we take the easy answer, or the so-called quick fix of Labor, the OECD has given strong support to this government's reforms—reforms like the charter of budget honesty, fiscal consolidation, the industrial relations reforms, the overhaul of employment assistance arrangements and the changes to the apprenticeship and trainee arrangements. Where did Labor leave apprenticeships and trainees in this country? These are all areas which the previous government did not have the courage or the foresight to address. Over how many years? Thirteen. Over how many reports? Innumerable. How many young lives have been damaged? You cannot count them. The OECD strategies are the right strategies to pursue. The countries that have implemented those policies have experienced the greatest falls in unemployment and have dramatically improved the performance of their labour markets.

This government is here for the long haul. We are fixing the fundamentals to ensure that we can provide for all Australians into the 21st century. The opposition would have this Senate believe that this government is responsible for the level of Australian workers' confidence. How long will they keep up that tired joke? Senator Mackay mentioned participation rates in the Australian work force. They have remained steady for the last three years at around 63 per cent, not a participation rate that the government created but one we inherited from the Labor government who, after 13 years, could not provide enough direction or stability for the Australian labour force to allow them to be re-elected to lead this country for another term. Aren't we all grateful for the foresight of the Australian community?

The Australian electorate elected this government on a promise that we would take a responsible approach, that we would provide real solutions and that we would fix the fundamentals. What we will not do is allow the opposition to bully us into building a job strategy on a base of sand that will just crumble like the previous Labor government's did. This government is providing a concrete foundation to ensure that growth is long term and that confidence in the work force and in the business community is strong and unwavering.

On the issue of job security, it is important to realise that technological innovation, globalisation and other changes are all having a profound effect on modern economies. For those with any degree of foresight or any capacity to think past the end of their nose, this makes you rethink the notion of job security. In fact, holding a single job for life is becoming the exception, not the norm. Rather, workers are moving from job to job, perhaps even making major career changes during their working life. It seems to me that this is particularly relevant to the question of inexorably falling union membership levels. Maybe those opposite need to contemplate why that might be. Perhaps the organisations that they represent and come from are not keeping up with the changes in employment.

The government is addressing these changes in a positive way with policies that will provide the employment growth and the labour market flexibility which will enable workers to move between jobs without becoming unemployed. But of course, as the Prime Minister himself has said, the Australian Labor Party is always prepared, when faced with the choice between a regulated labour market dominated by the trade union movement or a lower level of unemployment, to choose the regulated labour market. It is our reforms to education and training which focus on fundamentals like literacy and numeracy and reforms to employment assistance which will give people the skills they need to capitalise on emerging job opportunities. It is all about getting those fundamentals right for all Australians, something the opposition did not understand in government and certainly does not understand now.

The Workplace Relations Act is a powerful example of this government's commitment to getting it right. Australia does need a freer industrial relations system in order to move ahead. The Workplace Relations Act removes the old restraints which discouraged employers from hiring. The Labor Party's onerous unfair dismissal provisions have been replaced by a system which is fairer for both workers and employers. We now see workers and employers developing cooperative agreements which provide increased flexibility and productivity in the use of labour and which also meet the needs of employees.

It is extraordinary that the opposition moves a motion such as this, having us believe that the government does not have in place a job strategy that does look after the work force. Just think for a moment about where they are coming from. Let us take a look at their record on youth unemployment and the solutions that they came up with. Over 13 years in government they promised increased opportunities for young Australians and then let the number of apprenticeships run down to the lowest level in 30 years. When this government introduced a work for the dole scheme to provide 18‐ to 24‐year‐olds with experience and confidence, a scheme aimed at promoting the culture of work and combating the cycle of despondency and the lack of self‐esteem and despair that often tragically characterise the young unemployed, the Labor Party actually voted against the scheme in the House of Representatives.

The scheme is about fixing the fundamentals, building the concrete foundations and putting young people back into the loop. It provides additional funding of $21 million for 10,000 places in 70 pilot projects. It focuses on the long-term unemployed, helping them establish networks or employment contacts which are crucial to finding out about jobs.

The irrefutable facts of this government's approach to fixing the fundamentals to ensure a future for the Australian work force and the Australian business community are the following. There have been five interest rate falls since March 1996, and interest rates are at their lowest level in more than two decades. The interest rates charged to small businesses by banks are at their lowest level in 20 years, and underlying inflation is running at two per cent.

BREAK.PARA: This government is on course to deliver a structural surplus of $1.6 billion by 1998-99. In 1996 and 1997, business investment grew by 16 per cent. In the first six months of 1997, the economy was growing at an annualised rate of 3.7 per cent, and there have now been 24 consecutive quarters of GDP growth.

Out of the 1997 budget came the $1 billion Federation Fund for projects of national significance that will generate jobs in the construction phase. I have already referred to the work for the dole project. In addition to both of those, the $130 million small business innovation fund and the $45 million community support program, over the next four years, will assist 25,500 job seekers. The Green Corps training project is providing training for young people aged 17 to 20 years, with $41 million of government funding, full-time for six months on community based environmental projects which link training to career prospects.

If the opposition are seriously interested in employment strategies, they should also be looking at the OECD jobs strategy. The following points are listed by the OECD as being appropriate for maximising employment opportunities and employment growth: fundamentals like sound macroeconomic policy, which gives sustainable non‐inflationary growth; the need to enhance the creation and diffusion of technological know‐how; and the need to increase the flexibility of working time through the voluntary agreement of workers and employers, and the Workplace Relations Act goes directly to that point.

Also on the list are the need to facilitate the creation and expansion of enterprises; to make wage and labour costs more flexible to reflect local conditions and individual skills; to reform employment security provisions—again, the Workplace Relations Act addresses precisely that point; and to strengthen active labour market policies and improve their effectiveness—and, in every way, the government's work in the workplace relations area goes to that point.

Lastly, there is the need to raise skill levels by reforming education and training, which were left in a desperate situation after 13 years of ALP government. There is the need to reform unemployment and related benefits systems and their interaction with the tax system, to improve work incentives and achieve fundamental equity goals, and to enhance product market competition. All these fundamentals of the OECD jobs strategies need to be addressed together, not separately and not in isolation.

Senator Mackay was blissfully misinterpreting the remarks at the CEDA conference of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, yet again, notwithstanding the minister's clarifications. The minister quite clearly pointed Senator Mackay to the OECD job strategies to correct her misapprehensions.

On the question of job security, the minister made it quite clear what will happen when small business believes that it is going to be very expensive to make changes in the employment of a person who is not working out on the job. If they are unable to select another person and there is a high cost to that—there was a significantly high cost under the Labor Party's laws—what people do in that situation is employ casuals because they do not take the chance of making a bad choice. The minister made it quite clear that the government's legislation enables employers to make those choices. They are a very important part of giving small business the strength and capacity to operate effectively in the workplace.

Unemployment is a long-term problem. I acknowledged at the beginning of my remarks that the government knows and understands the views of the electorate on that question and also understands that the electorate had put up with the policies of the former government for a period in excess of 13 years.

As a long-term problem, unemployment requires long-term solutions. The coalition government's solutions are a balanced budget, which will take the pressure off interest rates, and I have already referred to reductions in the interest rates; the capacity for low interest rates that encourage business investment and job creation; a low inflation environment to encourage productive investment in wealth creating activities; flexible workplace relations to increase productivity, to increase Australia's international competitiveness and Austra lia's employment; and individually tailored assistance to the unemployed to give unemployed people the skills they need to get a job.

We pay providers for outcomes. We do not simply stick people in programs that shuffle and churn and change the statistics but still result in long queues of long-term unemployed. We reduced red tape for small business, which enables them to get on with the job of wealth and job creation. The package of reforms announced this week will do just that.

We have reinvigorated the apprenticeships and traineeships programs in Australia to give more training opportunities to the young Australians who were let down so comprehensively by the previous government. Through our education policies, we are creating pathways from schools to employment and encouraging industry links through that process. We focus on literacy and numeracy in our schools to give young Australians the skills they need to avoid unemployment.

Addressing Senator Mackay's motion is all about addressing the fundamentals. I have enumerated those for the Senate this afternoon. It is the government's concern with the fundamentals which means that we will provide Australians with the solutions, we will provide Australians with the answers, that they have sought for more than a decade from the previous government and were continually disappointed in not receiving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Structural unemployment in Australia is rampant. By that I mean the nature of industry, not the voluntary unemployment where people might choose to move from one job to another, or choose to leave one area of the country to travel somewhere else and then look for a job. Structural unemployment is about how industry is operating in Australia and how it is actually creating unemployment by the nature of its operations, the nature of its use of capital and technology rather than its use of people, the downsizing, the requirement that people work longer and longer hours and so on. I will be talking more about that during my presentation.

BREAK.PARA: The government is acting as if it is voluntary. We have heard people talk about deserving poor and undeserving poor. In most instances, there is a feeling that many people—perhaps most unemployed people—are the undeserving poor, and that is a very unfortunate trend.

Structural unemployment is a major problem in Australia, but Australia is not alone in that. Structural unemployment is common in most developed nations around the world. It is part of the move to internationalisation and it is primarily a result of the deregulation of the economic world which allows corporations to produce where they like, generally where labour costs, tax and regulations for safety and environmental protection are weakest. We have seen the proliferation of enormous environmental disasters within our region. There is an attraction for big industry to go in to rip and tear where they know there will be the least possibility for them to be called to question on environmental issues and social justice issues, and also where the taxes might be lower and the wages and conditions are lower. That is the world we are living in at the moment.

The denationalisation of economies has meant that there is less need for an internal mass market. For all that governments talk about what they do and do not do in terms of the economy, I guess in their private, honest moments they would tell you that there is not a lot that they have left themselves to do with the way they operate an economy these days.

If large corporations are not necessarily looking for an internal mass market for their goods and services, where are they looking? They are looking for a global market of elite and upper‐middle classes to substitute for the need for a national mass market to eliminate the Ford or Keynesian rationale for paying workers enough to pay for most products of an industrial economy. Remember, Henry Ford said that he thought the appropriate wage for his workers was enough to be able to purchase the goods that they were producing. That is not an unreasonable thing to say. The size of the United States economy certainly made that a very viable prospect.

But the changes that we have seen in terms of looking for the elite—the middle class in bigger economies, even if they are developing countries—have been exacerbated by technological changes that allow production to be more easily transferred—to be more flexible—allowing equipment to be used for various purposes. Data processing capacity and near‐instant communications allow just‐in‐time management practices. People do not hold stocks of goods any more if they can help it. You do not produce stocks and have them available; you have people on and bring the work force in just to produce that which has been ordered. That, in some ways, keeps down the cost for the producer, but does not necessarily reduce the cost for the buyer. I have not heard tales that these costs have been decreased, but it does mean that the cost for the producer is kept down because of their limiting their cost of wages.

Just‐in‐time management allows the severe reduction of material stocks and held stocks of products. It also applies to labour, encouraging the casualisation of the work force and the use of short‐term contracts. So you get a wider and wider group within our community who do not necessarily know from week to week what their pay will be and what their work situation will be. Of course, those people are less willing to spend any discretionary income that they have from the time that they are working.

Economic pressures have also led to the increasing reduction of secure full‐time work. Through various ways, the government has indicated that this might be a goal. It is rarely admitted but the reality is that there is a reduction in secure full‐time work. The lack of this secure full‐time work has increased pressure to reduce or eliminate on‐the‐job training. Such training makes no sense when there is no necessary continuity in the work force. The result is that the burden of training falls on the public and on workers. A further result is that people who have little access to appropriate training have fewer options for jobs.

I noticed Senator Payne mentioned Green Corps. The reality is that that is a step down in terms of resources and the number of people involved from previous programs. It means in fact that we have less likelihood of outcomes, and the people involved in those programs—the ones that I know about—have found that they are required to do more with less. That is always a problem. Whether or not people choose to go on those programs will affect the outcomes as well.

We have had much emphasis on international competitiveness. For many people that means a race to the bottom in many ways—wages and conditions, and environmental standards. We have seen what that race to the bottom in environmental standards means at the moment in terms of the smog and toxic pollution over this region.

I also noted that Senator Payne mentioned a competition policy, proudly mentioning the push that the current government has taken and, at many levels, state governments as well. In fact, it was introduced by the former Labor government. I would very much like the actual outcomes of competition policy to be reviewed. I would like it to be seen in terms of its employment outcomes and its environment and community outcomes—its social outcomes. But, in this chamber, we have not seen fit to do that. I think it is crying out to look at what the actual outcomes are. I know for sure that local government believe it is time for it to be reviewed and revisited because they have been given the short end of the stick on this issue.

They represent everybody in Australia. So if local government are finding it difficult and many people at the state government levels are finding it difficult, what does it mean for the rest of the people in Australia? Just wait until we have the outcomes of the 2,000 pieces of legislation that currently are being reviewed behind largely closed doors. What will happen when we have to deal with the outcomes of that? It is not a process that has happened; it is happening, and it is getting worse and worse the less we do about it.

I have looked at some figures based on seasonally adjusted data. The number of unemployed has been increasing from about 750,000 people, or 8.3 per cent, in June 1995, and it is now around 800,000, or 8.7 per cent. Long‐term unemployment has been increasing from 206,000, or 26.2 per cent of total unemployment, in May 1996, and it is now about 248,000, or 31 per cent of total unemployment. Nearly one‐third of unemployed people are long‐term unemployed.

Youth unemployment has been rising from a low of 26.4 per cent of the youth labour force in July 1996 and now stands at 27.3 per cent. The participation rate is down since the high of 64.1 per cent in November 1995, an indicator that the level of hidden unemployment is high and increasing. The participation rate now stands at 62.9 per cent.

Under‐employment, that is the number of people working part time because they cannot find full‐time work, is a more recent factor. It has become significant enough that the Australian Bureau of Statistics now collects this information as part of labour statistics. The latest information I could get was the September 1996 figures, which said that there were 547,000 unemployed workers at that time. Note that 1996 was a time when unemployment was actually lower than it is now. I do not know what the current figures are, but it is very important that we recognise this.

We all know that in countries where there are no unemployment benefits at all the concept of unemployment is in fact a luxury. People have to survive some way. It could be by the casual economy; it could be by stealing, if you have to survive; it could be by grubbing around in rubbish bins and trying to make things from the rubbish to sell. That might, in some people's eyes, be seen as unemployment. In many people's eyes, that is under‐employment, and some people just see it as the casual work force.

I do not think we would really like to see the situation in Australia where more people are being kicked off benefits for various reasons, which we have heard from the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, and to have a situation where people are having to make do in whatever way they can. In many cases, that is under‐employment. It can be that the people who have to accept have very little choice but to accept employment at, maybe in Australia, $2 an hour for delivering leaflets. How many people in Australia are being paid very low, unacceptably low, rates of pay?

This government are complicit in these changes for structural unemployment. They are not running the agenda necessarily in the economy, but they are complicit in some of these changes, as was the former government. The Thatcherite or Reaganite economic models espoused this to various degrees and were designed to facilitate the changes, which benefited the corporate interests mostly. The corporations and the international money market generally punish employment policies. They tend to give a big tick for lower taxation, for cutting back on the public sector or for downsizing, but they tend to punish countries that have employment policies. It is an irony, isn't it, that we are being dictated to by people whose main motives are greed and self‐benefit.

The issues that need to be addressed in a global economy are not necessarily how to attract corporations who will export. That is a recipe which may be making the profit margin of General Motors the goal of the nation. What we need is to develop a nation which is more self‐reliant and which is based on an ethic of providing and supporting people in meaningful work which does not violate goals for increasing the quality of life for all Australians. To be clear here, quality of life does not equate with maximum consumption. It implies that everyone can have enough, but that once most basic material and social needs are satisfied the majority of people find less materialistic activities more fulfilling than working themselves to death to increase their bank account.

What are we going to get in Australia? I saw some statistics the other day that stated that more people are actually dying of stress and overwork than are actually dying in road accidents. I would need to check the figures, but it was a bit of a shock. We have a situation in Australia where there is under‐employment and overtime—a lot of the time unpaid. There is stress for the people who are working, I think, and many of the people who are not working are stressed for different reasons. When we get to our retirement—which we have to pay for, and there is a lot of stress involved with that because it looks as if pensions are no longer going to be a right—I can see there will be very few people who will actually have the health and ability to enjoy it.

We are finding that leisure within our system is something that perhaps fewer people have access to. We have a situation where more people are required to work over the weekends anyway, working in 24‐hour businesses and so on. There is the whole concept of being able to incorporate the values that we enjoy in our lives and of being able to join with other people at weekends. That has almost disappeared altogether in Australia. That is very worrying, I believe. What are we doing in our nation; what are we benefiting from if that is what we are doing?

Receipt of money does become a priority for poor people. Necessities must be looked after, but once people move out of that category they can reassess. This is a good process. We need to reassess as a nation, and work towards a world where everyone has enough rather than a world where everyone has an opportunity to exploit each other as much as possible and a handful of people can win big while most other people lose. That is the concept of wealth creation, or the trickle down theory, much of which was discredited back in the 1970s and 1980s in development theory. We are going back to the assumption in Australia that if a few people have the ability to make a lot of money, then somehow or other everybody else benefits. The figures do not work out. Currently, that is a zero sum cake.

If what we are saying in our communities is that we can do things differently, perhaps we can turn this thing around. I was interviewed not so long ago by a journalist who wanted to know what I thought about employment and its rate of growth. I have said for a long time that I do not believe there is a magical point in national growth statistics where employment suddenly becomes available—although I think four per cent is generally thrown around. We have heard that there have been many quarters of growth in Australia, but we have not heard of there having been many benefits in relation to employment.

I would say that there are very good reasons why we have had long periods of jobless growth. One of them is because of the built‐in structure of unemployment. That is because we are, in fact, moving to get rid of people from the work force. We know that governments, especially conservative governments, are desperate to get rid of public sector employees. We know that many corporations themselves have decided their main role in life is to get rid of their employees.

However, I believe it is not the percentage of growth that is important. I believe it is the type of development and economy that is important. That can be creating diversity. That can be creating some form of greater regional self-sufficiency. It can mean, in many cases—cases like Maleny in Queensland—looking at novel ideas about creating regional credit schemes; looking at novel ideas about communities finding some of their solutions; and also looking at ideas such as finding a local currency which is exchangeable for goods and services which will enable small businesses to become creative and use skills that otherwise are not valued within the normal formal economy. Many people who are otherwise conservative are linking into those schemes because they work well. If what we are after is meeting people's needs, those are the kinds of ideas we have to look at.

I also think that the current, very narrow concept of `economy' which says that, as long as you have export coal, you have a healthy economy is very narrow minded. I think we should be looking at other ways of producing our energy. It is clear, and the statistics can show you many times over, that energy conservation and efficiency measures can create many, many more jobs than coal fired power stations—certainly many, many more jobs than those created with the money, the $2.5 billion, we have wasted in Australia on Lucas Heights. How many jobs have been created out of that $2.5 billion of, largely, wasted money?

What could we have been doing creatively in terms of the environment? What could we have been doing creatively in terms of alternative energy which would put Australia at the forefront of what the rest of the world is aiming to do in terms of energy conservation efficiency? We have wasted a lot of our opportunities, but we should not waste any more. I believe that we can have growthless jobs. I believe that we can be doing things differently in rearranging the way we operate our economy.

I have said before today that I do not believe the economy should be ruling people; people should be using the economy to achieve their own ends. We should not be dictated to by the international money markets. We should not have our social policies and employment policies dictated by people whose sole purpose in life is to line their own pockets through money market speculation and futures markets. We in this country should be able to decide on what is a reasonable outcome for our economy and our social system.

We should be looking at very creative solutions for achieving a greater level of independence from what is happening in the internationalist environment which is helping to create the situation we are in now. This does not mean `fortress Australia'. This means smarter thinking, and deciding to meet some of those needs at the regional and local levels with the resources that we have here. This means protecting and preserving the future, and not destroying it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion of Senator Mackay which is before the Senate. This is the most fundamental issue we face as a nation: dealing with the question of unemployment. The fact that unemployment is still at 8.7 per cent and, more importantly, that the participation rate has been declining since this government was elected—it has dropped, in fact, by 1.6 per cent since the March election of 1996—is a clear indictment of the current government and its lack of any strategy or plan to deal with this question.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that this country needs a plan. It needs a long‐term strategy to deal with the issue of unemployment if we are to achieve the goal of getting it down below five per cent, which was a goal that the Labor Party in government was prepared to set itself as an objective. But this government is not prepared to commit itself to that or any other target in terms of the unemployment figures.

The reality also is that the Labor Party did have a plan for dealing with the question of unemployment, and that plan was Working Nation. One of the significant achievements of that plan was what it did in terms of targeting the long‐term unemployed. When the plan was initiated, long-term unemployment in this country was around about 300,000; it depends what point you take as the kick‐in point, but it was around that figure. Labor got that figure down, in a very short period of time, to 206,000. Under this government, it has already moved back up to near 250,000.

A recent report was prepared by Mr P.J. Junankar and Mr Kapuscinski from the Australian National University. They said a couple of significant things which I think are important and should be put on the record. The report states:
Although Working Nation had a very short life it succeeded in helping the long term unemployed: it was a very useful social experiment which was aborted for political reasons.
It continues:
The coalition government have apparently lost interest in the long term unemployed: there has been a massive cutback in expenditure on labour market programs.

Contrast that with what the Labor Party did in government and Working Nation where we promised to create 500,000 jobs over the period of 1993 to 1996 and, in fact, achieved 680,000 jobs over that period; and contrast it also with the achievement of the Labor government from 1983 to 1996 where, in fact, there were an additional two million-plus Australians employed in this country over that period. That was the extent of the growth in the work force over Labor's term in office.

You have to contrast that of course with the position that was left to Labor—the legacy that Little Johnny Howard left them when he was the Treasurer of this country in 1983—of double digit inflation and double digit unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator—what is his name; Senator Crawford, is it?
—Campbell.

—He has not been here long enough to know that when he refers to a member of the other House, and particularly the Prime Minister, he refers to him by his correct name. I would ask him to withdraw that statement about the Prime Minister.

—On the point of order, I do not know that it is a matter of asking Senator Campbell to withdraw; rather the point of order ought to have been that Senator Campbell address the Prime Minister appropriately. That is more the question and that is the point of order that should have been made.

TALKER.NAME: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Jacinta Collins)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell, I ask you to correct your reference to the Prime Minister.

—On the point of order, I think you should also draw Senator Herron's attention to the responsibility that he has to refer to senators by their correct names. The sort of cheap, smart alec shot that he tried in his point of order was not only not funny but a little bit insulting. I would have thought it was even beneath his dignity.
—On the point of order, I did not recall the new senator's name.
—You're dumber than I thought you were then.
—I acknowledge that interjection and I would ask for that to be withdrawn too as an imputation on me.

—On that point of order, if Senator Herron did not recall Senator Campbell's name then I can only ask: how was he able to pay attention to the point where he was able to take a point of order if he was not listening to the debate and did not hear Senator Campbell called?
—Senator Forshaw, there is no point of order. I give Senator Campbell the opportunity to correct his remark and his reference with respect to the Prime Minister.
—I withdraw.
—No, Senator Campbell, there is no need to withdraw. Just correct your remark with respect to the Prime Minister.

—When the Prime Minister, John Howard, was Treasurer of this country in 1983 he left the nation with double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. That is a record that you cannot run away from. However, it is fair to say that the previous Labor government did have a plan for dealing with the question of unemployment. It did set out to tackle the problem and it did set itself, systematically, targets and goals to achieve it. It set the goal of achieving five per cent or less unemployment by the year 2000—something that this government is not prepared to acknowledge or prepared to set itself.

BREAK.PARA: Fortunately there are others in the community who do have plans about how to deal with the issue of unemployment, and a number of those plans have emerged recently. They have emerged out of the Mortimer report, which raises a number of key issues that we need to address as a community if we are to deal with the issue of unemployment, and those are currently before the government.

You have the Goldsworthy report, which deals with the question of information technology. It recognises the importance of information technology in terms of what it can do to drive the productive capacity of the country and of individual companies and how it can lead to the creation of more competitive enterprises with the capacity to employ greater numbers of Australians. We had the minister who is now responsible for information technology in this chamber the other day, unable to tell us what the size of his department was, what funds had been allocated to that ministry or what the strategy was in terms of addressing the issues that are in the Goldsworthy report.

The MTIA have a plan. They have submitted a plan in which they have put forward seven key steps, among which are the question of tax reform, an investment agency, stronger central coordination of industry policy and engagement with Asia in terms of it being a free trade area. These are among a number of key recommendations from that organisation in terms of how we can address the problem of unemployment in this country.

The common ground between all of those plans is that you will not get job growth without investment in research and development and in infrastructure. This government, in its budgets, has cut the public support for R&D, yet it is acknowledged across the whole of the business community that it is a key issue in terms of our companies being able to compete in the global market. There has recently been a report released by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology called `Made by Hong Kong' in which they reinforce that point. It is innovation that gives companies the edge in the global marketplace.

We as a nation have to understand and accept that, in the global market in which we are operating, we do not have the luxury of looking any more at Australia being a domestic market and an opportunity to compete in the market elsewhere. We are a small part of a global marketplace and we have to compete both for our share of the domestic market with international competitors and for our share of the international market with those domestic competitors in those sections of the international market. That is a challenge that we have to confront and we are only going to be able to do that if we are able to hit the marketplace with innovative ideas, then commercialise those ideas and turn them into innovative products that give us a leading edge in terms of our capacity to compete in that marketplace. That is the central message that comes out of all those reports.

The other area of commonality is the question of sectoral industry plans looking at those key industries of growth, like biotechnology and information technology, particularly in the software area. This country can be at the leading edge of software development in information technology. It is an area where there ought to be a lot of concentration, because we have the skills and the capacity to win a significant share of what will be a very substantial growth area in terms of jobs in the future. An example is what has been occurring in that area in the United States. Forty per cent of the jobs growth and income growth in GDP in the United States over the last 10 years has been caused by computers and computer software. It has been the engine of growth in the American economy. It is an area, as I said, that we have to give much more fundamental support to and support for if we are going to get the benefits that potentially reside in that area for us as a nation.

The reality is that the current coalition government have no plan for job creation. It is a government that has an ideological obsession with discredited economic fundamentalist policies that were implemented by Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan. They have a wish list to get back to the agenda of the early 1980s and a political mentality that is still somewhere in the 1950s. That is the reason why they are not prepared to commit themselves to an unemployment target.

They have no objectives and there is no criteria against which the government can judge what they are doing in terms of unemployment. They have no idea what the outcomes of their policies are going to be in terms of resolving the unemployment problem. They are counting and relying solely on the market to solve the problem. Their strategy for dealing with unemployment is a wing and a prayer.

They are hoping against hope that something will happen out there that will change the figures before the next election. They are also hoping that it may not be an issue, but it will be an issue. Unemployment will be the central issue upon which the next election is fought. It will be fought on jobs, it will be fought on job security, and it will be fought on the welfare of every Australian.

The results speak for themselves. If you look at the results over the 18 months of this government, you can see that in fact we have had negative employment growth.
