We have lost 60,000 full-time jobs since the last budget, 38,000 of them in August 1997 alone. Let us look at some of the criticisms that have been made after the last budget. From the Executive Director of the Victorian Council of Social Services:
Jobs is the critical issue and they have not tackled it. I don't know how they will bring unemployment down to 8 percent. There is no central industry reform or employment initiative.

A spokesperson for the Salvation Army said that the work for the dole scheme for 10,000 young people was `totally inadequate for the other 800,000 unemployed Australians'. All this government can do is to blame the unemployed for their situation and fiddle with the figures. The only way the Prime Minister, John Howard, and the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, can see to improve unemployment figures is to make sure unemployed Australians are too discouraged to seek jobs.

The work force participation rate is at its lowest for three years. People are just giving up in the search for employment. Look at some of the remedies that the minister offered in this chamber yesterday in question time, when she was questioned substantially upon her address to the CEDA dinner. It is interesting that she keeps saying that she is being quoted out of context but she has consistently refused to provide a copy of her speech. It would be interesting to see what else is in the speech that she may feel would be an embarrassment to her and, probably more importantly, an embarrassment to her government.

She kept saying there were two issues that were important for job creation opportunities to deal with unemployment in this country: one was a freer industrial relations market and the other was the question of unfair dismissals. Despite the fact that your industrial relations legislation dealing with unfair dismissals has been in operation for some considerable time, you are still raising the question of unfair dismissals as a furphy. Those are the two issues the minister keeps saying are central to this government's strategy for dealing with the question of unemployment. They want to blame everybody around them, except themselves, for the lack of result in this area.

But what are people in the real world saying are the barriers to employment creation opportunities? Let us look at the survey that was conducted by the Economic Intelligence Unit for the MTIA report and which I think was reproduced in Tuesday's edition of the Australian Financial Review. They said that the barriers to investment, in order of importance, were: the small size of our market, high local taxes, little incentive from the government—I repeat, little incentive—uncertain outlook for industry policy—in other words, the fact that there is not any industry policy against which they can judge their investment decisions—and the physical distance from markets. The last two issues that were identified as a barrier to employment in this country were high port and shipping costs and industrial relations problems. The last on the list was the industrial relations problem.

Here we have a government that continually talks about micro-economic reform and wants to attack the maritime workers and blame them for a lot of the problems that we confront; yet high port and shipping costs was identified way down the line as being a barrier to investment in this country. We all know that the attack on the waterside workers is not about trying to remove impediments to employment growth; it is ideological in the sense of this government's committed position of trying to destroy the collective organisation of workers in this country, as it is expressed through trade unions and the trade union movement.

The reality is, as I said before, that this government does not have a plan to deal with unemployment, nor does it have a plan about how to grow this economy. It does not have a strategy to put in place that will create the job opportunities that are necessary to reduce unemployment substantially.

There is another plan which has been developed and just released recently. This was a plan produced by my own union, the Australian Manufacturing Workers Union, called Rebuilding Australia: industry development for more jobs. I would take this opportunity to acknowledge the work that was done on that report by our national research officer, Nixon Apple. It sets out a strategy for dealing with the question of unemployment. Our union has been producing these reports from 1977.

TALK.START.PARA: —You killed off 11,000.
—We were proved right in 1977, in 1979 and in 1981.
—Did you go around to their homes after they had lost their jobs?
—We have consistently run that argument in this country for the development of our industries from the early 1980s—all of which you consistently oppose.
—They will never forgive you for it.

—Don't you sit there, Senator, and say that you are concerned about the battlers. You have never done anything to promote the development of manufacturing and service industries in this country. The only concern you had about trade unionists was taking their money to buy your pub in Melbourne. You were happy then to engage with trade unionists. But we do have a plan. We have a five-point plan for dealing with the question of unemployment. A key element of that plan is innovation—a strategy which says that we should adopt an approach to R&D assistance in this country which encourages companies to expend more of their own dollars as well as the dollars provided out of the public purse; a strategy which, if implemented, would in our view considerably increase the expenditure on R&D that we are seeing in this country in the current environment.

BREAK.PARA: The second part of that strategy concerns venture capital and capital adequacy. We acknowledge what was done in the small business fund. But one of the key issues in that area is the question of patient capital and the necessity to look at the tax act in terms of encouraging longer‐term investment over short‐term investment. There is a range of other issues. One of the most important is the establishment of a `national development authority' with a possible agenda to replace the Productivity Commission.
There are other issues which I will not get time to address. I seek leave to table that report in the Senate.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the things about a whip is that he does not get a chance to talk very often. All he has is the opportunity to table reports and whatever. Senator Mackay has raised a very important subject today. There is no doubt about that. All of us on this side of the chamber certainly share Senator Mackay's concerns about the issues of unemployment, job security and policy direction. There is no doubt about that.

SPEECH.PARA: All we have heard from the other side is a lot of quotes, and, just recently, Senator Campbell talking about a number of plans that have all of sudden appeared out of nowhere. I wonder where all those plans were when the Labor Party was in power and we had unemployment at 11 per cent or so. This government has not once tried to hide the unemployment situation in any shape or form. Instead, in the short time we have been in government, we have sought to get out into the open the fact that unemployment has been a longstanding problem for the last 20 years.

The problem that I have with Senator Mackay's motion is that it is not concerned with the plight of the unemployed. It is a motion that has been put forward to deliberately mislead the Senate and the people of Australia. This motion is misleading because it is based upon three fallacies. Fallacy No. 1 is that this government is responsible for creating an unemployment level of 8.7 per cent. Fallacy No. 2 is that this government is responsible for increasing job insecurity. Fallacy No. 3 is that this government does not possess a coherent job creation policy direction. They are the three fallacies that this motion is based on. In the short time I have, I would like to address those fallacies.

In addressing the first fallacy, if you were to accept the thrust of Senator Mackay's motion, you could be mistaken for believing that the unemployment levels that we in this nation are facing were the creation of this government. Nothing could be further from the truth. A paper entitled Divided nation: employment and unemployment in Australia, published in September last year by two independent commentators, Graeme Dorrance and Helen Hughes, reflected on the Hawke‐ Keating legacy. The paper documented that in 1993 long‐term unemployment had grown to 37 per cent. Likewise, in 1993, youth unemployment represented 40 per cent of total unemployment. Of most concern, however, is the following statement:

The re-emergence of high unemployment in Australia has been accompanied by widening income distribution and worsening poverty. Australia is now a divided nation: whereas 85 per cent of the workforce are employed and living well as `insiders', 15 per cent are unemployed, underemployed, disguised unemployed and poor `outsiders' concentrated in low socioeconomic status neighbourhoods marked by low labour force participation, high unemployment, poor educational achievement and poor health. An underclass is growing as unemployment levels rise with each cyclical downturn
So let us get it clear—for 32 consecutive months under Hawke and Keating, unemployment was at its highest since World War II. That was our inheritance 18 months ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! That's not right.

—Turning to fallacy No. 2, I thought it would have been abundantly clear to you, Senator Mackay, that this government is all about delivering job security. How else could you explain the recent decisions by the government in relation to the automotive industry? You made sneering comments about the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his selective intervention, but the examples are there for you to see. In South Australia and Victoria, as a result of the Prime Minister's intervention and sound and sensible government decisions, over 70,000 jobs have been secured and investment is now flowing in—Holden, Toyota, Mitsubishi and Ford are all engaging in further investment initiatives in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: How else can one explain the decisions by the government in relation to the textile, clothing and footwear industries but by the touchstone of job security? I suppose you will say that it was your policy. It was not. As a consequence of this government making a sound and sensible decision just over a month ago, approximately 100,000 jobs have been secured in this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dragged kicking and screaming.

—In my home state of Tasmania, as you would know, Senator Murphy, that icon of a company, Blundstone, announced a $5 million expansion to their works. That was the result of the government's wise commitment to the future of the TCF industries. They are going ahead with their job creating investment in Glenorchy and taking up the unemployment situation there. You know where Glenorchy is; it is a suburb of Hobart, not like Opossum Bay. How else can you explain the decisions by this government?
—Where do you live? Sandford, that's right.
—So what? We haven't got a Blundstone's boot factory at Sandford. I employ people on my farm.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, I sat here quietly, listening to Senator George Campbell telling us about all the plans he had for Australia. Perhaps I could get an opportunity to stand here and make a few points about what we are trying to do in government—not in opposition.

The release this week of the kit Giving Small Business a Fair Go certainly seeks to implement the measures that small businesses have been crying out for. If you want to talk about quotes, have a look at some of the quotes from small business people—the people that you ignored when you were in government. What did you do about small business? Not one thing. Most of the small businesses around today were big businesses but they became small businesses when you were in government.

So we do not make any excuses. We side with small businesses, because we know they are the only ones that can create real jobs for this country—not those Mickey Mouse jobs you quoted in Working Nation where people went in one door, were in training for about 12 months and then went out the backdoor. They are not real jobs. Small business can not only give job security, it can also provide real jobs.

That is why we are committed—and how else can you explain our commitment? In my own state of Tasmania we are committed to the regional forest agreement. What is going to happen? After two decades of the competing and divisive demands of conservation and industry in our state, this government is going to deliver job security, certainty and investment—something you never delivered. Only today, in one of the related moves to this program, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) announced the government's 20‐20 plantation vision, which is a boost for jobs, economic growth and rural communities.Senator Mackay, I know you will be delighted to know that the federal, state and territory governments joined with the industry in order to commit themselves to creating up to 40,000 jobs through a trebling of Australia's plantation forest estates by the year 2020. It will be interesting to know what sort of comments we get from Senator Brown about this. I am waiting to hear. I could go on, but it is pretty obvious that this government is certainly committed to delivering job security.

Let us turn to fallacy No. 3—the claim that this government lacks a job creation policy focus. I refer you back to the quote earlier from The Divided Nation. You should take particular note of this. The authors' following statement was:
Unless fundamental policy changes are made speedily, the insider proportion of Australians could be reduced to 80 per cent, leaving 20 per cent, or one person in five, to be poor outsiders.

Since day one, this government has set out to take on the challenge of reducing unemployment. Fundamental policy changes have to be made, and a lot of them have been made already. If we are going to get this country back and unemployment down, the sorts of things that are going to have to be put in place include balancing the budget, creating an environment of low interest rates, creating an environment of low inflation, introducing flexible workplace relations, tailoring individual assistance to the unemployed, reducing red tape for small business, creating pathways from schools to employment and focusing on literacy and numeracy in our schools.

As I said here the other night, I recently had the opportunity to visit Ireland. It is a pity Senator George Campbell is not here. The Irish economy faced similar problems to ours back in 1987. In fact, they were virtually bankrupt. And what did they do? They put forward a national recovery plan. I will tell you what they did. Because they put in place the sorts of things we are trying to do, they reduced unemployment from 20 per cent back to 12 per cent. It is still 12 per cent, but they have a 6½ per cent growth rate. They were able to do it because wage increases were limited to 2½ per cent and tax increases to a minimum.
The other thing they did which was most important was to get a good education in place. That is what Senator Vanstone and Dr Kemp are about.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to this report, A new Japan?: change in Asia's megamarket , I will not speak for any length of time but wish purely and simply to draw the attention of this chamber to the high quality of the report that is produced by the East Asia Analytical Unit of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Unfortunately, this is one of the units that has suffered as a result of cuts in this government's two budgets. Whilst it has not totally impaired the work of this particular unit, it nonetheless has slowed down the progress of some of the work that is produced. But this particular production is of the usual high standard of this East Asia Analytical Unit. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator Hogg in complimenting the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for this report. This year is the 40th anniversary of the Australia‐Japan Commerce Agreement. That was signed I think in July 1957. At that time it showed a lot of foresight, because the raw nerves of World War II were still very real. A decision was taken then to forge this relationship with Japan, and it has been a relationship of immense significance to Australia. Today, they are our major Asian market and it has been estimated that about 340,000 Australians depend on Japan for a job. From the Japanese point of view, the relationship is important for the importation of many of their raw materials. They are our major export market for a wide range of goods, including iron ore, gas from the North West Shelf, oil and a number of other products, including bauxite.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with Senator Hogg to make the point that it is a very important relationship and will continue to be that. It is important to realise on both sides of politics that it is a relationship to be built on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Bilateral Treaty: Australia and Republic of Kazakstan

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I would like to speak on document No. 18, the agreement between Australia and Kazakstan on commercial and economic cooperation. Most senators would know that there has been some difficulty with regard to Kazakstan, and the Joint Committee on Treaties has been looking at this particular treaty as to whether or not there should be a recommendation that its ratification proceed. I think honourable senators would also know about press reports on the difficulty that Telstra had in Kazakstan, where an agreement that they had with the Kazakstani government on the supply of telecommunications was terminated for a couple of reasons, one of which, I think, was that they failed to comply with a new law.

The treaties committee is somewhat concerned about this matter, as I am, because these agreements are essentially designed and intended for the improvement of trade between countries. I think what has to be kept in mind here, particularly in some of these countries which have emerged as a result of the break‐up of the Soviet Union, is that some of these East Asian countries are establishing themselves but it is important to Australian businesses that they are made aware of the circumstances that might prevail in some of these countries.

I have found it quite amazing that, in the national interest analysis that was presented to the committee initially, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade did not even inform the committee of the potential pitfalls that could occur within Kazakhstan. Of course, if you were a company interested in investment or cooperative ventures in that country, you would not be aware of them from the agreement or the treaty that is in place. That is somewhat of a reflection on the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade as it is currently operating. It is clear that Australia, from an international point of view, does not have a department, or indeed a minister, that are on top of this portfolio. I refer to the responsibility that the minister and his department have to Australian companies for the purposes of them achieving investment overseas.

It is clear from a public hearing that we had this week that there are difficulties. Some of those difficulties can be quite significant and could cause some companies to lose significant amounts of money. I am sure—and we raised questions in the committee about this—that the development of treaties between countries ought to be the responsibility of the minister. I understand the minister may well be meeting with the Kazakhstani minister this week, but it is important that these matters are resolved well in advance of treaties being signed.

Even at the signing there should be some clear understanding in regard to the processes and procedures that will be adopted. Telstra, as I understand it from the evidence that it submitted to the committee, entered into an agreement that was for all intents and purposes an indefinite agreement. There may well have been some weakness on the part of Telstra to adequately negotiate some aspects of the agreement that it had but overall there is a responsibility on the government of the country that has entered into a treaty arrangement with another country to offer some protection and some defence of Australia's companies and industries that seek to go overseas and invest.

The committee is going to further consider this particular treaty before making any recommendation that either it should or should not be ratified. It is obviously very important that we do have these treaties—there is no denying that. By all accounts, from an international point of view the current government is operating very poorly. We have a minister who really is not on top of his portfolio; he is unable to address a lot of these issues and this is reflecting very badly on this country. Any course of action, not only just with this treaty but in a whole range of other areas, will be very important to the successful outcomes or otherwise and to the guarantees, assurances and security provided so that companies from this country will be able to proceed to invest overseas.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

Paper No. 15 concerns the National Health and Medical Research Council. In that context, I want to address the announcement this week by the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) that the government was not going to uphold fully the advice given by the NHMRC about the use of the immunisation program for children—the current use of triple antigen at two, four and six months. Triple antigen is used for diphtheria, tetanus and whooping cough.

The whooping cough component of that immunisation can cause some side effects, often a reddening of the injection site and often a mild temperature, which is very disconcerting for the child and the family. It is vitally important that we increase the immunisation levels of whooping cough within our community. This is a disease that can kill very small babies and the health department tells me that an older person's immunity to this disease does tend to wane somewhat. So you need to have a very high level of immunisation, particularly in children, to actually ensure that you do not have a reservoir of the disease in the community.

We know that there have been six deaths this year in New South Wales alone from whooping cough, mainly of children younger than two months or of very small children—children who are too young to immunise. The government has undertaken an immunisation campaign and for that I congratulate it. I am very much in favour of immunisation for everything that a child can be immunised against because in my nursing career I have nursed children with diphtheria and I have seen children die of it.

I have nursed people with whooping cough and I have nursed children with tetanus. I have nursed children with polio—admittedly not in the acute stage but in its post form. Most people here are old enough to remember in their childhood the worry that our parents had with the 1955‐56 outbreak of poliomyelitis when, every time the child got a sore throat, our parents probably held their breaths in the hope that the child was not going to contract poliomyelitis. So I have seen those diseases and I have cared for people with them and I strongly support the immunisation of everybody who can be immunised.

But I have grave concern because of the announcement this week by the minister following his response to the NHMRC's work on the use of a drug for the vaccine for children in that first category. They are not going to use Infanrix, the new drug which is more expensive than the old one. This new drug, which contains part of the whooping cough virus that is sufficient to provide immunity, does not have some of the proteins found in the old drug that cause allergic reactions.

However, the minister has decided that this new drug—the dearer one—can be used for children of 18 months and in the booster for five‐year‐olds. That is a very good move because until now—because of the risks of reactions—children of 18 months and five years were getting the combined diphtheria and tetanus immunisation and not the whooping cough component. It now means that a drug with a whooping cough component can be used to immunise children of 18 months and can also be used in a booster for children of five years. That will reduce the reservoir of the disease in the community and it will also increase the amount of immunity in the community.

But I have concerns that they are going to not allow the use of this vaccine for children in their first three immunisation shots unless they have a strong family history of allergic reactions or unless they have had an allergic reaction to one of their previous vaccinations. This is a very cruel and very callous thing for the government to do.

It is vitally important that, if we are going to encourage parents to have their children fully immunised, we should be offering and making available to them the best vaccine that is going to have fewer side effects on their children. No parent likes to see an unhappy child with a red, sore arm, which often happens after triple antigen. I think the minister should really go back and seriously reconsider the decision made this week on this very important issue—a decision made just to save some money for the government. It is not doing anything for the welfare of those small children. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 June 1997, on motion by Senator O'Brien:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Brien, Sen Kerry

TALK.START.PARA: —We have recently seen further announcements by the government in relation to public sector superannuation which will have the effect of closing off those schemes for new employees, and thereby closing off the level of government contribution which applies in relation to those schemes for new employees. One would not expect there to be great future prospects in the Australian Public Service under this government because of its attitude to selling off, privatising, and contracting out various aspects of government services. Nevertheless, there will be some. I think it is regrettable that these schemes are ultimately being grandfathered, as it were, for the existing employees and that new employees will be denied the opportunity to join even the PSS scheme, which is the later of the two.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a fact that the previous government sought to give a choice for members of the CSS to move from that scheme to the PSS. But that scheme, too, will be grandfathered. We have now come to a situation where the government has announced that it will offer new employees a choice, excluding these two schemes, as I understand it, of five accumulation type superannuation schemes which will be operated by the private sector.

There are not too many people in the community who have the sort of level of knowledge about superannuation to make informed choices on their superannuation fund, particularly when they have newly joined the work force. It seems to me to be a policy based on ideology, not the realities of the workplace and the community, which drives this concept that their must be burgeoning choice in the selection of a superannuation fund.

I know there are some people who are desperate to make such a choice, but there are a great many other people in the community who are confused by superannuation, who do not understand how the industry works and who do not understand how a choice made early in their working life might affect them in later life.

I would not pretend to be able to make informed choices for other people—and I have some knowledge of the superannuation industry—without doing a lot of research on the matter. Yet we are seeing the possibility—and I saw an article in the paper recently—of legal action being available to employees against their employer if, for example, the choice of funds offered to them were not the funds or did not include funds which were in their best interest and they made the wrong choice. I am sure many employers do not want to find themselves in those circumstances.

That being the case, I think it is appropriate that the government consider its position in relation to the question of choice in superannuation—not only for its own funds but also for others. I am not saying that it should not occur. What I am saying is that if it does occur then there has to be a lot more information disseminated to the community, a lot more education of the community and a lot better understanding of superannuation in the community before we thrust this choice on members of the community.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly this evening, particularly in relation to a matter that I know you will be interested in, Mr Acting Deputy President. I refer to page 20 of the corporate plan, which sets out the proposal for the rescue and firefighting service charges for the various airports around Australia that have been established by Airservices Australia. In particular, I refer to those charges which have gone from a network price of $1.80 per landed aircraft tonne to various prices depending upon the airport. The airport at Launceston now attracts a charge of $7.68, an increase, as a result of these charges, of $5.88 per landed tonne for aircraft which lands there. Hobart airport attracts a charge of $6.41, an increase of $4.61 as a result of these charges.

SPEECH.PARA: This rescue and firefighting service measure which was implemented by Airservices Australia and has been in place since 1 July will effectively achieve an average reduction in the cost of rescue and firefighting services distributed across the network. It achieves that by imposing much higher burdens on the airports where there is a lower frequency of usage. In fact, the charges for rescue and firefighting services increased for every airport except Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne. They just happen to be the airports that are used for international aircraft almost to the exclusion of others. They are airports with a higher frequency of usage. It stands to reason that if you are going to distribute a standard charge for firefighting services in an airport which has a higher level of usage, you are going to get a lower per tonne of usage charge. On the other hand, if you go to remote airports, particularly those in Tasmania that rely on air travel, which have a lesser frequency of usage, you are going to have a higher charge. Those higher charges are going to affect the cost of travel to the more remote airports. It is not just Tasmania; these charges are being imposed all over the country. The effect of that is to reduce the charges for international carriers who fly into Sydney, Brisbane or Melbourne.

To achieve a reduction of the average network charge we need to distribute higher costs on the remote airports. It seems to me that this is not good policy in terms of the Australian transport industry. It is certainly not good policy for the remote airports, be they in the Northern Territory, Queensland, Western Australia or Tasmania. It is not good policy because it must have the effect of increasing the cost of travel to those airports. It is distributing the cost of travel disproportionately because those airports do not have a high frequency of usage.

It may be—it is not clear from these figures—that there remains some sort of cost distribution across the network in relation to the new charges. That can only be allocated to the overall cost of administration of Airservices Australia. I have raised this matter with the chief executive of Airservices. I am not satisfied that the matter has been considered properly. I will be seeking to pursue this matter further because, ultimately, the small airports around the more remote parts of Australia—the parts of Australia that perhaps rely most upon air travel, particularly in my state—are being penalised by this measure. I think that something has to be done. It has to be done soon. When you consider other things that are occurring in the air travel industry, this is just another unfortunate imposition on regional and remote Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee on the Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease settlement offer was handed down yesterday in this Senate. There were four speakers—Senator Bishop, the chairman of the committee, Senator Knowles, Senator Lees and Senator Harradine. Each of them spoke eloquently about the report. Tonight I wish to add a few further remarks as a member of the committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the cut and thrust of politics, the heat of debate in this chamber and in the other place, occasionally an issue comes along that affects us all in such a way that we put aside political differences and endeavour to work towards a unanimous position. I am sure we try to do that on many occasions, but sadly it does not always occur.

When the committee looked at the issue of the plight of persons who were recipients of the growth hormone program some years ago, who now live in the fear of contracting CJD, I am sure that all members of the committee—it is reflected in the report—recognised that this is an issue which is above politics. It is a situation where people, quite innocently trusting in the health system and trusting in the marvels of medicine and science, sought assistance to deal with the particular problems they had—whether it be children with a growth deficiency or women who were unable to fall pregnant.

Under this program, young children and women received injections of human pituitary gland hormones, which were intended to assist them to overcome their problems. Sadly, it was discovered some years later that there was a potential for such persons to contract the deadly CJD virus, a virus that can lay dormant for 20 to 30 years. Because that program was conducted under the umbrella of the government—the hormone treatment was made available through the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories—the parliament had to take responsibility.

When this issue came to light some five to 10 years ago, a report was commissioned by the previous government, a report written by Professor Allars. I can remember coming into this parliament in May 1994 and being handed bundles and bundles of government reports. Amongst them was a report on the CJD issue. I thought, `What the heck is that?' I did not have a clue about it. Subsequently, revisiting that report through this inquiry, I came to appreciate the courage that people have when faced with the sort of adversity that people who were under this program are now faced with. They live with the fear that they may have contracted this disease and may in years to come suffer quite a horrible death.

The committee was charged with looking at this issue. It had become a legal issue because of legal action taken by some of the recipients, including people who have since tragically lost their lives because they have contracted CJD. It also includes persons who have suffered psychiatric stress, nervous shock or some similar stress because of this fear of contracting the disease in the future.

Unfortunately, time does not permit me to go right through all those issues tonight, but I encourage each and every senator to find some time to read this report. You will find evidence of innocent victims of a government program, which was clearly conducted with the best of intentions, being given treatment that was also made available in overseas countries and with which unfortunately it was discovered, not until years later, that in some cases there was a terrible virus evident in the treatment that had been granted.

Witnesses who appeared before the committee were clearly distressed and lived with the constant fear of contracting the disease. They were witnesses who felt they could never have children in the future because of the fear of passing on the potential deadly virus. They were witnesses who first found out about the potential for contracting CJD years after they had been on the program—maybe 10 or 15 years later. They received a phone call from their doctor to say, `By the way, you had better come in and see me.' When they saw their doctor, they were told, `You were on this program 10 or 15 years ago, and there is a chance you will contract this deadly virus.' You can imagine the impact that that had upon those people.

The major duty of this committee, in listening to that evidence, was to consider whether or not the position that the government had adopted—both the previous government and this government—in providing some settlement, some resolution of the victims' difficulties, was adequate. In a number of cases we found that it was not. Certainly, claimants were denied legal aid, and the committee has recommended that that position be reviewed. They were denied legal aid apparently because they were seeking to pursue a test case that may not quite have fitted into the guidelines at the time, and subsequently there was a change of government which changed the rules again.

They were offered a settlement that basically involved an offer of damages in the event that they contracted CJD some time in the future. They were told by their own solicitors, who were passing on the Australian Government Solicitor's offer, that they really should accept that offer. They had, at one stage, only a month or two to accept that offer. If they did not accept that offer in full settlement of their claims, they were told that they were on their own and that they might have to bear the full costs of taking action against the government.

Fortunately, I think this committee's recommendations have put that proposal to bed. The committee has recommended that the government allocate additional funds to give some compensation to these people who, in some cases, have suffered not only psychiatric stress but also a significant disturbance to their lifestyle. There is much more that one could say about this issue and, as I have said, I urge all senators to read the report. It is sobering, and it is a lesson for us all on how sometimes the best programs of governments can go wrong and people are affected. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —This week saw the government announce its new initiatives for small business; a new deal and a fair deal. It prompts the question of why the government should support small business. In 1995‐96, there were 605,000 new reasons why the government should support small business. In fact, small business was the primary generator of new jobs in 1995‐96, with companies employing fewer than 20 people contributing 57 per cent of new jobs created.

SPEECH.PARA: Most job growth was created by micro‐businesses—that is, firms employing fewer than five workers. The wholesale trade, retail trade, accommodation, cafes and restaurant industries had the highest proportion of businesses which generated new jobs. Data from the Industry Commission's small business employment report released on 28 August this year found that between 1983‐84 and 1994‐95, private, non‐farm sector firms with fewer than 100 employees increased their market share of national employment by five percentage points, to nearly 47 per cent. During the same period, there was little change in the employment share of large firms. Australia now has a higher percentage of workers in small business than have the large industrialised economies such as the United States, United Kingdom, Germany and France.

If big business think that they are getting a raw deal, maybe they should consider the following statistics taken from the ABS business growth and performance survey released on 22 September 1997. It was small business that took the lead on unemployment while big business did nothing during 1995 to 1996. In fact, medium businesses—defined as those businesses employing between 20 and 200 workers—contributed 297,000 or 28 per cent to total job generation; big business contributed 14 per cent. This was despite the fact that in 1995‐96 43.5 per cent of big businesses increased their yearly income compared with micro, small and medium sized business, which recorded lesser fortunes.

The business community, of course, is playing an important role in fixing up unemployment. It is not just for government to solve the problem of unemployment. Solving unemployment also requires the business community to take greater responsibility and ownership over this terrible problem. Business is all about managing risk and embracing new and innovative ideas, not only through adapting to new technologies and finding where new jobs are, but also by embracing new employment initiatives, alternative work arrangements and flexibility in the workplace.

The five lecture series on `The future of work', recently presented by Radio National, dismissed the claim that there are just not enough jobs to go around. Robert Theobald, author of `Reworking success', stated:
The issue is not whether work is available—it is whether jobs provide a context in which 21st century activities can be most successfully accomplished.

Small business has demonstrated a willingness to do its part with available jobs to help fix unemployment, and the government remains committed to this sector and to looking after those businesses which look after Australians who are out of work.

What is the government doing to help small business? Since coming into office, the Howard government has been fixing the fundamentals and creating an economic environment conducive to doing business. In addition to the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), `More time for business', which was delivered in March 1997, the government's fair trading reform package delivers a comprehensive reform agenda to protect small business against unfair conduct by big business. The package of protections includes: protection against unfair conduct; industry codes of conduct; retail tenancies safety net; franchising reform; access to justice and enforcement; access to finance; and education and information packages on fair trading issues.

The response to the government's fair trading reform package announced by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) has been, I think it is fair to say, jubilant. The Service Station Association press release described the new package as `the most comprehensive small business package in history'. The MTAA said `these are the most exciting decisions made on behalf of small business for many decades'. The Australian Small Business Association said in their press release, `The policy passes small business test with flying colours.' The Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association congratulated the government `in producing a well balanced and focused initiative'. Small business is pleased that these initiatives have been implemented.

In tonight's debate I want to touch briefly on one of the key aspects of the government's fair trading reform package relating to unfair conduct and trade practices reform. A dominant theme of the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology Finding a balance: towards fairer trading in Australia was the wide range of business conduct damaging to small business.
A reading of the report leaves one in no doubt as to the veracity of the statement by the President of the United Retailers Association that:
. . . it is war out there between the retailers and the owners and managers.

The report identified five common features of unfair conduct impinging on small business. These include: little or no ability to negotiate terms of the contract; inadequate disclosure of relevant and important commercial information which small business should be aware of before entering into transactions; inadequate and unclear disclosure of important terms of the contract; contract renegotiations which actually favour the dominant party; and an inability or unwillingness to access quick, cheap and market‐sensitive ways of dealing with disputes for fear of reprisal.
The sentiment of small business towards the existing legislative framework that was put in under Labor was summed up appropriately by Mr Allan Asher, Deputy Chairman of the ACCC, when he said:

. . . in my view, it is a cruel hoax to give people a legal provision that is not enforceable. By enforceable, I do not just mean that there is a legal right but that there is some real capacity to be able to use it.

I am happy to say that the government has acted decisively on this issue by introducing a new provision in the Trade Practices Act that will give small business consumers genuine access to protection against unconscionable conduct, and provisions which will allow industry‐designed codes of practice, in whole or in part, to be legally underpinned and to be made mandatory under the Trade Practices Act and enforced as breaches of the act.
In addition, the new section 51AC of the Trade Practices Act diffuses the concerns of small business. The Australian Automobile Dealers Association stated:

. . . in practice there has been no effective protection for franchisees or other small business operators, through either common law or the current provisions of the Trade Practices Act—despite the enactment in 1992 of s. 51AA.
The changes will offer legal protection against unconscionable conduct comparable to that afforded to consumers. This is something that small business has long been asking government to do.

The introduction of a further section, section 51AD, ensures that a person bound by the act must not contravene prescribed industry codes. There are, as I said before, two types of codes—voluntary and mandatory. Mandatory codes will be prescribed only where self‐regulation has not worked or is not appropriate. It will apply to all participants in the relevant industry. Those breaching the codes will be subject to injunctions, damages or undertakings to the ACCC to disclose information. Additional resources will be given to support small business.

Big business has really nothing to fear either. No‐one could seriously suggest that dominant parties should be able to act unconscionably towards smaller firms. This is a government that actually introduces initiatives that reward businesses for good commercial decisions to invest, to innovate and, most importantly, to employ Australians. The introduction of the fair trading reform package is proof that the government has listened, understood and launched into action.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr Tom Considine Australia-Ireland Parliamentary Friendship Group Orphans of the Empire

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, could I add my personal best wishes to the good wishes you extended to Tom Considine and his family for the very, very best for the future. I was not aware that this was his last day. But we certainly do wish him and his family all the very best.

SPEECH.PARA: Last evening I had some brief words to say about what has become a rather controversial visit to Ireland, by the Australia‐Ireland Parliamentary Friendship Group, between 14 and 18 June 1997. I understand that the airwaves, particularly those of Sydney, today resounded with some counter-accusations about what was achieved on the trip. Like my colleagues who spoke last evening, I will try to contain myself within those time constraints we imposed upon ourselves.

BREAK.PARA: As was indicated by the leader of the delegation, Senator Calvert, last night when he tabled the report, we did prepare a report. That, however, is merely a snapshot of the very intensive week of activities we experienced in Ireland—a week of activities which, I believe, achieved the objectives that the delegation set for itself before embarking on the trip.

The criticism that has been made of the delegation and its visit, I suggest, is grossly unfounded because those who criticised did not seek to examine what the objectives of that visit were. If they had and if, in doing so, they had talked to members of the delegation who embarked on the visit, they could, in turn, have checked whether or not the objectives had been achieved. To my mind, they certainly have been achieved.

In speaking here tonight and putting some matters on the record, I want to confine my remarks simply to the International Fund for Ireland. I think it is particularly important that I do speak about the International Fund for Ireland.

I said last evening that the Australian government, the Australian taxpayers, are making a real contribution, a very huge contribution, to the peace process that is going on in that divided nation of Ireland. Our visit was only to the Republic of Ireland, and it was at the invitation of the Irish parliament, Dail Eireann. Nonetheless, we did discuss with various individuals, including politicians, the conflict that exists between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.

The International Fund for Ireland is, as its name states, an international organisation which was established by the British government and the Irish government in 1986. Its objectives are to promote economic and social advance; and to encourage contact, dialogue and reconciliation between nationalist and unionist throughout Ireland. Its founding agreement requires the fund to spend about three-quarters of its resources in Northern Ireland, and about a quarter in the southern border counties. The Australian Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Eddy Stevens, attends board meetings as an Australian observer.

Australia in September 1994, under its then Prime Minister, announced that it would make a contribution to the international fund of some $7 million over five years. The first three instalments have been sent over there, and there is a further $3 million outstanding from that commitment. Our one recommendation in the report to the parliament, and from there on to the government, is that that contribution obligation be fulfilled.

It is interesting to note in passing that the International Fund for Ireland has been audited. The audit was undertaken in 1995 by a company named KPMG Management Consulting. That company found in its audit that the fund had demonstrated that it had been very successful in its twin areas of operation: economic regeneration and reconciliation. In regard to the former, it found that the fund had assisted in the creation of approximately 24,000 jobs in the period to September 1994.

In addition, the audit concluded that the fund had made a major impact in fostering dialogue and reconciliation between the two traditions. Some 441 organisations which operate on a cross-community or cross-border basis had been assisted by the fund, involving some 5,700 community leaders. An update of the fund in 1995 found similar success in the creation of employment, and suggested it had a positive impact on the process of reconciliation.

The level of employment created through the fund projects has now risen to 28,000 jobs. That is particularly important when you examine the report and see the area that the delegation went and visited—in particular, Dundalk, which is a depressed area that in 1991 had an unemployment rate of some 26.4 per cent. That is 56 per cent higher than the national average, which was then at 16.9 per cent. The Australian taxpayer is assisting with the project we went to see and which we examined in detail, and where we met a large number of people, in Dundalk, with the employment partnership program.

That partnership program, in itself, is very interesting. It involves a wide range of organisations which include the Department of Social Welfare, County Louth Vocational Education Committee, the North Eastern Health Board, the County Louth Enterprise Board, the Industrial Development Authority of Ireland, the local urban council and the county council, as well as local banks, business enterprises, trade unions and other enterprises. It was indeed, to our minds, a success story. It was a success story which paid off in the creation of jobs—jobs which have provided income to people, jobs which have stopped idle hands from getting into mischief. And, of course, with it being a border county, one can understand the type of mischief that people can get into.

Our one recommendation is that the obligation that the previous Australian government entered into be fulfilled. This current government has indeed fulfilled the obligation to date. We hope that the remaining $3 million will continue to be given.

It was a very warm delegation and a large delegation, with some 11 members participating in it. We all got on well during the period of time we were pressed together. We were on a coach for quite a considerable amount of time in the travels that we undertook, and we did get on well. I do believe that we achieved some things; we certainly achieved the objective of continuing the very warm relationships that exist between two countries. Unfortunately, I have gone a little over my time, and I hope my colleagues will forgive me for that.

I want to make very brief mention of a book that is going to be launched in Sydney on Monday next. Unfortunately I will not be able to be in Sydney for the launch, which will be undertaken by Mr David Hill. Among other things, David Hill's claim to fame is that he was brought to Australia as a child migrant of this country. For that reason he is launching this book called Orphans of the empire, which, its cover says, is `The shocking story of child migration to Australia' and which:
. . . draws back the curtain on a part of Australian and British history that has been crying out for recognition. All Australians should read it.
They are the words of Sir Ronald Wilson, the former President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, who recently presided over a major inquiry into the stolen children.
I would like to read one small paragraph from the book, which unfortunately I have not had time to read in the depth that I would like:

One of the stranger cases of the separation of siblings involves two brothers, Alex McDonald and Bert McGregor, who attended the same Christian Brothers' orphanage, grew to adulthood and lived briefly in neighbouring streets without knowing they were related. Alex joined the Jesuit Order and Bert jointed the Christian Brothers. They discovered their relationship in a roundabout way, when Alex used the services of Margaret Humphreys to find his mother. His mother was meanwhile trying to find her other son (Bert). All three found each other more or less simultaneously.
It then refers to chapter 12. It goes on:

Both men believe the Christian Brothers Order deliberately withheld information from them even as adults. This claim is denied by the Christian Brothers, who blame absence of records and/or human error.

That is just one of many shocking stories that is contained in the book. I certainly look forward to reading it but, in glancing through it, it is a book that I would recommend to anybody who has a real feel for Australian history, particularly migration history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak tonight on one of the government's most significant reform packages to date, and that is `Agriculture—Advancing Australia'. This $517 million package was recently launched by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and my National Party colleague Mr John Anderson, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It brings together the inadequate tangle of assistance which had sprung up over the years, especially under the previous government, in a mostly ad hoc fashion. We now have a proper program of support, investment and education for the nation's farming families.

SPEECH.PARA: John Anderson deserves congratulations for this package. To call it simply a $517 million package is only to tell half the story. The $517 million includes more than $200 million more than was allocated in the 1996‐97 budget, and to have brokered this deal through cabinet is an enormous achievement. All of us in the coalition, especially those of us who have connections with regional Australia, are pleased to have delivered such a substantial package.

The AAA package, as it is called, has been very well received by farming families, rural organisations and rural commentators. Mr Ian Donges, the President of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, called it a well‐balanced series of measures which will set the framework for self‐reliance in Australia's rural industries. The Australian called it a step on the path to making the farm sector more efficient while extending to it the welfare benefits the rest of the community take for granted. Peter Austin, in the Land, said it was just what the rural sector needed.

The scope of the package demonstrates how serious we are about making major changes to benefit those on the land, and all the regional jobs that flow from a buoyant rural economy. The major features of the package are as follows. Firstly, the creation of the tax linked commercialised farm management deposit scheme will provide farmers with the tools they need for greater self‐reliance, allowing them to invest the considerable sum of $300,000 as a buffer against lean times and drought. Interest will be paid at market rates and deposits will be fully tax deductible in the year that they are made and taxable in the year of withdrawal. Reports about the possible impact of the El Nino make this scheme particularly timely. The capacity of farm families to survive drought and economic downturn was made much more difficult in the Labor years, what with high interest rates, high inflation, the cost‐price squeeze and the gutting of the original IED scheme, which had provided the capacity for prudent farmers to provide for lean times and also drought.

Secondly, there is a revamped drought relief repayment, called the exceptional circumstances relief payment, which will be available to farmers experiencing other rare and severe events, not only those in droughts. This will provide some welfare assistance to farm families—assistance that is, of course, available to all other Australians.

Thirdly, there is a $50 million farm business improvement program, which will pro vide assistance for skills development, farm business planning, farm performance, risk management, marketing and natural resource management, and things like landcare in addition to that. Education is the key to everything, as we know, and that is as true of those involved in primary industry as it is in other sectors of the community.

Fourthly, there is the introduction of the farm family restart scheme, which will deliver improved welfare to the farm sector to support them while they assess future opportunities, and to allow them to make up their own minds about their future—which is very important to people; they do not like to be pushed around on the land—and make any necessary changes that are suitable for them, including support if families choose to leave the industry and leave the land.

Fifthly, there is an improved rural communities program which will provide flexible grants to assist rural communities, offer such essential services as rural counsellors—who have been an integral part in the restructuring of the bush over the last few years and most of whom have done an absolutely splendid job in the most difficult circumstances—telecentres and, of course, credit union facilities. Referring to the successful credit care scheme, I know that Senator Payne is here tonight and I would just like to put on record the integral part that she played in that very worthwhile organisation before she came into the Senate.

And, lastly, there is the commitment to generational farm transfer. This is one of the most important parts of the package, because it provides the opportunity for farmers to retire and to gift their farms without jeopardising their access to the age pension. At the moment, farmers are ineligible to receive the pension for five years, if they give away assets in excess of $10,000 a year. This has, understandably, discouraged many from transferring ownership to the next generation—especially as a lot of farmers are very conservative in their estate planning.

Under this scheme, the government has declared a three‐year moratorium on these gifting provisions so that this time older farmers who make this assets transfer will have immediate access to the age pension. The moratorium is limited to net assets of $500,000 per farm, and other conditions apply, including an income test. By acknowledging the difficulties surrounding the gifting and aggregation of farms and proposing changes, the coalition has taken on some of the biggest challenges faced by farming families—a set of serious problems ignored by the previous government. If you recall, the previous Prime Minister called himself `the farmers' friend'.

It is the coalition who has listened to farmers in dire straits, to those who have slipped through the holes marked `farming family' in our welfare safety net. It is this government which has heard the pleas of the men and women who live in regional areas and who really call for government assistance but at this time whose options have run out.

Labor had little understanding of primary industry. They floundered as drought ravished the country and as commodity prices plummeted. You may recall that then Prime Minister Keating lectured those who live in the bush by saying that drought is a natural occurrence and therefore farmers should prepare themselves for it. And so they should, but they would like a little bit of help to make that possible. To encourage them, as this package does, is something that we should all be very pleased with.

When we came to office last year, we found that our packaging costs were 40 per cent higher than in Europe or in the United States; we found meat processing costs in our best plants were three times higher than those in the United States equivalents and almost twice those in New Zealand; and we found that it cost twice as much to transport grain here than it did over similar distances in the United States and even in the UK. In fact, if it were not for the National‐Liberal party coalition, then in opposition, proper drought relief payments would never have existed. It is as simple as that. We can take a substantial credit for embarrassing the previous government into taking the very important and difficult decision it was for them and the costly decision it was for them—but it was in the interests of all the Australian community that that was done.

Finally, for the cynics and knockers who believe that farmers do not deserve help and that assisting primary production is a waste of time, I say to them, `Well, you're simply wrong.' The editorial in the Financial Review of 16 September is a good example of the writers being patronising. It begins: `How do you wean farmers off their welfare mentality?' It goes on to accuse this government of `slugging non-farmer Australians to pay for special handouts to farmers'. Can I say that the reporting of rural matters by our major dailies is inadequate and it does them a great disservice.

I give as an example the fact that, between 1990 and 1997—a very difficult time for wool producers—there has never been a credible interpretation and discussion of that issue in any of the major newspapers. I think that is a great mistake. The print media have served Australian farmers particularly badly over recent years. Their reporting is often simply insulting and untrue. As some would say: there is life—Australia's lifeblood—outside the boardrooms of Sydney and Melbourne. The Agriculture—Advancing Australia package does not come out of a vacuum. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to the comments by Senator Sandy Macdonald. I do not wish to debate them here tonight; I will certainly do so on another occasion because it is an important issue that needs debate and attention. I could not help but think, as I listened to Senator Macdonald's recitation about the assistance provided to farmers in this so-called assistance package—I think he mentioned a figure of about half a billion dollars or more—that it is a pity that the same people that Senator Macdonald represents in the farming community and the farming organisations, such as the NFF, do not take stock and have a think about their own attitudes to that other issue that is so important to the land, and that is the issue of native title. Yet they stand up on so many occasions and attack the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of this country because they happen to have received some assistance over the years. It is on that theme that I wish to speak tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the major issues that the parliament will be debating—an issue it is debating in the other place and will certainly be debating in this chamber in the coming weeks—is that of native title, and particularly the government's response to the Wik decision. I want to talk about something positive because I believe we are going to hear a lot of ignorant comments in the coming weeks, as we have done, when people attack the justified concerns of our indigenous people. I want to talk about some positive things that are happening in this area of reconciliation between white Australians and our indigenous people.

I come from the Sutherland Shire and I have spoken about it on many occasions. It claims to be the birthplace of the nation. That is where Captain Cook landed, at Kurnell, in 1770. We do not have an Aboriginal community in the Sutherland Shire, as such, but we have a sister relationship with the Jawoyn people of the Northern Territory. The Sutherland Shire Council had the foresight, a number of years ago, to see that to assist the process of reconciliation we should try to build links between white Australia, particularly white Australians in the cities, and our indigenous people. So they set up a relationship between the Sutherland Shire and the Jawoyn nation in the Northern Territory.

In June‐July this year a number of school students from the shire visited the Jawoyn nation in the Northern Territory for two weeks. I would like to put their names into the Hansard because these young students represent the hope, I believe, of bringing about eventual reconciliation. They are: Liz Favaloro, Andrew Strudwick, Amy Trindall, Glen Sullivan, Ian Sullivan, Carolyn Read and Mr Eddie Pender, who is the National Parks and Wildlife Service ranger who organised and accompanied the students on their tour. They spent some 10 days in the territory. They visited the major sites such as Kakadu and Katherine Gorge.

But they also spent time living with the Jawoyn people at the Werebun community and the Barunga community. They had the opportunity to experience first hand the cultural heritage of the Jawoyn people. They were introduced to traditional Aboriginal lifestyles such as searching for bush tucker, living out in the open, attending ceremonies and listening to the stories.
I would like to read from a report that has been written by one of the students, Liz Favaloro, because it sums up superbly the experience that these young students had. She says:

This morning we went to a place named Manyalluluk where we met some of the Jawoyn students. This journey has been so much fun and I have learnt so much already about a different culture and different lifestyles. I can't believe that we have already been here for four days.

Exchange students met at Manyalluluk to go on a bush walk where we ate, smelt and observed different roots, leaves, berries and trees. Becoming familiar with them, I have learnt of the roots which dye different materials, leaves which act as an antiseptic, edible fruits, leaves which stun fish, edible honey ants, etc.
After such an enjoyable walk we were offered a delicious lunch ranging from Kangaroo, Damper and different salads. Absolutely delicious!
All the Jawoyn students and Sydney exchange students exercised after lunch by a very fast game of football. We are beginning to become great friends and liking each others company very much.

We are all going to "Birdie Creek" for an overnight stay which was really fantastic. As soon as the sun set the fires began to blaze and all the children ranging from all ages performed a corroboree, it was terrific—then to top the night off Phyllis (an Aboriginal elder) spoke to all of us around the campfire. She told a story of the white men and how life was when she was younger. Phyllis is a wonderful storyteller, I could have listened to her words of wisdom for hours.
Camping under the stars for the night with the cool breeze, clean air and natural surroundings nothing could have been better.

Obviously, a fascinating and rewarding experience—an opportunity for students from Sydney to get together with students from the Jawoyn nation and experience what we all hope for in this country—true reconciliation and a recognition of the great culture of our indigenous people.

But the story does not end there because this week in the Sutherland Shire there is a return trip from students of the Jawoyn nation. I would like to read their names into the record: Houia Haerewa, Antony Groves, David Groves, Scott Lee, Darian Hood, Leah Jumbililie, Larissa Lee, Shaunette Mumbin, Gaston Bowden, Helen Lee and Ruth Kelly. Those students are accompanied by Phyllis Winjarra, the elder of the Jawoyn people who read those stories to the students back in June and July.

This is a terrific initiative. I had the opportunity to meet those students from the Sutherland Shire at a flag raising ceremony when they returned. I met them with Burnum Burnum, who recently passed away. Burnum Burnum believed that the way to true reconciliation was for our younger people to come to understand the great cultural heritage and tradition of our indigenous people. The students of the Sutherland Shire and the students of the Jawoyn nation and all those people who have cooperated to put this project together deserve our congratulations. We can all learn a lesson from what they have experienced. They are showing us the way to true reconciliation.
